column16: Join the Digital Library Pedagogy Group (#DLFteach) community of practice for updates about #DLFteach work this year and open discussion about future projects and ways we can support one another. This working lunch allows us to check in with our community, welcome new members, and chart a path forward.
column17: Join the Digital Library Pedagogy Group (#DLFteach) community of practice for updates about #DLFteach work this year and open discussion about future projects and ways we can support one another. This working lunch allows us to check in with our community, welcome new members, and chart a path forward.
column18:
The DLF Digital Library Pedagogy Group (#DLFteach) working lunch will feature updates on the group’s work over the past year. Attendees and facilitators will discuss how to build a community of practice around teaching with and about digital resources and tools, especially as we get used to teaching in a world of increased distance learning. This working lunch will also give attendees the chance to join us in proposing, discussing, and planning future #DLFteach work. In the spirit of the ongoing #DLFteach Toolkit series of publications, participants are also invited to bring their own lesson plans, assignments, and strategies for feedback, though not required. Our discussion will follow this agenda:

Snapshots of the past year’s work and open discussion (10 min)

Small group discussions and brainstorming future work of #DLFteach (40 min)

Report on group discussion and announcements (10 min)

Join the discussion and continue to build the community of digital library pedagogy, and help us celebrate the fifth birthday of the DLF Digital Library Pedagogy Group!

column2: Digital Preservation 2020: Get Active with DP
column7: Thinking Outside the Inbox: New Developments in Email Archiving
column9: email, archiving, PDF, systems, preservation
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Email records present an ongoing challenge to the archival field, as they are produced in high volumes, are technically complex, and frequently contain sensitive information. This panel will discuss four projects currently underway or recently concluded, all designed to better support organizations in their pursuit of email archiving.
column17: Email records present an ongoing challenge to the archival field, as they are produced in high volumes, are technically complex, and frequently contain sensitive information. This panel will discuss four projects currently underway or recently concluded, all designed to better support organizations in their pursuit of email archiving.
column18:
Email has been utilized as a communication tool since the 1970s, and despite many alternative modes of communication emerging over the decades, its continued popularity is clear, with over 293 billion emails sent and received per day. The importance of preserving these records and their potential to serve as documents of decision-making and correspondence down to the second can hardly be overstated. Even so, the digital archiving and preservation community continues to struggle with solutions to acquire, process, preserve and provide access to this significant format. Email records are produced in high volumes, are technically complex, and frequently contain sensitive information. Despite the intimidating prospect of a massive record that often poses a high security risk, professionals in our field continue to actively seek out solutions in the opportunities.

This panel discusses four projects in various stages, all meant to meet different challenges inherent in email archiving. Stanford Libraries will review their recent grant designed to enhance the processing and discovery elements of ePADD, as well as look forward to creating a sustainable roadmap for the open source system. Harvard Library will discuss the evolution of their preservation solution for email, as well as upcoming development. And the University of Illinois will present two projects: The Email to PDF grant, which brought together a range of practitioners in the email archiving and PDF spheres to propose new preservation options; and the Email Archives: Building Capacity and Community Program, a grant opportunity, providing additional means for archiving support.

These projects collectively highlight key challenges in sustainability and problem-solving, as well as the creative and persistent approaches email archiving professionals employ in their pursuit to meet these challenges head-on instead of waiting and sitting on our collective hands.

column5: University of Florida & Digital Library of the Caribbean, United States of America
column7: Self-Determination: Intermutuality and Supporting Each According to Their Needs - Utilizing Agile/Scrum and Management Practices
column9: procedural justice, agency, inclusivity, meaningful work
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
Leadership and management
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Libraries have been instruments of oppression and colonization. Alternative models have emerged in response: decolonizing, postcolonial, postcustodial, slow archives. We discuss the Digital Library of the Caribbean model with shared governance, mutual aid, mutual dependency, and the strategic application of agile/scrum technical development, and managerial theories based on fairness.
column17: Libraries have been instruments of oppression and colonization. Alternative models have emerged in response: decolonizing, postcolonial, postcustodial, slow archives. We discuss the Digital Library of the Caribbean model with shared governance, mutual aid, mutual dependency, and the strategic application of agile/scrum technical development, and managerial theories based on fairness.
column18:
Power inequities mean even well-intended museums and libraries routinely disrupt people’s knowledge of and access to their cultural heritage. These institutions were allies in or at least instruments of the political and legal dominance of one culture over others. Alternative or mitigative models to this colonization have emerged in response: decolonizing, postcolonial, postcustodial, and slow archives. This presentation discusses an alternative model based on the Digital Library of the Caribbean (dLOC), which incorporates tenants of shared governance, mutual aid, generous thinking, community building, polycentrism, collaborative pluralism, and mutual dependency. Importantly, we discuss dLOC’s ways of working: utilizing concepts and methods from agile/scrum technical development and managerial theories based on fairness, fostering self-determination and supporting our communities.

dLOC’s alternative model is baked-in and extends through all aspects, including organizational design and technical development. For example, dLOC’s technical team follows agile and scrum for equitably engaging stakeholders to support each according to their needs. While agile and scrum are often utilized for deeply capitalistic ends, these are also methods that avoid top-down controls and instead enable voice of those most in need and most impacted by digital library technologies. These range from developers to stakeholders at partner institutions. Additionally, dLOC’s alternative model reflects concepts from progressive management theory that have developed over time in the literature but are not commonly applied to scholarship on digital libraries. These broad concepts include agency, procedural justice, and organizational support, and translate to meaningful work and community supports for other stakeholders and institutions.

column16: Virginia Tech University Libraries is hosting a discussion-based unconference session to gather colleagues working or interested in cloud-native digital libraries development. VTUL is developing a cloud-native digital asset management and preservation platform. We invite discussion on similar approaches and identify intersections to work toward a common approach.
column17: Virginia Tech University Libraries is hosting a discussion-based unconference session to gather colleagues working or interested in cloud-native digital libraries development. VTUL is developing a cloud-native digital asset management and preservation platform. We invite discussion on similar approaches and identify intersections to work toward a common approach.
column18:
Virginia Tech University Libraries (VTUL) would like to host a discussion-based unconference session to gather colleagues working in or interested in cloud-native Digital Libraries development. VTUL is developing a microservices, template-based, cloud-native, multi-site digital asset management, and preservation platform. We’d like to gather like-minded colleagues to discuss their work and interest in similar approaches and identify points of intersection to determine interest in working toward a common approach.

We will invite attendees to briefly describe their work and interests via a short survey to be distributed to attendees at the beginning of the unconference. The unconference session will include a brief introduction to the topic and feature small group and large group discussions on the intersection of work and interest in exploring opportunities to work together. Session attendees will be asked to group up based on topics that emerge in the survey results or in the initial session discussion, and then report back during the final group discussion.

We expect the following themes might emerge:
- Cloud-native approaches versus vendor neutrality
- Infrastructure component choices
- Preservation in a black box
- Defining services and service compositions and documented interfaces to support multiple implementations

The Cloud-Native Digital Libraries unconference aligns with the conference theme Technologies, infrastructure, and/or vendor relations in that the goal of this unconference is to explore new approaches to digital libraries platforms. All products, notes, diagrams, and presentations will be made available following the session. The unconference conveners will also provide a summary of the event and anonymous responses.

column2: Digital Preservation 2020: Get Active with DP
column5: Virginia Tech, United States of America
column7: A Cloud-based Serverless Microservices Application for Digital Preservation
column9: digital preservation, cloud storage, cost, trust, microservices
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Virginia Tech University Libraries is developing a cloud-based, serverless, microservice application to support digital asset management, preservation, and access. This presentation will outline the balance of cost-effectiveness and creating a trustworthy platform while relying on the cloud.
column17: Virginia Tech University Libraries is developing a cloud-based, serverless, microservice application to support digital asset management, preservation, and access. This presentation will outline the balance of cost-effectiveness and creating a trustworthy platform while relying on the cloud.
column18:
Virginia Tech University Libraries (VTUL) began work on our Digital Libraries Platform to address difficulty building digital preservation solutions with software not designed for that purpose; to reduce our maintenance obligations and expense of on-premises servers; and to provide scalable, performant systems that were beyond our ability or budget to provide internally. To address this, VTUL is developing a cloud-based serverless microservice application to support digital asset management, preservation, and access. In light of the expected effects of Covid-19 on our budget, we value that cloud providers allow us to choose services and how those services are delivered based on cost and performance. We are therefore able to differentiate between services that require performance and those that can run asynchronously at a lower cost.

We’ve found that implementing this microservice architecture, as opposed to monolithic architectures, allows us to develop, version, and call services independently based on the Levels of Digital Preservation appropriate for specific materials. Preservation microservices include on-ingest and scheduled fixity, format characterization, and other functionality that may be called independently and are instantiated only when needed.

In this presentation we will focus on a serverless cloud-native approach to fixity creation and validation as well as the financial and transparency implications of this approach. While cloud-vendors advertise 99.9999% data durability, we have chosen to implement our own services to verify data in blackbox vendor systems.

This presentation aligns with the conference theme Sustainable Digital Preservation Practices in that we are exploring cost-effective and trustworthy approaches to digital preservation.

column7: Finding a Good Fit: Scaling Best Practices for Born-Digital Material to Fit the Needs of Diverse Communities
column9: Born-digital records, Sustainability, Stewardship, Personal Digital Archiving
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14: BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column16: Many different types and sizes of institutions hold and continue to acquire born-digital materials in their collections, and seek flexible and sustainable solutions for stewarding these materials. This panel brings together three non-academic institutions who have navigated creating and maintaining digital programs in a variety of settings, for diverse audiences.
column17: Many different types and sizes of institutions hold and continue to acquire born-digital materials in their collections, and seek flexible and sustainable solutions for stewarding these materials. This panel brings together three non-academic institutions who have navigated creating and maintaining digital programs in a variety of settings, for diverse audiences.
column18:
There is a growing literature on best practices and recommendations for acquiring, processing, and stewarding born-digital materials in archival repositories. These recommendations and best practices have primarily been articulated by large and well-funded research universities, often with dedicated positions and substantial equipment budgets. However, many different types and sizes of institutions already hold born-digital materials in their collections, continue to acquire these materials, and seek flexible and sustainable solutions for stewarding these materials. It can be difficult to adapt and scale best practices to meet the needs of smaller institutions, which may have diverse levels of IT infrastructure or support, funding for staff and equipment, collecting focuses, and audiences. This panel brings together three non-academic institutions who have navigated creating and maintaining digital programs in very different settings, and for different audiences: New-York Historical Society (N-YHS), the Memory Lab Network at the District of Columbia Public Library, and Brooklyn Historical Society.

Our session will address key challenges and questions that practitioners have encountered in creating and maintaining born-digital programs at their institutions. The three panelists will give brief presentations of their work. Margo Padilla will discuss establishing a born-digital program as the first digital archivist at N-YHS, in a temporary, grant-funded position. Margo’s project responsibilities include developing a scaled-down approach to born-digital stewardship that can be easily implemented and grow in complexity as she trains permanent staff in full lifecycle management of born-digital materials. Siobhan Hagan will discuss scaling digital preservation best practices for the public across the US through the Memory Lab Network. She will detail the work conducted in “training the trainers” of public librarians across the country, providing access to increasingly virtual resources, and creating realistic solutions for personal digital archiving issues. Maggie Schreiner will discuss creating a low-cost and iterative born-digital records program at Brooklyn Historical Society: building a low-cost digital forensics workstation, creating a retrospective disk imaging project to capture legacy collections materials, and developing appraisal and access procedures for born-digital collections. Following these presentations, we will facilitate a group conversation about the most common themes.

column18:
Evaluation and assessment are crucial aspects of managing any search interface. After a recent significant redesign of the University of Tennessee’s Digital Collections website, a usability study to assess users’ experiences with the new features was carried out using Loop11. Participants were recruited from English 102 classes that were using the site to complete a primary source assignment. In pursuing real information needs, the participants searched for topics as diverse as moonshine and body image. Their experiences were captured using screen recordings, heat maps, and written feedback. This data was used to analyze the effectiveness of new website features, including a Learn More page, collection groups, and a way to limit searches by resource type. While many of the participants were able to use these features successfully, the study identified ways to improve the site for more efficient search and navigation. In particular, the data indicated that participants had difficulty narrowing the records to the most relevant results. In addition, the placement of the “Learn More” section was not intuitive for most users. An unintended outcome of the study was the increased integration of Digital Collections resources into standard library instruction sessions as a result of collaboration with liaisons while preparing the study and recruiting participants.

In order to encourage participation, the presenters will ask for audience feedback. Topics will include strategies for transitioning in-person studies to online protocols in the wake of COVID-19 and composing questions that elicit useful responses.

column16: This workshop will be a hands-on session, helping organizations to use the Levels of Preservation Assessment Tool. column17: This workshop will be a hands-on session, helping organizations to use the Levels of Preservation Assessment Tool. Participants will come away with a flexible interpretation of the Levels of Preservation, knowing how to use them to conduct digital preservation assessments, and how assessments may be used to help achieve goals.
column18:
Mapping the current efforts of your archives/digital holdings to the Levels of Preservation is often performed in an effort to holistically understand what is currently being done and to determine where future efforts could be placed to strengthen the technological aspects of a digital preservation program. The recently updated Levels of Preservation include an Assessment Tool to aid organizations in this activity.

This workshop will be a hands-on session, helping organizations to use the Levels of Preservation Assessment Tool, which can be used to assess an entire program or the specific needs of a collection or stream of digital content. While progressive, the Levels are not meant to suggest that all programs or content need to aim for Level 4 digital preservation.

Workshop leaders will guide participants in identifying what they want to assess and assist completing the assessment spreadsheet. Based on responses, leaders will help participants to analyze results and identify next steps, such as setting goals, allocating resources, and engaging stakeholders and partners. Participants will be asked to share their spreadsheets and the next steps and leaders will show the connections among participants that suggest opportunities for collaboration and strategy formation.

Participants will require a device and internet connection. Participants will come away with a flexible interpretation of the Levels of Preservation, knowing how to use them to conduct digital preservation assessments, and how assessments may be used to help achieve goals.

column16: What if you could teach more than a tool in a tool-based workshop? My poster will cover lecture elements and activities I use in open tools-based workshops to addresses additional learning goals such as digital literacy, accessibility, and socially and culturally conscious selection of colors and symbology.
column17: What if you could teach more than a tool in a tool-based workshop? My poster will cover lecture elements and activities I use in open tools-based workshops to addresses additional learning goals such as digital literacy, accessibility, and socially and culturally conscious selection of colors and symbology.
column18: In my position as a digital scholarship librarian I teach a lot of open tools-based workshops, people want to learn the tools, and I want to teach them, but I also have other learning goals in my open workshops. I want to focus on digital literacy, accessibility, and socially conscious and responsible selection of colors and symbology. My poster will cover some of the ways I’ve coupled the more straightforward learning objectives of “students will be able to create a basic chart in x-tool” with more complex learning objectives like “students will be able to explain factors to consider when selecting colors for a choropleth map” or “students will be able to identify graphs that do not follow the best practices of numeric representation.” The poster will feature example activities and lecture elements I use for these workshops.

column18: This poster will showcase projects and resources developed by the DLF Assessment Interest Group (AIG) Metadata Working Group (MWG). column7: Designing a Totally Online TEI Workshop that Is Project Based, Community Driven, and Fun
column9: Project-based learning, Workshop development, Program development, Digital pedagogy, Critical digital scholarship
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Two colleagues who have experience teaching online workshops in digital storytelling and podcasting to graduate students use their materials and pedagogy to develop a workshop in TEI and website building.
column17: Two colleagues who have experience teaching online workshops in digital storytelling and podcasting to graduate students use their materials and pedagogy to develop a workshop in TEI and website building.
column18:
Over the last few years, we and other colleagues in the Univ. of Washington Libraries have developed and offered online workshops for graduate students. We call these workshops “Storytelling Fellows,” and in them, graduate students learn to make digital stories or podcasts in which they tell the story of their research. In these workshops, aside from learning new skills and preparing stories for varied audiences, the students also benefit from making connections with other graduate students and developing their creations in a workshop environment. Storytelling Fellows is very work driven and community based.

In response to a growing interest in TEI, or text encoding, on our campuses, we took an online professional development workshop on how to encode and create digital editions of texts with the TEI standards. The workshop that we attended was good--and it met its own goals--but after having taken it, we couldn’t help but to wonder what a TEI workshop would look like in the Storytelling Fellows design that we’ve developed and come to trust. In particular, we wanted to design a workshop that would be much more project-based, learner driven, and conducive to people making connections, not just with teachers, but also with cohort members.

In a presentation, we would give some background about the Storytelling Fellows model before laying out how we used that framework to design a fun, interactive TEI workshop. We would also be able to relate how our design worked and what revisions we look to do upon further iteration.

column16: In 2019, the Metadata Assessment Working Group distributed a survey to various GLAMs about their metadata quality and evaluation practices. This presentation will address initial survey findings--including existing metadata standards, evaluation practices, and quality goals--and address next steps in establishing broadly-applicable benchmarks for metadata quality.
column17: In 2019, the Metadata Assessment Working Group distributed a survey to various GLAMs about their metadata quality and evaluation practices. This presentation will address initial survey findings--including existing metadata standards, evaluation practices, and quality goals--and address next steps in establishing broadly-applicable benchmarks for metadata quality.
column18: The Metadata Quality Benchmarks sub-group was formed within the DLF AIG Metadata Working Group to investigate how organizations are measuring their metadata quality. As a first step, the sub-group sought to gather more information about metadata quality measurement methods already used by the digital library community. In 2019, members of this sub-group distributed a survey asking respondents about the kinds of metadata infrastructure and schemas deployed at repositories in their organizations, how they evaluate metadata quality or set benchmarks, and areas where quality analysis could be improved. The sub-group collected responses from roughly 150 institutions, analyzed the data, and produced a white paper based on their initial findings. This presentation will discuss initial findings based on the responses to these questions, with topics including respondent profiles; repository information, including size as well as standards and tools employed; metadata elements commonly employed and evaluated in repositories; and respondents’ metadata assessment practices (both practical and aspirational). The presentation will conclude with a discussion of key findings--including common metadata element usage and measurement challenges across responses--as well as how this white paper could be used as a foundational step toward broadly-applicable benchmarks for metadata quality analysis.

column7: Introduction to Fedora and the Oxford Common File Layout
column9: Fedora, repository, preservation, open source
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Fedora is a flexible, extensible, open source repository platform for managing, preserving, and providing access to digital content. This workshop will provide an introduction to the latest version of Fedora with a focus on digital preservation functionality and workflows.
column17: Fedora is a flexible, extensible, open source repository platform for managing, preserving, and providing access to digital content. This workshop will provide an introduction to the latest version of Fedora with a focus on digital preservation functionality and workflows.
column18:
Fedora is a flexible, extensible, open source repository platform for managing, preserving, and providing access to digital content. Fedora is used in a wide variety of institutions including libraries, museums, archives, and government organizations. For the past several years the Fedora community has prioritized alignment with linked data best practices and modern web standards. We are now shifting our attention back to Fedora's digital preservation roots with a focus on durability and the Oxford Common File Layout (OCFL). This tutorial will provide an introduction to the latest version of Fedora with a focus on digital preservation functionality and workflows. Both new and existing Fedora users will be interested in learning about and experiencing Fedora features first-hand.

Attendees will be given access to individual online sandbox instances of Fedora. These sandboxes will be used to participate in hands-on exercises that will give attendees a chance to experience Fedora by following step-by-step instructions. The workshop will include three modules, each of which can be delivered in 1 hour or less:

Introduction and Feature Tour

This module will feature an introduction to Fedora generally, with a focus on the latest version, followed by an overview of the core and extended Fedora features. It will also include a primer on data modeling in Fedora.

Digital Preservation Workflows

Fedora has a number of features that support digital preservation, including fixity checking, versioning, and backup/restore. Fedora also provides a robust REST-API that can be used to integrate with other applications and services in a broader digital preservation workflow. This module will demonstrate both Fedora’s internal digital preservation features and API-driven integrations.

Fedora 6 and the Oxford Common File Layout

Fedora 6, the next major version of Fedora, will focus on digital preservation by aligning with the Oxford Common File Layout (OCFL). The OFCL is an application-independent approach to the storage of digital objects in a structured, transparent, and predictable manner. It is designed to promote long-term access and management of digital objects within digital repositories. This module will provide an overview of the Fedora 6 design, including a brief introduction to the OCFL and how it is being implemented, along with a summary of development progress to date and the anticipated timeline for the 6.0 release.

Workshop attendees will:

1. Become familiar with core and extended Fedora features and functionality

2. Learn how to create and manage content in Fedora in accordance with digital preservation best practices

3. Understand the benefits of the OCFL and how it will be implemented in Fedora 6

This workshop is intended to be an introduction to Fedora - no prior experience with the platform is required. Repository managers and librarians will get the most out of this tutorial, though developers new to Fedora would likely also be interested.

Participants will need laptops in order to access the online sandbox and participate in hands on exercises. The room should be equipped with powerstrips for the laptops, and everyone will need wireless internet access.

column16: Fedora 6 will focus on digital preservation by aligning with the Oxford Common File Layout (OCFL). This presentation will provide an overview of the application design, including a brief introduction to the OCFL, along with a summary of development progress to date and the timeline for the 6.0 release.
column17: Fedora 6 will focus on digital preservation by aligning with the Oxford Common File Layout (OCFL). This presentation will provide an overview of the application design, including a brief introduction to the OCFL, along with a summary of development progress to date and the timeline for the 6.0 release.
column18:
Fedora 6, the next major version of Fedora, will focus on digital preservation by aligning with the Oxford Common File Layout (OCFL). The OFCL is an application-independent approach to the storage of digital objects in a structured, transparent, and predictable manner. This provides many benefits, including: parsability, both by humans and machines, to ensure content can be understood in the absence of original software; robustness against errors, corruption, and migration between storage technologies; versioning, so repositories can make changes to objects allowing its history to persist; storage diversity, to ensure content can be stored on diverse storage infrastructures including cloud object stores; and completeness, so that a repository can be rebuilt from the files it stores. Many standards talk about what you should do to support digital preservation best practices, but not how. The OCFL provides the how.

Fedora 6 will replace the current ModeShape backend with a more scalable and performant implementation that persists data in accordance with the OCFL specification. Migration tooling will also be updated and enhanced to support migrations from all previous versions of Fedora to Fedora 6. This presentation will provide an overview of the Fedora 6 design, including a brief introduction to the OCFL and how it is being implemented, along with a summary of development progress to date and the anticipated timeline for the 6.0 release.

column16: Members of the DLF Project Managers Group will introduce participants to the Project Management Toolkit, project management theories, and focus on teaching technologies. Participants will learn how existing tools and documentation can help in postponing projects and templates can help you quickly initiate new projects on the fly.
column17: Members of the DLF Project Managers Group will introduce participants to the Project Management Toolkit, project management theories, and focus on teaching technologies. Participants will learn how existing tools and documentation can help in postponing projects and templates can help you quickly initiate new projects on the fly.
column18:
Members of the DLF Project Managers Group will teach participants about various project management theories and how they apply to managing digital projects in a library environment. Facilitators will discuss how they employ multiple strategies separately or in combination to build successful workflows. Facilitators will also discuss project charters, plans, and timelines, and how they’ve implemented these documents to guide work.

The workshop will demonstrate tools featured in the DLF Project Managers Toolkit. Facilitators will demonstrate how they utilize tools at their institutions, workflows built around the tools, elaborate on why they chose the tools they did, and challenges they experienced in implementing the tools. Project managers have encountered both technical and human challenges when implementing new tools and workflows.

Facilitators will lead a discussion on critical response in times of change, demonstrating how shifts in our work and project management and tools can assist in keeping projects on track. Participants will learn how existing tools and documentation can help in postponing projects and templates can help you quickly initiate new projects on the fly.

The workshop will conclude with a discussion on how to implement project management at their institution, addressing work culture, resource allocation, communication, staff experience, and other constraints.

Participants in this workshop will need to bring their own laptops and the room will need to be supplied with power strips for the attendees. The presenter will need to plug in their laptop to a project to demonstrate the tools on a screen.

column7: The Well of Nuance: Providing Access To The Complex, Queer Legacy Of Radclyffe Hall And Una Troubridge
column9: LGBTQIA+ collections, queer history, digital preservation, access, curation, digitization
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
2018
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Digitizing the papers of Radclyffe Hall and Una Troubridge presents a unique opportunity: a chance to provide the public digital access to the couple’s thorny, but important history. In our paper, we talk about the process and possibilities of digitizing their papers while not shying away from their fraught legacies.
column17: Digitizing the papers of Radclyffe Hall and Una Troubridge presents a unique opportunity: a chance to provide the public digital access to the couple’s thorny, but important history. In our paper, we talk about the process and possibilities of digitizing their papers while not shying away from their fraught legacies.
column18: Radclyffe Hall and Una Troubridge’s legacies are often limited to a discussion of The Well of Loneliness, Hall's landmark novel challenged for its LGBTQIA+ content during a censorship trial in England. However, their lives were a much messier meshing of identities and actions. It is impossible to analyze Radclyffe Hall and Una Troubridge without becoming entangled in their own controversial legacies. Both rattled literary circles and LGBTQIA+ individuals alike with undisguised representations of queer desire and existence in their work. Politically conservative, largely protected by wealth and race from the more extreme consequences for gender and sexual transgressions of the time, and friendly to both eugenics and right-wing movements, the two women offer contemporary queer historians a trove of content that is intricate and perplexing. This paper examines the process by which our Hidden Collections project Creating a Digital LGBTQ collection from the Radclyffe Hall and Una Vincenzo, Lady Troubridge papers at the Harry Ransom Center has challenged our own understanding of problematic LGBTQIA+ content as we digitize and present Hall and Troubridge’s papers to a public audience. Rather than demure from the discomfort of queer historical figures who left behind thorny legacies, we examine the implications of “leaning in” on those tricky intersections of interpersonal actions and political beliefs. We also examine the implications of bringing them to the forefront of our digital pedagogy while still respecting concerns of postmortem privacy and an understanding of the turbulent world in which both women lived.

It is impossible to analyze Radclyffe Hall and Una Troubridge without becoming entangled in their own controversial legacies. Both rattled literary circles and LGBTQIA+ individuals alike with undisguised representations of queer desire and existence in their work. Politically conservative, largely protected by wealth and race from the more extreme consequences for gender and sexual transgressions of the time, and friendly to both eugenics and right-wing movements, the two women offer contemporary queer historians a trove of content that is intricate and perplexing. This paper examines the process by which our Hidden Collections project Creating a Digital LGBTQ collection from the Radclyffe Hall and Una Vincenzo, Lady Troubridge papers at the Harry Ransom Center has challenged our own understanding of problematic LGBTQIA+ content as we digitize and present Hall and Troubridge’s papers to a public audience. Rather than demure from the discomfort of queer historical figures who left behind thorny legacies, we examine the implications of “leaning in” on those tricky intersections of interpersonal actions and political beliefs. We also examine the implications of bringing them to the forefront of our digital pedagogy while still respecting concerns of postmortem privacy and an understanding of the turbulent world in which both women lived.

column16: Faced with campus closures, members of the University of Houston Libraries developed a plan to engage student employees in creating closed captions for hundreds of archival moving images in the Libraries’ Audio/Video Repository. This presentation will describe the project and address unique challenges related to transcribing archival content.
column17: Faced with campus closures, members of the University of Houston Libraries developed a plan to engage student employees in creating closed captions for hundreds of archival moving images in the Libraries’ Audio/Video Repository. This presentation will describe the project and address unique challenges related to transcribing archival content.
column18:
As the realities of the coronavirus pandemic came into sharp focus, the University of Houston (UH) moved classes online. Shortly thereafter, campus facilities closed, including the UH Libraries, moving all services online. To keep our typically on-site student staff gainfully employed, along with adding to the strength of our online collections, members of the UH Libraries’ Special Collections department and Metadata and Digitization Services department's Digitization Unit developed a plan to engage student employees in the creation of closed captions for the hundreds of digitized archival films and videos in the Libraries’ Audio/Video Repository. Though well-described with complete descriptive metadata, these videos lacked closed captioning, making their audio content inaccessible to deaf and hard of hearing patrons.

Building on prior research into audiovisual transcription accuracy, the project team developed training materials, conducted a small pilot project, and began working with twenty-one students from six units across the UH Libraries to create high-quality captions within one week of the campus closure.

This presentation will describe the project design, the outcomes of the effort, and engage audience members with examples of the unique challenges related to transcribing archival content.

column7: From Failure to Fruition: Illuminating Digital Collaboration Challenges using the the Neon in Nevada Case Study
column9: Digital libraries, collaboration
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This snapshot, presented by two Nevada digital library stakeholders with years of experience building digital collections, focuses on the unlikely topic of failures. What, exactly, hasn’t worked? And what clues can we find to indicate a path forward?
column17: This snapshot, presented by two Nevada digital library stakeholders with years of experience building digital collections, focuses on the unlikely topic of failures. What, exactly, hasn’t worked? And what clues can we find to indicate a path forward?
column18:
In the Western United States, the neon signs found in Nevada cities and towns represent the “last frontier” mentality prevalent throughout the state during the 20th century’s growth and development. In more recent years, physical boundaries have faded and digital development of online library collections showcasing Nevada’s history have been widely cultivated - but not coordinated. Unlike the development of Nevada’s cities, which have flourished and sustained, collaborative digitization efforts are still on the distant horizon. This snapshot, presented by two Nevada digital library stakeholders with years of experience building digital collections, focuses on the unlikely topic of failures. What, exactly, hasn’t worked? And what clues can we find to indicate a path forward?

Using the case study, Neon in Nevada (initiated as two parallel digitization projects; now becoming an integrated joint digital initiative), the presenters will share 7 critical stress points encountered in their efforts to build collaborations. These “failures”, while discouraging in practice, are valuable lessons pointing to opportunities for renewed strength as the state builds capacity.

Nevada only has one city outside Las Vegas with a population of more than 100k, but the inhabitants (and their history) are of international research significance. Take a visual tour, featuring “Vegas Vic,” the “Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas” sign, and the “Reno Arch” as the authors guide attendees through the wreckage of their digital debacles ultimately arriving at a destination of reflection and digital renaissance.

column16: Academic digitization department models can often involve large amounts of staff with complicated workflows and typically reside within much larger units. Building on the strengths of units that already existed, digitization at the University of Nevada, Reno is using a team-centered approach to successfully manage digitization projects.
column17: Academic digitization department models can often involve large amounts of staff with complicated workflows and typically reside within much larger units. Building on the strengths of units that already existed, digitization at the University of Nevada, Reno is using a team-centered approach to successfully manage digitization projects.
column18: Academic digitization department models can often involve large amounts of staff to accomplish complicated workflows and typically reside within larger special collections or information technology units. Conversely, digitization at the University of Nevada, Reno began with a camera and a repository platform. Building on the strengths of units that already existed, a team-centered approach to managing digitization projects was born. This presentation will discuss how we developed a team from existing units for digitization, how the model successfully scales for the project at hand, key projects where the model’s agility was tested, and how we leverage tools like Confluence and Airtable to keep the workflow on track. Audience members will be polled on the current state and organization of their own digitization departments and challenged to consider if a team-centered approach can help them accomplish more with less.

column7: Images as Data through Distant Viewing
column9: images, data, computer vision, access, discovery
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: The hands-on workshop will explore methods for transforming digital images into data for search and discovery. Using the programming language R, the workshop will focus on how to extract features in images such as art, film, and photography. No programming experience is required or expected.
column17: The hands-on workshop will explore methods for transforming digital images into data for search and discovery. Using the programming language R, the workshop will focus on how to extract features in images such as art, film, and photography. No programming experience is required or expected.
column18:
Galleries, libraries, archives, and museums (GLAM) institutions continue to make exciting and unprecedented commitments to digitizing their holdings. Recent events such as the global pandemic have amplified the importance of access and discovery to such collections. As people including students, researchers, and life long learners work from their homes, access to digitized materials has become an even more a part of people’s daily lives. With funding from a Mellon-funded initiative called “Collections As Data” (https://collectionsasdata.github.io/part2whole/cohortone/), a team including the workshop leaders are developing methods for image analysis among archival collections. In the “Images as Data through Distant Viewing” hands-on workshop, we will explore methods for transforming digital images into data for search and discovery.

The workshop will begin with an introduction to the concept of distant viewing as a theoretical and methodological frame for applying computer vision. Following a brief introduction to the programming language R, the workshop will focus on how to extract features in images such as art, film, and photography. Feature extraction will include color, image similarity, and objects. Next, we will turn to how the metadata produced using these processes can inform new forms of collections discovery, such as user-driven recommender systems. Participants will also have the opportunity to apply and adjust the code using Rmarkdown notebooks, which can then be re-used for their own data in the future.

No programming experience is required or expected.

column5: Bibliotheca Alexandrina, Egypt
column7: BAMM Players/Viewers framework
column9: digital repository, mutimedia, viewers, collections, formats
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Bibliotheca Alexandrina Multi-Media (BAMM) repository is an Open Archival Information System (OAIS) compliant repository, which is responsible for storing, indexing, archiving, listing and publishing media objects. BAMM Players/Viewers framework is responsible for displaying the contents of the digital objects through the websites, mobile apps or desktop applications
column17: Bibliotheca Alexandrina Multi-Media (BAMM) repository is an Open Archival Information System (OAIS) compliant repository, which is responsible for storing, indexing, archiving, listing and publishing media objects. BAMM Players/Viewers framework is responsible for displaying the contents of the digital objects through the websites, mobile apps or desktop applications
column18:
The viewer engine supports several formats and designates a viewer for each format in BA; such as books, maps, audio files, video, audio books (Daisy), and photos. Each viewer is independent from the other and communicates with the storage and copyright solution in a separate manner.

The viewer framework consists of two parts the backend service and the viewer clients. the backend service serves the viewer clients serves the client with the information and content required to view the digital object. the backend service consists of a restful web service, a file streaming service and a copyright engine. The viewer clients are the frontend user interfaces that present the digital objects according to their formats to the user. There are three types of clients: web clients, Mobile apps, and desktop clients. All the clients work on the same backend services regardless of the client type.

The frame work also contains a viewer/ player engine that is responsible for determining the viewer responsible for viewing the digital object format. The engine receives the object identifier, queries the data repository for its media type and decides the proper viewer client for the specified digital object. The client then communicate with the backend services to verify the access to the digital object according to the copyright status of the object. Finally the viewer client uses the backend streaming services to display the digital object to the user.

column7: The Digital Sixties: Bridging Generations and Scholarship in Online Archives
column9: Civil Rights, political activism, digital archives, 1960s, Midwest
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Social movements are increasingly documented in digital collections, providing researchers new insights into the tensions, conflicts and transformations of those turbulent times. This session will explore three “Digital Sixties” archiving projects housed at Midwestern universities and consider their value and relevance for current racial justice efforts, particularly Black Lives Matter.
column17: Social movements are increasingly documented in digital collections, providing researchers new insights into the tensions, conflicts and transformations of those turbulent times. This session will explore three “Digital Sixties” archiving projects housed at Midwestern universities and consider their value and relevance for current racial justice efforts, particularly Black Lives Matter.
column18:
Scholarly and popular interest in the 1960s, particularly the political movements and social transformations of that period, has prompted research libraries to expand accessibility to relevant primary sources. These efforts are particularly timely in light of the shift online for research and instruction during a pandemic.

The resulting “Digital Sixties” archives have expanded the geographic and intellectual terrain of 1960s-era activism and, in the process, complicated both public and academic understandings of that pivotal period, enriching scholarship in many disciplines, including history, political science, ethnic studies, gender and sexuality studies, sociology, rhetoric, and law.

This session will explore three “Digital Sixties” projects housed at Midwest universities, each documenting different dimensions of 1960s social movements and cultural transformation and consider their value to both scholarly and popular audiences.

The March on Milwaukee digital collection (https://uwm.edu/marchonmilwaukee/), housed at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, documents Milwaukee’s civil rights history, particularly the 1960s protests, boycotts, and legislative battles against segregation and discriminatory practices.

The Roz Payne Sixties Archive Project (https://rozsixties.unl.edu), hosted by the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, is named for the noted activist, photographer, and filmmaker, who died in 2019. The site features her collection of underground newspapers, leaflets, flyers, posters, photographs, and newsreel films.

Uptight and Laid-Back: Iowa City in the 1960s (https://dsps.lib.uiowa.edu/sixties/), hosted by the University of Iowa, recounts the experiences of a Midwestern university town through the use of photographs, alternative newspapers, flyers, recorded sound, and motion picture film, including a documentary recounting a 1967 protest.

Speakers are:

· Abigail Nye, MLS, reference and instruction archivist, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee

· Patrick Jones, PhD, associate professor of history, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

· David McCartney, MA and MLS, university archivist, University of Iowa

column35: In all three cases, community scholars and activists have drawn on our collections to frame ongoing community protests. The pandemic also has prompted building community through social media using these online resources.
column50: Our session will elaborate on how the documentation of 1960s-era activism has enhanced greater awareness and understanding of that critical period, and in doing so, has again made the period relevant to communities today.

column9: digital humanities project, black studies, project implementation, afro-indigenous traditions
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
Project design and implementation

column16: University of Oregon’s Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies and Indigenous, Ethic, and Race Studies departments, and UO Libraries partnered to create virtual space for Caribbean women healers keeping their Afro-Indigenous, Indigenous and Afro-descendant healing traditions alive. This poster shares technologies and techniques that communicate stories, plant collections, and research methodologies.
column17: University of Oregon’s Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies and Indigenous, Ethic, and Race Studies departments, and UO Libraries partnered to create virtual space for Caribbean women healers keeping their Afro-Indigenous, Indigenous and Afro-descendant healing traditions alive. This poster shares technologies and techniques that communicate stories, plant collections, and research methodologies.
column18:
Caribbean Women Healers: Decolonizing Knowledge Within Afro-Indigenous Traditions is a collaborative digital research project developed by the University of Oregon the Department of Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies, the Department of Indigenous, Ethic, and Race Studies, and UO Libraries Digital Scholarship Center. Since 2016, UO faculty researchers have conducted ethnographic research with women healers in the Caribbean and the quickly-expanding Caribbean diaspora in the U.S. Pacific Northwest. Their research contributes to existing scholarship on Caribbean healers by highlighting how women exercise their knowledge and roles as healers, teachers, and community leaders within Afro-Indigenous Caribbean healing traditions to effect change well beyond the traditional centers of those communities.

Beginning in the summer of 2019, this digital humanities partnership has created a virtual space for Caribbean communities living in diaspora-away to maintain intergenerational transmission of traditional healing methods and knowledge production. And a space for interviewees to share their healing traditions with the desire to use media as a way to reproduce knowledge across generations as well as across communities.

Beginning in the summer of 2019, this digital humanities project is creating a virtual space for practitioners to maintain intergenerational transmission of traditional healing methods by sharing their experiences and knowledge with displaced communities. This poster highlights the processes and technologies used--including data sharing and privacy, project management, data remediation, ExifTool, Audacity, Wordpress and Divi, StoryMap JS, and Panopto--and how these methods could be used for broader digital scholarship instruction and research.
column19:

column5: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, United States of America
column7: “Do I Not Destroy My Enemies When I Make Them My Friends?”: Building A Team For Sustainable Digital Preservation
column9: Team, Repository, Libsafe, Lessons Learned
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Creating the right team for long-term digital preservation can be hard….really hard. Over several years, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum assembled a “team of rivals” made up of internal staff experts and our preservation software vendor to implement a sustainable, well-support digital repository.
column17: Creating the right team for long-term digital preservation can be hard….really hard. Over several years, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum assembled a “team of rivals” made up of internal staff experts and our preservation software vendor to implement a sustainable, well-support digital repository.
column18:
Creating the right team for long-term digital preservation can be hard….really hard. In addition to the cliche adversarial relationship between IT and cultural heritage professionals, there are often conflicts with senior leadership,(Why do we need this?) finance, (Wait, how much money!?) and curatorial staff (Where’s my stuff?) each with their own goals and values.

Over several years, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum assembled a “team of rivals” made up of staff experts in IT, digital asset management and preservation, and our preservation software vendor, LibNova, to distribute the knowledge and skill needed to implement a digital repository, housing almost a petabyte of data, consisting of oral testimonies, film, digitized archival collections and rare books, born-digital memoirs, and recorded sound.

This presentation will chart the journey the Museum took to build a stakeholder coalition within the Institution, which ultimately led to a more sustainable, well supported digital repository built on the mutual understanding and respect of colleagues.

column7: Ethical Analytics and Book Usage Data: Exploring Data Trusts, Visualizations, and Policy Controls
column9: metrics, eBook, usage, data, Open Access
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: More than ever, institutions and funders are interested in how people reference, access, and use OA publications. Recognizing the vital need for ethical analytics, two global OA usage data efforts invite DLF participants to explore the exciting, concerning, and potentially transformative outcomes that could arise from such data access.
column17: More than ever, institutions and funders are interested in how people reference, access, and use OA publications. Recognizing the vital need for ethical analytics, two global OA usage data efforts invite DLF participants to explore the exciting, concerning, and potentially transformative outcomes that could arise from such data access.
column18:
Understanding how people reference, find, and use published digital knowledge is key to data-driven decision-making about collections management, investment, and marketing. Equally, usage data can expose the information that isn’t being accessed or cited, raising questions of how such analytics could influence the production, publication, and funding of scholarly and creative works.

Two efforts are exploring these questions within the narrow scope of monograph usage data. This pre-recorded panel will begin by raising awareness of data trusts as a community-governed mechanism through which data providers are coming together to improve usage data aggregation and benchmarking across platforms and providers. Then, Cameron Neylon, PI for the Curtin Open Knowledge Initiative (COKI) (http://openknowledge.community/) and Kevin Hawkins, PI for the Open Access eBook Usage (OAeBU) Data Trust (https://educopia.org/data_trust/), will describe their projects and how data privacy and ethics issues have surfaced with the increased visibility and use of OA publication usage information. Then, Christina Drummond, Data Trust Program Officer with the Educopia Institute, will present a collection of ethical frameworks, processes and tools that could guide data trusts and digital libraries as they look to leverage usage analytics.

During the community watch parties, the presenters hope to facilitate a discussion of how publication usage data (not just for books) could be ethically used, or potentially abused by digital library stakeholders. Participants will also be asked to consider what principles and protections should govern such data trusts that serve the scholarly community.

The Curtin Open Knowledge Initiative (COKI) is a leading hub for analysis and evaluation of open knowledge in higher education, leveraging more than 12 trillion data elements to inform the analysis of open knowledge practices and impact.

The Open Access eBook Usage (OAeBU) Data Trust pilot, supported by The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation through December 2021, is developing infrastructure, policy, and governance solutions to support the aggregation, benchmarking, and reporting of monograph usage data from across library and commercial publishers and their publishing platforms and services.
column19:

Then, Christina Drummond, Data Trust Program Officer with the Educopia Institute, will present a collection of ethical frameworks, processes and tools that could guide data trusts and digital libraries as they look to leverage usage analytics.
During the community watch parties, the presenters hope to facilitate a discussion of how publication usage data (not just for books) could be ethically used, or potentially abused by digital library stakeholders. Participants will also be asked to consider what principles and protections should govern such data trusts that serve the scholarly community.
The Curtin Open Knowledge Initiative (COKI) is a leading hub for analysis and evaluation of open knowledge in higher education, leveraging more than 12 trillion data elements to inform the analysis of open knowledge practices and impact.
The Open Access eBook Usage (OAeBU) Data Trust pilot, supported by The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation through December 2021, is developing infrastructure, policy, and governance solutions to support the aggregation, benchmarking, and reporting of monograph usage data from across library and commercial publishers and their publishing platforms and services.
column50: This proposal has been revised to focus on the ethical issues raised by usage data metrics and analytics, with an added emphasis on the tools and processes available to help staff review analytics for ethical use and impact, to increase awareness of such resources among digital library staff.

column16: What does it mean to make A/V content accessible? Using the Institute of Afro-American Studies' radio program "Soul of Reason" as an example, I'll tell NYU’s digital library’s A/V captioning story. It involved conferring with peers; making technical decisions; handling COVID-related challenges and opportunities; and staying the course.
column17: What does it mean to make A/V content accessible? Using the Institute of Afro-American Studies' radio program "Soul of Reason" as an example, I'll tell NYU’s digital library’s A/V captioning story. It involved conferring with peers; making technical decisions; handling COVID-related challenges and opportunities; and staying the course.
column18: Once upon a time, an accessibility mandate came to NYU. It included captions and transcripts for A/V materials. Although the requirement was simple on the surface, the need for captions was multifaceted, with a lot more questions than answers in terms of best practices. When NYU’s Digital Library Technology Services (DLTS) department embarked on the mission to provide captions, we ended up on an adventure that took us through such disparate topics as compliance, style guides, accuracy, display issues, and the age-old question of what users actually want or need and what it means to make content accessible. We faced challenges such as sheer hours of material, costs, budgets, and the true price-tag of publishing online in-house. In this presentation, using the Institute of Afro-American Affairs’ radio program “Soul of Reason” as an example, I’ll talk about how we conferred with some of our peers; how we made technical decisions; how COVID-19 interfered with and facilitated our work; and where we are now on our journey.

column5: Algiers University, Algeria
column7: Open Access In Algerian Libraries: Bad Policies Or Plain Ignorance?
column9: open access, libraries, academic institutions, Algeria

I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
International topics
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Open access in the Global Souths is a way to fight an endemic lack of information. Algeria as a L.M.I.C. has put a number of programs in this optic. There seem to be deficiencies associated to these programs and this presentation will try to pinpoint the reasons
column17: Open access in the Global Souths is a way to fight an endemic lack of information. Algeria as a L.M.I.C. has put a number of programs in this optic. There seem to be deficiencies associated to these programs and this presentation will try to pinpoint the reasons
column18: Open access has seen an exponential development that has made it an unavoidable subject in the LIS landscape. This weltanschauung has revolutionized the way we access and spread information. Open access is more of a boon for the Global Souths because the Global North has already a fairly acceptable access to information .The Global Souths suffer from various problems (economical, political, societal, etc …) that hinder their progress toward a more developed and sustainable situation .Algeria, a Low Middle Income Country, has embarked on an ambitious program geared mainly at academic institutions allowing them to freely access information through different schemes. The Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research and the General Directorate of Scientific Technological Research put a number of projects that would allow mainly graduate students access to databases and subscription to core titles. Although ambitious and having the back up of a centralized and public system, the different projects seem not to have achieved their intended goals as Algerian academic institutions are not well ranked internationally and have not taken advantage of this “diamond open access”. The question we are going to investigate is what is the reason of these less than acceptable results: is it a bad policy or is open access not understood nor implemented rightly? We will try to answer these questions by looking at the different programs and their intended and actual results and try to see where the problem lies.

Consortia, collaboration, and partnerships;
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: In 2018, a team of librarians, digital humanists, and faculty formed to explore publishing trends in North American comics through catalog data. After normalizing the dataset, the team published it and created data visualizations. This presentation shares their findings and starts a conversation about project management and collaborating across units.
column17: In 2018, a team of librarians, digital humanists, and faculty formed to explore publishing trends in North American comics through catalog data. After normalizing the dataset, the team published it and created data visualizations. This presentation shares their findings and starts a conversation about project management and collaborating across units.
column18:
This presentation reports on an ongoing collaborative project that examines library catalog data to explore geographies of publishing and library collecting policies in North American comics. Continuing an institutional history of creating collections as data, a group of Michigan State University librarians, digital humanists, and faculty formed a working group in 2018 to compile and analyze comic book data. From MSUL’s Comics Collection, which holds more than 300,000 print comic book titles, we extracted a subset of about 50,000 records of comics published in North America. We normalized and standardized publication dates, publisher names and their locations to map the evolution of comics publishing over time. We reconciled each comic’s publisher and author data against Wikidata. Future work to add the many smaller comics publishers and creators present in MSUL’s collection to Wikidata will help increase their visibility and expand our understanding of comics as a medium.

As we worked on the project, we left room for our final outcomes to serve all members of the team based on our needs, interests, and skills. We made the dataset openly available through a GitLab repository, where we will share data visualizations that present the collection in new ways so that scholars and members of the public can explore and interrogate this unique collection.

We see this presentation as an opportunity to share the results of our work, from the perspectives of comic book history, library and information science, and digital humanities project development and to start a conversation about developing and adapting a project across disciplinary boundaries.

column2: Digital Preservation 2020: Get Active with DP
column7: The Right Stuff (Over Time): Collaborative Approaches to Selection for Digital Preservation
column9: Digital preservation, digital archives, appraisal, collaboration, implementation
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Selection for digital preservation should be a collaborative endeavor between preservation practitioners and collection stewards. This panel will discuss some existing frameworks for this ideal collaboration, along with several institutional perspectives on the implementation and experience of appraisal and selection for several types of collections and content digital types.
column17: Selection for digital preservation should be a collaborative endeavor between preservation practitioners and collection stewards. This panel will discuss some existing frameworks for this ideal collaboration, along with several institutional perspectives on the implementation and experience of appraisal and selection for several types of collections and content digital types.
column18:
While some storage may be cheap, preservation storage and related digital preservation activities are not. In the face of ever-increasing digital collections, more than ever, collection stewards need to actively engage in the selection of digital content for long-term preservation. Digital preservation practitioners can work collaboratively with collection stewards to make these decisions by providing a framework and criteria for appraising digital content.

Rooted in traditional collection development criteria for both general and special collections, Tallman and Work have previously published Guidelines and Criteria to Select for Digital Preservation (https://osf.io/8y6dc/). This session will build on that work and incorporate community feedback, additional perspectives, and additional types of digital content, such as web and social media archives, email, research data, and post-custodial stewardship.

While criteria are the first step, presenters will discuss strategies for implementation and share about their experiences partnering with collection stewards for sustainable selection for digital preservation. Audience participation, feedback, and questions are encouraged.

column2: Digital Preservation 2020: Get Active with DP
column5: The National Archives (United Kingdom), United Kingdom
column7: DiAGRAM - The Digital Archiving Graphical Risk Assessment Model: Rethinking Practice By Quantifying Digital Preservation Risks
column9: resource allocation, risk modelling
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: DiAGRAM is a decision support system, developed by The National Archives, the Applied Statistics & Risk Unit, and partner archives. It is based on a probabilistic graphical model that captures the complex interdependencies of risk events and allows archivists to quantitatively evaluate their impact and compare potential risk management strategies.
column17: DiAGRAM is a decision support system, developed by The National Archives, the Applied Statistics & Risk Unit, and partner archives. It is based on a probabilistic graphical model that captures the complex interdependencies of risk events and allows archivists to quantitatively evaluate their impact and compare potential risk management strategies.
column18:
The last 20 years have seen a wide range of digital preservation good practice established, from the OAIS reference model to the NDSA Levels of Preservation. This practice is aimed at mitigating the risks faced by the digital materials being preserved.

However, there has been little quantitative work done to allow institutions to make informed decisions about which risks actually pose the biggest threat to their collections. With limited resources we have to choose which mitigations to apply. Would an institution’s overall digital preservation risk be lowered most by concentrating on staff training, or by aiming to reach NDSA Level 2 in Storage, or would improving Integrity first be more effective?

DiAGRAM’s foundation is a Bayesian Network - a statistical model that estimates the probability of outcomes by considering conditional events and changes over time (e.g. the lifespan of our archival storage depends on a changing mix of storage media types). Bayesian networks have been used as a foundation for decision support tools in a variety of contexts.

We will illustrate how our online tool, DiAGRAM, can:

Improve users' understanding of the complex digital archiving risk landscape and of the interplay between risk factors.

Empower archivists to compare and prioritize very different types of threats to the digital archive: from software obsolescence to natural disaster.

Aid in quantifying the impact of risk events and risk management strategies on archival outcomes to support decision making, communication with stakeholders and developing business cases for targeted action.

Supported by the National Lottery Heritage Fund.

column18: Artificial Intelligence is reshaping many areas of our lives, and Library and Information Sciences are not outside this influence. LIBNOVA, as a major world player in digital preservation, with its technology being used in many national and university libraries and archives around the world, began exploring this area three years ago. After their initial promising findings, they received a European Union grant to research further. They will share with the audience some insights about Artificial Intelligence, Neural Networks and Deep Learning technologies, and update on their research results and some notes on the disruptive changes that will be triggered as this emerging technology is applied to Libraries, Archives and knowledge management fields.

column16: We will cover a journey from a PDF kept within an unstructured collection to a final structured, full-text searchable asset. Also, we will show how an A.I.-based automated classification assistant can help a record keeper or archivist pre-classify document content types.
column17: We will cover a journey from a PDF kept within an unstructured collection to a final structured, full-text searchable asset. Also, we will show how an A.I.-based automated classification assistant can help a record keeper or archivist pre-classify document content types.
column18:
There is a sense that some may not be accessing the digital preservation stage for lack of time, resources or even knowledge, but digital preservation can be an accessible undertaking for smaller entities with limited budgets, by adopting some of the latest cutting edge technology available. It can simplify the process of structuring content and transforming it into a valuable asset.

In this live workshop we would like to cover a journey from a PDF kept within an unstructured collection to a final structured, full-text searchable asset. We will see in real time and live how, by using an A.I.-based automated classification assistant, we can help a record keeper or archivist pre-classify document content types, such as contracts or invoices, extract valuable metadata, such as names or dates from the documents, and then allow the archivist or recordkeeper push it out to a permit-based access layer making the content full-text searchable.

This live presentation should be of interest to most people involved with digital records of any sort and is aimed at individuals of all technical levels. However, some previous basic knowledge of digital preservation would be helpful.

column5: LIBNOVA, Spain
column7: Dealing With Research Data in Digital Preservation
column9: research data management and preservation
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16:
One of the more overlooked areas of digital preservation is the scientific world.

Vast amounts are spent on research and generating research data, but very few entities turn to digital preservation to protect those assets.
column17:
One of the more overlooked areas of digital preservation is the scientific world.

Vast amounts are spent on research and generating research data, but very few entities turn to digital preservation to protect those assets.
column18:
One of the more overlooked areas of digital preservation is the scientific world.

It is surprising that with the vast amounts spent every year on generating research data that very few entities turn to digital preservation to protect those assets. It is known that libraries, archives and other cultural entities have a mandate to protect and preserve our cultural heritage for the long term, but what about research institutions and the massive amount of data they generate ?

We see strategies usually based on understanding what data should be collected and how this data can be leveraged. Not much attention, however, is dedicated to generating a plan to manage, secure and preserve the huge data volumes extracted from the costly research.
