column7: Breaking Boundaries with CollectionBuilder: Iterative Digital Collection Software Development with Partners
column9: digital collections, partnerships, software development, static web
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation will describe the collaborative development process of CollectionBuilder, a static web application that uses Jekyll, APIs, and structured metadata to improve the browsing, design, and visualization capacities for digital collections. Community-driven collaboration with partner institutions has broadened the capacity of CollectionBuilder as a skin interface and teaching tool.
column17: This presentation will describe the collaborative development process of CollectionBuilder, a static web application that uses Jekyll, APIs, and structured metadata to improve the browsing, design, and visualization capacities for digital collections. Community-driven collaboration with partner institutions has broadened the capacity of CollectionBuilder as a skin interface and teaching tool.
column18:
CollectionBuilder utilizes static web technology, APIs, and structured metadata to create a digital exhibit interface that invites users to engage with content through auto-generated visualizations such as timelines, maps, and subject clouds. Until last year, CollectionBuilder’s use was limited to its creators, developer-librarians at the University of Idaho. However, funding from a 2019 IMLS grant expanded opportunities to teach and implement the platform more broadly through partnerships across the country, and feedback from partners has led to alterations that make CollectionBuilder more broadly adaptable.

Librarians at the State Library of North Carolina initiated the development of a “multi-collection” option for CollectionBuilder’s CONTENTdm skin, which allows creators to use objects from multiple digital collections when curating a digital exhibit. At the New College of Florida (NCF), the CollectionBuilder skin was modified to interact with SobekCM Repository’s API and build explorative interfaces on top of existing collections. Additionally, the tool’s use in pedagogical settings at NCF has demonstrated CollectionBuilder’s value in teaching data management and web development concepts alongside digital collection practices.

This presentation looks at both sides of the collaboration process, bringing together representatives of the cross-institutional partnership. We will describe the experience of working on a tool that was built by someone else, and detail the benefits and deliverables that arose from this iterative style of development. Specifically, we will highlight the ways in which modifications inspired by this collaboration are worked into the CollectionBuilder template so that they anticipate and aid customizations by future users.

column5: Smithsonian Institution, United States of America
column7: Gloss vs. Glass: The Impact of Paper Types on Digitization Equipment
column9: Digitization, Digitization Equipment, Copyright, Future Planning
column10:
Technologies, infrastructure, and/or vendor relations
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: When books began harming digitization equipment, the culprit appeared to be clay-coated papers creating micro-abrasions on anti-reflective coated glass platens. Digitization of glossier papers is increasing due to the US public domain moving wall, in-copyright permission agreements, and Controlled Digital Lending (CDL) practices, and imaging labs will need to adapt.
column17: When books began harming digitization equipment, the culprit appeared to be clay-coated papers creating micro-abrasions on anti-reflective coated glass platens. Digitization of glossier papers is increasing due to the US public domain moving wall, in-copyright permission agreements, and Controlled Digital Lending (CDL) practices, and imaging labs will need to adapt.
column18:
Digitization is an inherently physical process. Mass digitization of bound volumes relies on book cradles with glass platens that touch each page. Ensuring that digitization equipment does not harm collections is a central concern of Conservators and Imaging Specialists alike. An increase in their glass platen replacement rate led Smithsonian Libraries’ Preservation and Digitization staff to investigate an unanticipated reversal – why were the books suddenly harming the digitization equipment?

The build-up of ‘micro-abrasions’ – a slow sanding of the glass – was impacting digitization quality, throughput, queues, and budget lines. Staff theorized that clay-coated paper could be to blame. The micro-abrasions were possibly connected to a grant project that had increased the number of modern periodicals entering the queue.

Suspecting the glass platens’ glare-reducing anti-reflective coating, the Libraries’ had custom glass platens made without the coating for testing. These platens have proven effective, but required adjustments and restrictions to standard workflows and queues.

These clay-coated papers are being digitized at a higher rate across the field due to increased permissions agreements for in-copyright materials, the now moving public domain wall in the US, and Controlled Digital Lending practices.

Using glass with anti-reflective coatings will require increased monitoring for micro-abrasions, grouping of like-sized materials to extend platen life, and alterations in selection and prioritization practices. Using non-coated glass will require lighting and camera adjustments to avoid reflections, which have implications for imaging. Digitization teams may need to compensate in the future by equipping their labs with multiple glass types.

We are looking for other institutions who are encountering the same issues, and want to collaborate on future work in this area.

column12: Labor, staffing, and the future of work
column16: This session focuses on successful reorganization to meet changing campus needs, align with a new strategic plan, and lead the evolution of a new digital scholarship support model. We describe the ways in which we brought along administrative and technical folks unused to working collaboratively on messy faculty projects.
column17: This session focuses on successful reorganization to meet changing campus needs, align with a new strategic plan, and lead the evolution of a new digital scholarship support model. We describe the ways in which we brought along administrative and technical folks unused to working collaboratively on messy faculty projects.
column18:
The Digital Humanities Initiative (DHi) began as a pioneering model for how to support digital humanities research at a small liberal arts college. DHi drew heavily on staff support from the Metadata & Digital Strategies (MaDS) and Network Services within Hamilton College Library and Information Technology Services (LITS). It focused on archive based research by faculty and students. After ten years of success, opportunities for change presented themselves through staff turnover, a new senior cabinet at Hamilton College, and a new strategic plan focused on developing digital skills in faculty and students. LITS seized this opportunity to evolve its support for digital scholarship into a model that would provide broader assistance for a wider range of projects and also connect departments more directly within LITS.

Discovering this new model of support involved challenging those in LITS to think about connections across the roles of staff members within the organization. This required getting buy-in from key members of LITS, reorganizing staff on a small scale and disrupting some established ways of thinking and doing things, including bringing together academic and administrative experts to work collaboratively on risky faculty projects. After evaluating potential collaborative support models, Academic Digital Initiatives was born. It includes key members of the Business Intelligence & Web Services, Infrastructure, MaDS and Research & Instructional Design units who serve as project managers, shepherding faculty and administrative projects through a process that includes agile frameworks, project sprints, and documentation of lessons learned. Leading these changes required clear communication for stakeholders across multiple levels.

column16: Records digitized by the Congregational Library & Archives (CLA) have been utilized by many different user groups in unexpected ways. The CLA identified deficiencies with how digitized materials were displayed and metadata captured, limiting their use. In response, the CLA developed requirements for a new system that will improve access.
column17: Records digitized by the Congregational Library & Archives (CLA) have been utilized by many different user groups in unexpected ways. The CLA identified deficiencies with how digitized materials were displayed and metadata captured, limiting their use. In response, the CLA developed requirements for a new system that will improve access.
column18:
The New England’s Hidden Histories (NEHH) project, administered by the

Congregational Library & Archives, in partnership with the Phillips Library, UCC

Connecticut Conference, and New England Historic Genealogical Society, has

successfully digitized over 20,000 pages of Early-American Congregational records.

These records have been utilized by many different groups, such as by genealogists

for family history services and society membership applications, and by academic

researches to extrapolate historic climate data and track the impact of infectious

diseases. Some of these uses were expected, but many were completely

unexpected, and drastically changed how the CLA thought about these records and

how they might be used.

However, limitations regarding the display and acquisition of metadata related to

these digitized materials has hampered both access and visibility for researchers

and general users, as well as efforts to showcase under-represented narratives.

Consequently, the CLA has initiated an overhaul of how digital collections are

accessed, searched, and displayed. In collaboration with researchers and AVP (a

DAMS consultant), the CLA developed functional requirements for how these digital

records will be handled and displayed.

We therefore propose a paper presentation which will examine how our digitized

records have been used, how we believe they can be better used, and the

methodologies we developed to create a vision of our digital future. We believe that

our example - a small library with a small staff thinking large about its digital future
- will benefit and provide a roadmap for similarly sized institutions.

column16: The UWM Libraries, and our Research Computing partners, are building data services using a collections-as-data audio-mining project as a focal point. We will discuss the progress of a library task force initiated to explore the project's implications for library operations, and broader implications for data literacy, ethics and justice campus-wide.
column17: The UWM Libraries, and our Research Computing partners, are building data services using a collections-as-data audio-mining project as a focal point. We will discuss the progress of a library task force initiated to explore the project's implications for library operations, and broader implications for data literacy, ethics and justice campus-wide.
column18: Libraries have long been aware of the potential for new forms of research as archival collections are digitized. Scholars are eager to mine these resources using new computational methodologies made possible by treating them as "collections as data". Alongside these developments, libraries have been developing services to support digital scholarship and data-driven research. Our presentation will focus on how the UWM Libraries are building cross-department and cross-campus data services using a collections-as-data project as a focal point. We will discuss the project itself, an audio-mining project focused on our LGBTQ+ collections, and the progress of a library task force initiated to explore the project's implications for overall library operations, including education across divisions on data literacy and data ethics and justice; and how we have engaged our campus Research Computing staff to develop workflows, infrastructure, and educational opportunities to benefit a wide range of researchers new to data-driven research. We will seek input from the audience on parallel efforts to build services for data-driven research, especially efforts that engage humanities and social science faculty and students, and that wrestle with the ethical implications of artificial intelligence and machine learning, big data, and their application to the archival record of historically underrepresented communities. We see these discussions as opportunities to ensure broad-based campus discussions that build data skills and support with a strong critical and community-engaged component.

column16: Taking a cue from Stephen Wolfram’s post “What is a computational essay?”, we describe and reflect on an experiment we embarked on during a semester-long fellows program in which we generated and explored the ways Computational Essays might be used as a critical, playful mode of encountering code.
column17: Taking a cue from Stephen Wolfram’s post “What is a computational essay?”, we describe and reflect on an experiment we embarked on during a semester-long fellows program in which we generated and explored the ways Computational Essays might be used as a critical, playful mode of encountering code.
column18:
How to introduce both STEM and humanities majors to disparate aspects of web development alongside critical theory of technology? How to do so substantively and coherently while acknowledging real logistical constraints? We propose to describe and reflect on an experiment we embarked on last fall during a semester-long undergraduate fellows program, placing our experience in the broader context of digital pedagogy. Taking a cue from “What is a computational essay?”, Stephen Wolfram’s 2017 blog post, we generated our own Computational Essays, interrogating and defining just what that might mean along the way.

The resulting projects make use of Observable, a new JavaScript notebook platform, and are inspired as much by code studies as by the code notebooks prevalent in science pedagogy, not to mention Miriam Posner’s often-cited digital humanities capstone assignment. The Computational Essay here serves as a central, flexible tool imbricating code and prose, a single artifact in which HTML text, executable scripts, and their outputs appear without apparent hierarchy privileging one over the other.

Students had the semester to consider a topic of interest and find a corresponding dataset, and through trial and error, engage both visual and discursive narratives “in” the data as well as observations “about” the data. Shuttling between issues of representation, standards, infrastructure, code, and rhetoric, students had the opportunity to wrestle with major themes of the fellowship. Our presentation will outline our approach and explore the ways the Computational Essay might be used as a critical, playful mode of encountering code.

column10:

column16: Libraries reach only a small percentage of current and potential users through traditional channels such as their websites. This interactive program will feature panelists who will discuss opportunities to increase the visibility of libraries on popular websites and expand engagement with people beyond established physical and virtual library locations.
column17: Libraries reach only a small percentage of current and potential users through traditional channels such as their websites. This interactive program will feature panelists who will discuss opportunities to increase the visibility of libraries on popular websites and expand engagement with people beyond established physical and virtual library locations.
column18:
Libraries struggle to remain relevant and to demonstrate value in an environment of proliferating information sources. Studies have shown that libraries reach only a small percentage of current and potential users through traditional channels such as library websites, because most people do not begin their research at a library. Instead, people usually turn to search engines and familiar non-library websites first when looking for information.

In the midst of rapidly changing user needs, libraries also compete with increasingly personal experiences on popular websites that often enable more personalized online experiences than those offered by libraries.

In this program, panelists will discuss new ways librarians can connect with people through the non-library websites they regularly consult for information. They will demonstrate the success that partnerships with some of the largest consumer and education sites have delivered in increasing the visibility of libraries and will show how libraries can benefit from these programs.

Panelists representing a cross-section of library types and sizes and commercial organizations will also discuss opportunities for partnerships that increase the visibility of unique special collections in digital, electronic, and physical formats.

During this interactive program, participants will share their own approaches for gaining the attention of hard-to-reach information seekers and will have the opportunity to brainstorm additional tactics that will reinforce their value in the eyes of their users. Participants will leave the program with recommendations for new tactics to try when they return to their libraries.

column16: We will present a collaborative open access music score publishing project undertaken by the UCLA Library and Kaleidoscope, a local chamber orchestra. Includes discussion of the institutional repository publishing platform, promotion of the project via online exhibit, and future scholarly access to the score collection via MusicXML.
column17: We will present a collaborative open access music score publishing project undertaken by the UCLA Library and Kaleidoscope, a local chamber orchestra. Includes discussion of the institutional repository publishing platform, promotion of the project via online exhibit, and future scholarly access to the score collection via MusicXML.
column18:
This 15-minute presentation will detail a collaborative music score open access publishing project undertaken by the UCLA Library and the Kaleidoscope Chamber Orchestra. In February 2020, Kaleidoscope and the Library jointly put out a Call for Scores that attracted over 7,700 submissions from composers, 6,000 of which will be published in UCLA’s open access institutional repository. This initiative, established in conjunction with a university-wide open access initiative, will result in the first significant open access collection of contemporary music scores. Beyond establishing the collection, the ultimate goals of this project are to raise awareness of open access at UCLA and beyond, and to create a resource valuable to both practitioners and scholars of music.

Following the call’s close in April, a team of UCLA Library employees began the work of preparing score submission data for ingest into eScolarship, the University of California’s institutional repository. The ingest process is coordinated with repository managers at a system-wide level. Once a representative sample of the score collection is published in eScholarship, there are plans to begin promoting the collection via an online exhibition platform such as Omeka. This will allow us to curate a selection of the scores, provide context for the project, and integrate multimedia file types. Finally, we hope to go beyond providing access to the individual scores by asking contributors for derived MusicXML files, which we hope will both enhance preservation at the file level and establish a contemporary music dataset of value to scholars and composers.

column16: The University of Houston Libraries has completed an estimate of its digital preservation program's electricity usage and carbon footprint. Building on this research, I investigate whether changes in digital preservation processes and policy, such as a reduced schedule of hands-on fixity checking, can positively impact our energy expenditure.
column17: The University of Houston Libraries has completed an estimate of its digital preservation program's electricity usage and carbon footprint. Building on this research, I investigate whether changes in digital preservation processes and policy, such as a reduced schedule of hands-on fixity checking, can positively impact our energy expenditure.
column18:
The University of Houston Libraries has completed an estimate of its digital preservation program's electricity usage and carbon footprint, revealing that storage, processing, and networking equipment for local systems emit approximately 56.3 metric tons of greenhouse gases annually. Working with the Libraries' systems administrator and the UH campus sustainability coordinator, I plan to further refine this research to gather exact figures of electricity consumption. I would like to investigate whether changes in digital preservation processes and policy, such as a reduced schedule of hands-on fixity checking, can positively impact our energy expenditure (and whether such a strategy can still provide a high level of integrity and durability for our digital assets over time).

Note: This case study is somewhat contingent on being able to return to work on campus over the summer. If the in-person research is delayed, I plan to investigate a broader range of ideas by which digital preservation practitioners can reduce their power draw and carbon footprint but will not be able to conduct any hands-on tests.

column16: This presentation focuses on workshops offered at UTM Library where we took critical pedagogy approaches to gathering internet-based data with open-source tools. The aim of these workshops is to encourage a modular approach to research design, one that enables researchers to iteratively tweak their protocols to produce replicable methods.
column17: This presentation focuses on workshops offered at UTM Library where we took critical pedagogy approaches to gathering internet-based data with open-source tools. The aim of these workshops is to encourage a modular approach to research design, one that enables researchers to iteratively tweak their protocols to produce replicable methods.
column18: The contingent nature of internet-based technologies requires modular approaches to digital pedagogy. Digital scholarship is the iterative adoption of new forms of methods, collaboration, and publication in digital research. These forms can include scraping, mining, and visualizing data using tools designed to meet ethical and legal requirements. This presentation focuses on workshops offered at UTM Library where we took critical pedagogy approaches to gathering internet-based data with open-source command line tools—that is, we designed workshops where, typically, inaccessible data could be retrieved for social critique in knowledge mobilization activities. Inspired by Programming Historian, Minimal Computing, and the Digital Methods Initiative, we developed extensive documentation for attendees to install and use digital tools in research, and to critically evaluate the tool’s validity in their research design. Attendees gathered and analyzed data with scrapers, such as twarc for Twitter data, using research questions as a starting point to develop digital methods. Through a series of exercises attendees evaluate the relevance of the tool to their own research, while considering the challenges of gathering research data hidden behind the end-user license agreements of online platforms. The aim of these workshops is to encourage a modular approach to research design, one that enables researchers to iteratively tweak their protocols to produce replicable methods. While the research data itself may not be replicable due to the technical and legal limitations of doing internet-based research, the immediate relevance of presenting data on contemporary issues can highlight social critiques of platform governance and public infrastructure.

column16: Seals were colorful items of jewelry with protective qualities and one of the primary mediums of communication in the ancient world. Carved with designs and inscriptions, seals create raised impressions when pressed into a soft surface like clay. This presentation overviews the YBC’s digitization of seals and their ancient impressions.
column17: Seals were colorful items of jewelry with protective qualities and one of the primary mediums of communication in the ancient world. Carved with designs and inscriptions, seals create raised impressions when pressed into a soft surface like clay. This presentation overviews the YBC’s digitization of seals and their ancient impressions.
column18: Digitizing the Yale Babylonian Collection is a two-year project to image and document ca. 35,000 seals and cuneiform artifacts housed in the Yale Babylonian Collection (YBC) using flatbed scanning, High Dynamic Range Imaging (HDR) and Reflectance Transformation Imagery (RTI). The YBC represents one of the most substantial cuneiform collections in the world, and holds documents of unparalleled historical significance, shedding light on the earliest phases of human history. The aim of the project is to advance the research and education objectives associated with this collection by documenting and disseminating the artifacts through Yale’s Discovery portal, through the YBC website and through the international cuneiform aggregate dissemination portal, Cuneiform Digital Library Initiative (CDLI). The project will make the cuneiform texts – a type of artifact that has been particularly targeted for looting and illicit trade – globally accessible to scholars as well as to the public.
column19: Digitizing the Yale Babylonian Collection is a two-year project to image and document ca. 35,000 seals and cuneiform artifacts housed in the Yale Babylonian Collection (YBC) using flatbed scanning, High Dynamic Range Imaging (HDR) and Reflectance Transformation Imagery (RTI). The YBC represents one of the most substantial cuneiform collections in the world, and holds documents of unparalleled historical significance, shedding light on the earliest phases of human history. The aim of the project is to advance the research and education objectives associated with this collection by documenting and disseminating the artifacts through Yale’s Discovery portal, through the YBC website and through the international cuneiform aggregate dissemination portal, Cuneiform Digital Library Initiative (CDLI). The project will make the cuneiform texts – a type of artifact that has been particularly targeted for looting and illicit trade – globally accessible to scholars as well as to the public.
column50: Seals are one type of artifact with cuneiform writing and impressions of seals regularly occur on cuneiform tablets. The presentation will define ancient seals for a nonspecialist audience, outline the goals of the project, and share the challenges and opportunities created by the global pandemic. One key take away is that the earlier photography of cuneiform tablets (2018-2019) allowed us to study seal impressions while away from the collection.

column5: Virginia Tech, United States of America
column7: Preserving DH Projects: Creating an Environment for Emulation
column9: Digital Humanities, Preservation, Emulation, Documentation
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Digital Humanities (DH) projects are complex with multiple moving components in need of preservation. Early preservation planning for each component is a strategy for long-term access. This presentation will break down various components of a DH project, preservation approaches for those components, packaging methods for future recreation/emulation.
column17: Digital Humanities (DH) projects are complex with multiple moving components in need of preservation. Early preservation planning for each component is a strategy for long-term access. This presentation will break down various components of a DH project, preservation approaches for those components, packaging methods for future recreation/emulation.
column18:
Digital Humanities (DH) projects have multiple moving components that each require their own preservation strategy. Projects begin with some form of data (text, images, csv files), that evolves into planning documentation (grant proposals, wireframes, productions plans), which leads to the project site (HTML/CSS). It can be overwhelming planning to preserve an entire interactive website as one entity. This presentation outlines our approach to breaking down a DH project into individual components, applying a preservation method appropriate to its content type, and then packaging each component together for long-term storage.

This approach relies on emulation over migration to address format obsolescence. Since each component is a unique format, and all of the components are packaged together, file format migration would be performed manually. This is not a scalable method. By planning for emulation and reconstruction of a website, we can develop a streamlined workflow for appraising, packaging, and preserving content. For this approach to be effective, documentation for each component is critical. Documentation is a driving force behind successful emulation to capture not only the technical components and decisions, but to establish a clear understanding of the goal and purpose of the project.

This presentation is the result of a test case performed on a current DH project to export and appraise the content and supporting infrastructure, apply individual preservation methods, and reconstruct the project from those components. This aligns with the conference topic Project management as we are providing a potential workflow for producing preservation-friendly DH projects.
column19:
Digital Humanities (DH) projects have multiple moving components that each require their own preservation strategy. Projects begin with some form of data (text, images, csv files), that evolves into planning documentation (grant proposals, wireframes, productions plans), which leads to the project site (HTML/CSS). It can be overwhelming planning to preserve an entire interactive website as one entity. This presentation outlines our approach to breaking down a DH project into individual components, applying a preservation method appropriate to its content type, and then packaging each component together for long-term storage.
This approach relies on emulation over migration to address format obsolescence. Since each component is a unique format, and all of the components are packaged together, file format migration would be performed manually. This is not a scalable method. By planning for emulation and reconstruction of a website, we can develop a streamlined workflow for appraising, packaging, and preserving content. For this approach to be effective, documentation for each component is critical. Documentation is a driving force behind successful emulation to capture not only the technical components and decisions, but to establish a clear understanding of the goal and purpose of the project.
This presentation is the result of a test case performed on a current DH project to export and appraise the content and supporting infrastructure, apply individual preservation methods, and reconstruct the project from those components. This aligns with the conference topic Project management as we are providing a potential workflow for producing preservation-friendly DH projects.
column50: Thank you for your consideration

column9: survey, capacity, sustainability, collaboration

column16: How are Canadians making active plays towards digital preservation? We will present the results of the CARL Digital Preservation Working Group survey of Canadian memory institutions, and the subsequent development of three focus areas to address key gaps in their ability to safely pass digital collections into the future.
column17: How are Canadians making active plays towards digital preservation? We will present the results of the CARL Digital Preservation Working Group survey of Canadian memory institutions, and the subsequent development of three focus areas to address key gaps in their ability to safely pass digital collections into the future.
column18: To date, digital preservation work in Canada has occurred in a largely isolated and uncoordinated manner. While there have been some successes at the level of traditional regional networks such as library consortia, the ability for Canadian memory institutions to safely pass their digital collections into the future is unevenly distributed, and shared digital preservation networks and infrastructure are being used at a fraction of their capacity. In 2016, the Canadian Association of Research Libraries established the Digital Preservation Working Group (DPWG) to advance the collaborative preservation of Canada’s digital documentary heritage. One of the DPWG’s first initiatives was a survey addressing the extent of digital preservation capacity and needs across memory institutions in Canada. Our presentation will showcase the results of the survey, which demonstrated that while respondents all have digital collections of value, the resources to pursue active digital preservation work have not yet coalesced. Nevertheless, the results showed pockets of expertise and ability at different institutions across the country, and broadly, a commitment in principle towards digital stewardship. Following a discussion of the survey results, we will present how three key needs emerging from the survey results have structured focus areas for creating an active, collaborative community of practice in Canada via policy development, national shared infrastructures, and staffing. Our presentation will take stock of the current state of digital preservation work in Canada and lay a roadmap for how Canadians can develop our strengths and become better team players towards the goal of sustainable digital stewardship.

column16: This unconference session will discuss how to sustain digital humanities projects in ways that anticipate eventual long-term preservation in a digital archive. Participants will share examples, thoughts, concerns, and suggestions on how to create pipelines from sustainability to preservation that take into account our myriad of institutional contexts.
column17: This unconference session will discuss how to sustain digital humanities projects in ways that anticipate eventual long-term preservation in a digital archive. Participants will share examples, thoughts, concerns, and suggestions on how to create pipelines from sustainability to preservation that take into account our myriad of institutional contexts.
column18:
Over the past 25 years, the Roy Rosenzweig Center for History and New Media (RRCHNM) has built hundreds of digital humanities projects and websites, along with three major software programs—Zotero, Omeka, and Tropy—that enable or form the backbone of thousands more. While many of these DH projects have been decommissioned or handed off to other organizations over the years, RRCHNM still remains responsible for just over 200 of them. For the past 2 years, we have been working with GMU Libraries to archive obsolete and low-traffic DH projects in a DSpace repository, as well as to establish internal sustainability workflows to ensure continued public access to completed projects that are still actively used by their various communities and audiences. But these actions taken to ensure the medium-term sustainability of live DH projects—especially the various technical solutions we adopt—have the potential to impact, or preclude entirely, the future preservation and archiving of key aspects of our projects.

This unconference session will be dedicated to discussing how to sustain live digital humanities projects in ways that anticipate eventual long-term preservation in a digital archive. It will also discuss how to establish pipelines for the sustainability and future preservation of DH projects, particularly in a university/college context. Despite increasing interest in sustainability over the past several years, sustaining live DH projects (equating, approximately, to the NDSA Level 4 Content Functional Area) is understudied compared to other aspects of digital preservation. Furthermore, it is often done by severely under resourced individuals and project teams or those without the necessary LIS background to understand the impact of their actions on the long-term future of their projects. Through exploring this problem space with participants in a variety of different contexts, positions, and institutions, we will brainstorm and share examples, thoughts, concerns, and suggestions on sustaining DH projects with long-term preservation in mind, that assumes there may not be a one-size-fits-all solution and takes into account the myriad of institutional contexts in which we work.

column16: As part of newly created roles and a wider digital scholarship initiative, University of Wyoming’s Digital Scholarship Librarian and Data Management Librarian created a visualization which centralized the disparate data and digital services on campus. This poster discusses their experience mapping digital services so others can recreate a similar resource.
column17: As part of newly created roles and a wider digital scholarship initiative, University of Wyoming’s Digital Scholarship Librarian and Data Management Librarian created a visualization which centralized the disparate data and digital services on campus. This poster discusses their experience mapping digital services so others can recreate a similar resource.
column18: The University of Wyoming Libraries recently began expanding its digital scholarship and data services. The Libraries hired a Digital Scholarship Librarian and a Data Management Librarian whose new positions would support a Digital Scholarship Center within the University Libraries. Regular programming is expected to begin in the fall semester of 2020. In the process of planning potential services, the Digital Scholarship and Data Management Librarians realized that many different groups on campus offered a variety of services related to digital scholarship, but there was no centralized or easy way of knowing who offered what services. Each service was siloed in its own unit. In an effort to break down knowledge silos and help the university community explore all avenues of support for their digital projects, the Digital Scholarship and Data Management Librarians created a Digital Scholarship Map. The map functions as a connector between users and the varied digital service units on campus. It also has the potential to create partnerships between these different groups and the Digital Scholarship Center. This poster will discuss the methodology used to gather information about the different groups, services, and spaces across campus and how the map was created. The experience of the Digital Scholarship and Data Management Librarians can be used by others who hope to recreate a similar resource at their own institutions.

column16: The Collaborative Archive & Data Research Environment (CADRE) is creating a digital infrastructure that will open access to big data research assets and services. With a tiered-pricing model that shares costs across institutions, the cloud-based CADRE platform will offer a long-awaited solution for all academic libraries and researchers.
column17: The Collaborative Archive & Data Research Environment (CADRE) is creating a digital infrastructure that will open access to big data research assets and services. With a tiered-pricing model that shares costs across institutions, the cloud-based CADRE platform will offer a long-awaited solution for all academic libraries and researchers.
column18:
The Collaborative Archive & Data Research Environment (CADRE) is solving big problems in big data research.

Indiana University Libraries, in partnership with the Indiana University Network Science Institute and the Big Ten Academic Alliance (BTAA), formed a cross-industry coalition to build an affordable, sustainable solution that one library could not create alone. With support from eight other BTAA library institutions, the Web of Science Group, and Microsoft Research, the CADRE project was formed.

CADRE is advancing data-driven research with an open-source, cloud-based platform that opens access to big bibliometric datasets. CADRE establishes an infrastructure to store, secure, and maintain these datasets and provides a user-friendly, data-mining interface.

Libraries can take part in this shared infrastructure through CADRE’s hosted model that ensures the platform is accessible to every type of institution.

CADRE promotes standardized, high-quality data with Digital Object Identifiers, advancing reproducibility in research and improving data provenance.

Currently seeded with Microsoft Academic Graph, Web of Science, and USPTO data, CADRE also provides tools to empower individual researchers to work with big data, such as its GUI query-builder and a coding environment for creating custom data-analysis and visualization tools. Users come together in the “Marketplace” to share workflows, queries, data-analysis tools, research results, and more—and to utilize what others share.

We invite DLF attendees to test CADRE’s free tier of service and share feedback on what they believe will make CADRE—a platform built on collaborative principles—the solution to all academic libraries’ and researchers’ big data research needs.

Services and programs

column16: Recently, Trinity College and Wesleyan University launched student-centric digital scholarship initiatives, in which students are empowered to develop their own learning goals and conceptualize and execute their own digital humanities projects. For our proposed panel, we will share what we have learned to revise our programs.
column17: Recently, Trinity College and Wesleyan University launched student-centric digital scholarship initiatives, in which students are empowered to develop their own learning goals and conceptualize and execute their own digital humanities projects. For our proposed panel, we will share what we have learned to revise our programs.
column18:
In 2018, Wesleyan University Libraries and Information Technology Services launched the Digital Scholarship Fellows Program, an internship offering a small cohort the unique opportunity to work with experts from the Digital Lab and Academic Technology to develop the skills they will need for research in the digital humanities. Under the direction of the digital projects librarian and the director of academic technology, the students are introduced to digital humanities tools and methods, often in collaboration with other digital scholarship support centers on campus, including the GIS lab and Archives and Special Collections. Our purpose is to build a student-centric digital humanities community of practice in which students are given the resources to develop and execute their own projects. The inaugural cohort is composed of Rama Co, a junior studying College of Letters and Philosophy; Sofia Sperber, a sophomore taking up Sociology and Environmental Studies; and Philippe Bungabong, a sophomore pursuing Economics and Data Analysis. Albeit in different fields, the inaugural Digital Scholarship Fellows will collaborate in producing two DH projects that combine the disciplines of history, art, politics, and international economics.

In 2019-20, Trinity College has launched three initiatives aimed at supporting students’ digital scholarship. The first is a student advisory board, which has become a driver for programming and marketing directly to students. The first two events, on digital productivity strategies and on privacy & student data, have been among the best-attended student-oriented events that did not involve laser tag or free Chipotle. They have also offered useful correctives to contemporary marketing platitudes about the relevance of various social media platforms. A second initiative involves a student fellowship program, which provides students with money and access to specialized staff so that they can complete digital humanities projects. A special instance of this, scheduled to pilot in the spring semester, is a Thesis Sprint, which will offer students sustained support over three days in order to move a project significantly closer to completion. The third initiative is student-targeted digital scholarship studio hours, which are two hours a week in our digital scholarship space, giving students the opportunity to get drop-in help on a wide variety of research questions, and to collaborate with others on similar projects.

This panel discusses parallel student-centered digital humanities initiatives at Trinity College and Wesleyan University. Focused on partnering with students rather than simply training them, these initiatives offer new opportunities for students, IT departments, and libraries to advance digital scholarship at the undergraduate level.

column16: Many institutions are faced with migrating content from one repository to another. In this workshop, participants will learn strategies to identify suitable repositories and effectively plan and execute a migration. Participants will actively explore phases of migration as they relate to their organization and come away with next steps.
column17: Many institutions are faced with migrating content from one repository to another. In this workshop, participants will learn strategies to identify suitable repositories and effectively plan and execute a migration. Participants will actively explore phases of migration as they relate to their organization and come away with next steps.
column18:
As digital repositories evolve, so do the needs of institutions who employ them. Increasingly, institutions are faced with the daunting task of migrating content from one repository to another. But what strategies exist to help institutions identify suitable repositories and effectively and efficiently plan and execute a migration? This workshop aims to explore the issues and strategies of repository (re)selection and migration.

Participants will learn about the different phases of a migration process including: system evaluation and selection, migration planning, and implementation strategies and tools. Through hands-on activities and facilitated discussion, participants will actively explore these phases as they relate to their own organizational context and come away with next steps for planning for system selection and/or a migration at their own institution.

After attending the tutorial, participants will:
- Understand the major components of a repository migration
- Understand criteria for repository selection
- Apply migration strategies and methods to their organizational context
- Gain familiarity with some tools used to migrate repository content

The workshop will be led by members of the Bridge2Hyku (B2H) Project, an Institute for Museum and Library Services (IMLS) National Leadership/Project Grant (LG-70-17-0217-17) initiative led by UH Libraries and partner institutions to support the creation of the B2H Toolkit- a suite of resources for migration planning and implementation. The toolkit includes both software that is specific to a migration from CONTENTdm to Hyku, as well as general migration guidance applicable to many types of system migration.

column5: University of Michigan, United States of America
column7: Doing All the Work to Get Their Work in the Repository, But Faster
column9: Jupyter Notebooks, automation, workflows, mediated deposit, digital repository
column10:
Project management, including workflows and processes
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column12: Project management, including workflows and processes
column16: Mediated deposit is key for increasing content in digital repositories. Yet it’s time-consuming, making automation advantageous. We’ve developed two Jupyter Notebooks to streamline steps in our mediated deposit service. This presentation will cover how we built the tool, demonstrate outputs, and discuss benefits so that attendees may consider using it.
column17: Mediated deposit is key for increasing content in digital repositories. Yet it’s time-consuming, making automation advantageous. We’ve developed two Jupyter Notebooks to streamline steps in our mediated deposit service. This presentation will cover how we built the tool, demonstrate outputs, and discuss benefits so that attendees may consider using it.
column18: Mediated deposit services have arisen to increase content in digital repositories and complete the steps of gathering citation metadata, finding files, researching rights, and batch uploading to a repository. Literature says that staffing for these tasks is necessary but not necessarily sustainable. It’s well known that the work is time-consuming, and faculty prefer that someone do the work on their behalf. Automation for parts of this workflow helps lessen the burden on staff, but there is little literature on using Python and Jupyter Notebooks, a web-based coding app, to expedite this work. We recently launched the new Enhanced Deposit Service to help faculty get as much as possible of their research, teaching, and creative outputs into our repository. Simultaneously, we’ve developed two Jupyter Notebooks to (1) check for content already in the repository, and (2) both get citation information, including the DOI and publisher which may or may not be in the citation, from Crossref and pull rights information from SHERPA/RoMEO. The Jupyter Notebooks streamlined tasks that would otherwise take much longer by consolidating many steps into working in output spreadsheets, rather than having to access multiple online systems separately to get information for each publication. This tool allows you to see/control which Python code block is running for those with less coding experience. Our presentation will describe how we created the Jupyter Notebooks, demonstrate their outputs, and discuss the benefits of using the tool for this process so that others can consider using it in their workflows.

column16: In Fall 2019, NARA released a draft of its Digital Preservation Framework for public comment. We’ll discuss the past year’s work and what’s next as our holdings continue to grow. We hope by sharing about the framework and soliciting feedback, it will serve as a digital preservation community resource.
column17: In Fall 2019, NARA released a draft of its Digital Preservation Framework for public comment. We’ll discuss the past year’s work and what’s next as our holdings continue to grow. We hope by sharing about the framework and soliciting feedback, it will serve as a digital preservation community resource.
column18: In Fall 2019, the US National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) released a draft of its Digital Preservation Framework for public comment. The framework identifies hundreds of file formats in NARA's holdings and includes risk assessments, prioritization for action, and preservation action plans for these formats. Feasibility drove decision-making when crafting the framework; for example, limiting the scope to formats for which there are a minimum of 1,000 files in NARA’s holdings. We will discuss the past year’s work on the framework, including feedback received and how that has shaped this project (in particular the decision to release the preservation actions plans as linked data), and how we are moving forward despite known challenges with currently available tools and formats for preservation and access for some content types. Work on the Digital Preservation Framework will be ongoing and iterative; we will also cover what’s next as our holdings continue to grow. In addition to serving as internal guidance for NARA, the framework intends to be transparent documentation of digital preservation thinking and activity at NARA. We hope by continuing to share about it and solicit feedback, the framework will serve as a community resource for measuring and mitigating risk to a variety of formats.

Work on the Digital Preservation Framework will be ongoing and iterative; we will also cover what’s next as our holdings continue to grow. In addition to serving as internal guidance for NARA, the framework intends to be transparent documentation of digital preservation thinking and activity at NARA. We hope by continuing to share about it and solicit feedback, the framework will serve as a community resource for measuring and mitigating risk to a variety of formats.
column23: US National Archives and Records Administration

column5: NYARC/ The Frick Collection and Art Reference Library, United States of America
column7: Saving Space: Deploying Lossless Jpeg-2000 as a Preservation Format
column9: Storage, Jpeg-2000, sustainability
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: The Frick Art Reference Library is systematically digitizing 1.2 million photographic images for access and preservation and is using lossless Jpeg-2000 as an archival format to keep their storage needs feasible. This introduces several challenges including new software proficiencies, compatibility issues, and swamping the preservation system.
column17: The Frick Art Reference Library is systematically digitizing 1.2 million photographic images for access and preservation and is using lossless Jpeg-2000 as an archival format to keep their storage needs feasible. This introduces several challenges including new software proficiencies, compatibility issues, and swamping the preservation system.
column18:
The Frick Art Reference Library Photoarchive is a study collection of 1.2 million reproductions of works of art accompanied by extensive historical documentation including bibliographic references, attribution changes, provenance, and condition. Currently the collection is being digitized for access and preservation, yielding well over 3,000,000 files. Given the scope of the project, storage needs guide many decisions. The Digital Lab explored several approaches to reducing individual file size, ultimately settling on using lossless Jpeg-2000 as an archival format.

While this decision dramatically reduces our storage requirements, the impact on workflows and needed expertise is significant. In-house digitization processes utilize CaptureOne and Photoshop, which do not fully support jp2. As such, conversion adds another distinct process and layer of quality assurance which depends on a suite of tools that must be installed, learned, and maintained. One key challenge is the inability of jp2 conversion tools to preserve technical metadata, which must be copied separately. Moreover, early size-reduction strategies often present compatibility issues that must be resolved. One last concern is the ability of our preservation system to accommodate jp2, which required changes to normalization rules to prevent overwhelming the system.

When deciding to digitize over a million images, it must be assumed that some compromises must be made. Despite the additional technical debt and ongoing knowledge that must be maintained, the decision to deploy Jpeg-2000 as an archival format makes the project feasible in a way that might otherwise not be possible.

I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
2017
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Two separately funded CLIR projects make the records of early American religious congregations available for use worldwide. This session explores the projects' development, from identification and scanning of manuscripts to promoting and providing true accessibility for them. Today’s pandemic underscores the need to make primary source material available online.
column17: Two separately funded CLIR projects make the records of early American religious congregations available for use worldwide. This session explores the projects' development, from identification and scanning of manuscripts to promoting and providing true accessibility for them. Today’s pandemic underscores the need to make primary source material available online.
column18:
Records of local early American religious congregations hold vital clues to our past, casting much light on our ancestors who built those communities, their interactions with each other as well as the broader societies in which they lived. Often these records are still held by local congregations, and difficult to access. But even larger, established repositories hold important collections that often remain "hidden." These two separate projects: Digitizing the Records of Philadelphia’s Historic Congregations: Providing Documentation for the Political, Social and Cultural Developments in Philadelphia (2017) and New England's Hidden Histories: Providing Public Access to the Manuscripts of New England's First Churches, Incubators of American Democracy (2015) bring many of these historically priceless and often inaccessible records to public view. Although work continues, the two projects have scanned a large body of documents now freely available online for scholars and the general public. The projects take two somewhat different approaches to their online presentations: the Philadelphia records can be seen through a unified website: www.philadelphiacongregations.org and through the American Theological Library Association’s (ATLA) digital library and the University of Pennsylvania’s Special Collections online portal: OPenn. New England's Hidden Histories serves as a single centralized online location for images created in cooperation with local churches and by a significant number of established historical repositories: http://www.congregationallibrary.org/nehh/main.

We are making these documents accessible by publishing them freely online on our respective websites, transcribing them where possible. Digitization alone often does not render these documents accessible, as many either cannot read them or can read them only with difficulty.

We are engaging communities to work with these records - scholars, genealogists, students, members of congregations, and interested members of the public, and building online communities for these groups. We are bringing together scholars in symposia, placing post – event recordings online, organizing talks with local groups to promote use of the records and sharing experiences with history and archival communities, as well as the general public.

These projects give volunteers of the various congregations a forum in which they can share ideas and problems, and bring the resources of larger institutions to smaller archival repositories, enabling them to learn from each other in online forums and onsite lectures.

Next steps include applying for supplemental grants to scan additional records; expanding our offerings by bringing attention to previously scanned records; increasing scholarly and community outreach and broadening our online presence with lesson plans.

This panel brings together the principal investigators of each project: Carol Smith, Christ Church Preservation Trust, James Cooper, Professor of History at Oklahoma State University and Project Director of the Congregational Library and Archives; as well as Arthur Sudler, Director of the Historical Society of the African Episcopal Church of St. Thomas; Nancy Taylor, Executive Director, Presbyterian Historical Society; and Walter Rice, IT consultant on the Philadelphia Congregations project who designed the online platform for the website, pulled in the scans done by the Athenaeum of Philadelphia, worked with ATLA and OPenn to fit these records within their digital libraries.

column50:
This panel integrates work from two separate CLIR projects, the Congregational records of 2015 and the Philadelphia Congregations' records project of 2017.  
Today's  pandemic underscores the need for  online accessibility in general and also  the need to develop provisions for remote presentations at symposia like this one; for these reasons we wish to have a "virtual" option. A second "wave" is entirely plausible--no one can state with any certainly what the landscape will look like in November, or months before, when flights will need to be booked, and such.

column7: Feminist Revisions: An Emergent Model for Digital Scholarship in Libraries
column9: feminism, library, service, collaboration, equity
column10:
Services and programs
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Our poster outlines the feminist, anti-racist, and equity-centered approach that we used in the formation of a digital scholarship services pilot at the University of Michigan Library. We focus on three core programs developed within the DS Hub: service model design, digital pedagogy support, and workshops and research project partnerships.
column17: Our poster outlines the feminist, anti-racist, and equity-centered approach that we used in the formation of a digital scholarship services pilot at the University of Michigan Library. We focus on three core programs developed within the DS Hub: service model design, digital pedagogy support, and workshops and research project partnerships.
column18:
As an alternative to existing models for digital humanities support in academia, our poster outlines the feminist, anti-racist, and equity-centered approach that we are using in the formation of digital scholarship services at the University of Michigan Library. The poster will foreground the theoretical and practice-based approaches that inform this work, drawn from community organizing, anti-oppressive facilitation methods, and critical pedagogy.

The digital scholarship hub is a small part of a larger distributed network across the library and the U-M campus. Our poster will map this landscape and detail the work that laid the groundwork of our approach.

To ground the poster in concrete examples, we focus on the three core programs developed within the DS Hub: (1) service model design, (2) digital pedagogy support, and (3) workshops and research project partnerships. Through these examples, we will demonstrate how our principles manifest in practice around the values of consent, trust, and care.

Even as we acknowledge our privilege as a unit of a large, resource-rich institution, we are working to ensure that our principles inform our priorities: valuing people, communities, and social justice over grant funding or prestige. Drawing from the work of The Consentful Tech Project and adrienne maree brown’s Emergent Strategy, we outline an approach for building programs that are community-centric, accountable, and caring of the individuals and communities involved. Ultimately, this poster will show how access and equity is integral to the creation of a digital scholarship team built on critical feminist values and practice.

column16: This interactive unconference session will be facilitated by co-convenors of the DLF Privacy and Ethics in Technology (PET) Working Group. Attendees will work through a sequence of exercises to arrive at new insights and actions for addressing issues related to privacy and ethics in library technologies.
column17: This interactive unconference session will be facilitated by co-convenors of the DLF Privacy and Ethics in Technology (PET) Working Group. Attendees will work through a sequence of exercises to arrive at new insights and actions for addressing issues related to privacy and ethics in library technologies.
column18:
This session from the DLF Privacy and Ethics in Technology (PET - formerly Technologies of Surveillance) Working Group is planned to accommodate either in-person or remote participatory approaches (for example, using Zoom + Miro) and will be led by the working group’s co-conveners. Attendees will be invited to share their backgrounds, interests, and topical concerns before dividing into break-out rooms or small groups. Each group will address key questions based in relevant interest areas, organized around the PET sub-groups: Ethical Service Design; Strategic Engagement with Administration; Data Governance; Cross-Organizational Collaborations; EdTech; Technologies of Surveillance; and, Instruction, Outreach, and Advocacy. Attendees will be able to unconference in small groups around these or other emergent topics related to privacy and ethics in technology.

Session participants will then work together through facilitated exercises, with the option of applying PET toolkits and resources or imagining what new resources may be useful within the context of their home institutions. Discussion among participants will involve how the role, purpose, and involvement opportunities of the DLF Privacy and Ethics in Technology working group can continue to assist library workers in communicating library values, practices, and policies to library and non-library stakeholders, avoid unnecessary user data collection and analysis, and the development of practical getting-started plans for ethical engagement with library technologies. In the final part of the session the full group will reconvene to discuss new insights and brainstorm appropriate post-conference next steps.

column7: Web Forms Through Time: a Case Study of the HIDVL Metadata Collection Process

column16: Active for 10+ years, HIDVL is a digital video library showcasing performance and politics in the Americas. This talk presents the evolution of the project’s metadata collection process from a custom web form to an Airtable, posing questions about obsolescence and suggesting methods for countering institutional knowledge loss.
column17: Active for 10+ years, HIDVL is a digital video library showcasing performance and politics in the Americas. This talk presents the evolution of the project’s metadata collection process from a custom web form to an Airtable, posing questions about obsolescence and suggesting methods for countering institutional knowledge loss.
column18:
NYU’s Hemispheric Institute Digital Video Library (HIDVL) is a digital resource on performance and politics in the Americas. The project, active for over 10 years, provides access to streaming video and metadata and is co-created by information professionals from the NYU Division of Libraries and content curators from the Hemispheric Institute.

This lightning talk presents the evolution of the project’s web-based metadata form as a case study. Interviews with current and former project managers, content specialists, and developers, combined with a study of available documentation, constitute qualitative information from which to trace the HIDVL metadata collection process from its earliest days as a custom web form to its current iteration as an Airtable base. For context, an overview of how metadata transformation and publishing workflows have changed over HIDVL’s history will be provided. Beyond presenting an example of how form design and metadata collection processes have changed over the course of 10 years, this talk will pose questions about obsolescence, in terms of technologies and data formats as well as the impacts of staff change on institutional knowledge loss, and ultimately suggest how we might counter both.
column19:

column7: No One's First and You're Next: An Interactive Session on Selecting for Digitization
column9: Digitization, Representation, Digital Libraries, Collections as Data
column10:
Social contexts and ethics/responsibility
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Although digital collections are an important resource, there is little consistency in how cultural heritage professionals select content for digitization. This workshop will provide space for participants to consider and share their institution’s digitization selection as it relates to representation, equity, institutional mandates, and collecting scopes.
column17: Although digital collections are an important resource, there is little consistency in how cultural heritage professionals select content for digitization. This workshop will provide space for participants to consider and share their institution’s digitization selection as it relates to representation, equity, institutional mandates, and collecting scopes.
column18:
Digital collections are important. They offer remote access to irreplaceable cultural heritage; they demonstrate which holdings institutions consider to be the most important; they are increasingly being used as data, opening new means of interpretation and interaction. However, many cultural heritage institutions lack thorough strategies for selecting content for digitization, leaving professionals to make digitization decisions without a clear mission.

This workshop will open by sharing findings from an ongoing Collections as Data project that uses the Louisiana Digital Library to investigate selection for digitization within a multi-institutional digital library. The workshop leaders will then moderate a series of exercises to enable workshop participants to share digitization selection policy at their own institution and brainstorm modifications.

The workshop leaders will provide specific discussion topics with related questions about selection for digitization. For example, one question might be, “When making decisions about what to digitize, does your institution consider community representation?” Attendees will be given time to individually consider answers to the questions in preparation for a gallery walk: the discussion questions will be posted on chart paper around the room, and attendees will visit each question and informally record their thoughts. Finally, attendees will split into small groups, each of which will be tasked with synthesizing a set of posted responses. Each group will share their synthesis, which will lead to a larger group discussion about digitization selection as it relates to representation, diversity, equity, institutional mandates and collecting scopes.

column7: Rethinking Repositories
column9: migration, collection management, digital scholarship, archives, digital collections
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Migrations of digital collections are difficult, resource-intensive, and therefore dreaded. However, they also present an opportunity to re-examine each aspect of a repository to improve usability, accessibility, and preservation. These presentations provoke discussion on strategies for advocacy, collaboration, user research, and stakeholder management, and provide inspiration to tackle transformative change.
column17: Migrations of digital collections are difficult, resource-intensive, and therefore dreaded. However, they also present an opportunity to re-examine each aspect of a repository to improve usability, accessibility, and preservation. These presentations provoke discussion on strategies for advocacy, collaboration, user research, and stakeholder management, and provide inspiration to tackle transformative change.
column18:
Migrations of digital collections to new platforms are difficult, resource-intensive, and therefore dreaded. However, because migrations require such large-scale work, they present an opportunity to re-examine each aspect of a repository, improving the usability, accessibility, and long-term preservation of the collection. Migrations often expose flaws that exist within repositories. While these flaws present challenges, this allows digital practitioners to identify and remediate these problems before they carry over to the new system.

Every migration of digital collections presents its own set of challenges unique to the institution and the platforms involved. Digital practitioners must think creatively and develop innovative solutions to overcome these challenges. This panel goes beyond offering migration strategies and encourages digital practitioners to undertake large-scale work on digital collections by re-framing migration as an opportunity for transformation rather than an obstacle to overcome. Panelists will share experiences with migration involving Islandora, CONTENTdm, ArchivesSpace, Knowvation, and in-house built digital content management systems. They will specifically speak to how they have taken advantage of migrations to advocate for additional resources, collaborate within and across institutions, evaluate usability, overhaul metadata, and otherwise optimize their digital collections.

Each presenter will begin with “two truths and a lie” about their migration story and poll the audience. This will create a space for both presenters and audience members to discuss missteps, failures, and sacrifices inherent to the migration process. Presenters will showcase how these lapses shouldn’t be covered up, but instead utilized for the enhancement of the repository.

These presentations will provide the basis for a discussion with the audience on concrete strategies for advocacy, effective collaboration, user research, and stakeholder management, in addition to broader inspiration to tackle transformative change.

column5: Hope College, United States of America
column7: Above the Fold through Time: Using Tableau and Digital Humanities Methods for Newspaper Database Analysis
column9: digital humanities, collection development, Tableau, newspaper subscriptions
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation will discuss the utilization of Tableau and digital humanities methodologies as a collection development tool for newspaper databases. Through a timeline-map and data visualization we compared database coverage in time and space. We will discuss project workflow from data collection to cleanup to analysis and research questions considered.
column17: This presentation will discuss the utilization of Tableau and digital humanities methodologies as a collection development tool for newspaper databases. Through a timeline-map and data visualization we compared database coverage in time and space. We will discuss project workflow from data collection to cleanup to analysis and research questions considered.
column18: Database evaluation has historically been a tricky prospect, with libraries attempting to balance coverage, cost, usability, and many other factors within a subscription decision. The presenters were interested in exploring full-text newspaper databases with a different lens and utilized Tableau to map content available within a range of subscription and open access databases. The use of a timeline-map allowed for a more critical look at the strengths and weaknesses of coverage by exploring newspaper coverage geographically and through time. Using a tool like Tableau is helpful for a library making decisions on the electronic resources that are the best fit for an institution’s teaching and research needs. Mapping also makes clearer the presence or lack of diversity in resources that advertise a global scope and may be helpful for a range of collection development projects. Tableau’s visual analysis capabilities bring to light whether a publisher’s advertised holdings line up with the “real” offerings within the database. This research method also allows for evaluating whether open access and public domain resources are a viable alternative to subscription databases. This presentation will summarize the project workflow from data collection to cleanup to analysis and share how the research questions evolved throughout the process. Attendees will be invited to brainstorm what other types of library-focused projects digital humanities tools might lend themselves.

column7: Responsive, Creative, and Intentional: Reimagining a Digital Library Program
column9: program review; digitization; services; collaborative leadership
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: In 2018, the Dartmouth Library’s digital program underwent a review, transforming from a digitization service with distributed staffing to a fully conceived digital program with an intentional mission and responsive leadership. As we continue implementation, we’ll share our process and recommendations for other organizations considering a similar transition.
column17: In 2018, the Dartmouth Library’s digital program underwent a review, transforming from a digitization service with distributed staffing to a fully conceived digital program with an intentional mission and responsive leadership. As we continue implementation, we’ll share our process and recommendations for other organizations considering a similar transition.
column18:
In 2018, the Dartmouth Library’s digital library program underwent a review, transforming a digitization service with distributed staffing into a fully conceived digital program with a stated mission and responsive, collaborative leadership. While the former program had functional workflows, it lacked goals or internal purpose; namely, it was reactive rather than intentional. Staff turnover led to responsibility for the program being placed in our hands; when a new AUL came on board with oversight over the program, we stepped forward to suggest a review (and volunteered to lead it). We envisioned an independent program with shared, collaborative leadership: a “production” leader responsible for process management and infrastructure development and a “community” leader responsible for education, outreach, and scholarship -- and we continue to work patiently and collaboratively to implement this vision. Most importantly, our driving ethos was building a responsive program with its own ambition, agenda, and shared values. Our program seeks to engage user communities with unique digital collections, produced collaboratively, inclusively, and openly.

This presentation will outline our review and implementation process, as well as share a glimpse at our documentation. We’ll detail what roadblocks and frustrations we faced but also the moments of satisfaction (and joy) along the way. We’ll also provide some tips for other programs looking to perform a complete overhaul or even implement some minor reforms while leading “from the side.” Institutional change can be difficult and frustrating; we’ll suggest, based on our experience, some approaches to facing those frustrations with persistence and humor.
