column7: Scaling for Feasibility: Case Studies in Automating Digital Preservation Tasks
column9: digital preservation, scaling, large collections, automation
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation examines how to scale digital preservation actions for collections comprising millions of objects, including working with stakeholders, automated packaging and ingest processes, and reporting options.
column17: This presentation examines how to scale digital preservation actions for collections comprising millions of objects, including working with stakeholders, automated packaging and ingest processes, and reporting options.
column18: When working with collections comprising millions of files, scale and its effect on all stages of a digital object’s lifecycle must be taken into account. Common issues that require closer consideration include moving the data from its original media, arrangement, modes of future access, packaging, and ingestion. The core tasks involved with preparing and maintaining bulk content in a preservation system are made feasible only through automation. This presentation will provide a detailed look at the work of preserving collections at this scale, including a discussion of working with stakeholders, automated packaging and ingest processes utilizing readily available tools on Windows and Linux/Mac platforms, and extending the reporting through preservation system APIs, direct database access, and third-party services. The presentation will address lessons learned throughout the process and planned next steps. Implementing digital preservation at scale requires flexibility and a willingness to explore different methods and tools.

column12: Project management, including workflows and processes
column16: The Iowa Labor History Oral Project (ILHOP) is a critical resource for Midwestern and labor history. Now, as the project retools for the digital age, it faces challenges and opportunities of managing large digitization projects, demonstrating the extensive collaborations necessary to create, sustain, and make accessible long-term oral history projects.
column17: The Iowa Labor History Oral Project (ILHOP) is a critical resource for Midwestern and labor history. Now, as the project retools for the digital age, it faces challenges and opportunities of managing large digitization projects, demonstrating the extensive collaborations necessary to create, sustain, and make accessible long-term oral history projects.
column18:
With approximately 1,300 interviews, the Iowa Labor History Oral Project (ILHOP) is a critical resource for Midwestern history. Started in the 1970s as a collaboration between the Iowa labor movement, the University of Iowa Labor Center, and the State Historical Society of Iowa, ILHOP has grown into one of the largest, longest-running labor-focused oral history projects in the world.

Now, as the project retools for the digital age, it faces challenges and opportunities associated with managing a large oral history project over time. Since 2013, with the support of new partners and a series of national grants, project staff have collected hundreds of new born-digital interviews, digitized over one thousand analog interviews, made the digitized collection accessible online, and begun the process of transitioning a 2003 print index into a complete, expandable, and keyword searchable digital index.

While this recent work has greatly expanded ILHOP’s reach and significance, it has also created new challenges for project management. This presentation will focus on the shortcomings of controlled vocabulary for indexing and metadata creation. Both the structure of the 2003 index (developed for interviews focused on the 1930s-1960s) and LCSH terms have frequently been insufficient for describing the project as it has grown and evolved over time.

Our intention is to demonstrate the extensive collaborations necessary to create, sustain, and make accessible long-term oral history projects. Our audience is those of all skill levels interested in oral histories, historical diversity, and digitization project management.

column16: This presentation 1) addresses the role that archival justice can play in the digital humanities classroom, while playing a vital role in unearthing silenced histories, 2) shares pedagogical considerations and challenges for such a topical focus, and 3) highlights students' final projects that resulted from the course.
column17: This presentation 1) addresses the role that archival justice can play in the digital humanities classroom, while playing a vital role in unearthing silenced histories, 2) shares pedagogical considerations and challenges for such a topical focus, and 3) highlights students' final projects that resulted from the course.
column18: In 2019, El Diario de la Gente, the independent Chicanx student newspaper at CU was digitized and made publicly available, which documents student activism, activities of Los Seis and other activists, and engagement in the national Chicanx movement. Additionally, a statue was finally dedicated in commemoration of these students in front of TB1, a building on campus where sit-ins and protests took place to fight for Chicanx curricula, in addition to student rights for tuition assistance and student governance. Harnessing this unique cultural moment, the newspaper was incorporated into an introductory Digital Humanities (DH) graduate course taught by a faculty teaching librarian, as a means of enabling students' exploration of a variety of DH literacies, from exploring computational approaches such as text mining and geospatial analysis, to postcolonial and feminist values. This presentation 1) addresses the role that archival justice can play in the digital humanities classroom, while playing a vital role in unearthing silenced histories, 2) shares pedagogical considerations and challenges for such a topical focus, and 3) highlights students' final project that resulted from the class, Digital El Diario (digitaleldiario.com).

column16: Entomo-3D is a transdisciplinary project to digitize 15,000 insect specimens representing critical pollinators from the Virginia Tech Entomology Collection, including 300 3D models through high-resolution photogrammetry. This collection showcases federally listed endangered species which are declining due to habitat loss, climate change, and other factors.
column17: Entomo-3D is a transdisciplinary project to digitize 15,000 insect specimens representing critical pollinators from the Virginia Tech Entomology Collection, including 300 3D models through high-resolution photogrammetry. This collection showcases federally listed endangered species which are declining due to habitat loss, climate change, and other factors.
column18:
Entomo-3D is a transdisciplinary project to digitize 15,000 insect specimens representing critical pollinators from the Virginia Tech Entomology Collection, including 300 3D models through high-resolution photogrammetry. This collection showcases federally listed endangered species which are declining due to habitat loss, climate change, and other factors.

Due to Virginia Tech’s strong creative technologies program and entomology program we sought to build partnerships across these disciplines to attract and fund three graduate students to complete most of the project. The grant pays for the student’s salary and benefits, while the university covers the tuition as cost share, allowing each of the students to secure a graduate education, master a horizon technology, and graduate in two years without incurring educational debt.

The outreach and assessment strategy includes working with rural Appalachian schools to bring these models to middle school students to both promote their use, and also determine how learning with 3D models is different from learning with physical specimens. Outreach also includes working with the local chapter of the Master Naturalists program to both leverage their expertise, and also incorporate these new digital resources into their training materials for education and for certification.

This highly visual presentation will focus on the strategies for additional support from administrators for this project, highlight the development of professional and institutional capacity, and the preparation of students for future employment through developing these collections.

column16: Thinking of bringing in a Wikipedian in residence to your library? Over the past decade, these residencies have become a popular way to establish collaborative relationships with the Wikimedia community. In this interactive panel discussion, librarians from three Canadian public universities will share their experiences hosting Wikipedians in residence.
column17: Thinking of bringing in a Wikipedian in residence to your library? Over the past decade, these residencies have become a popular way to establish collaborative relationships with the Wikimedia community. In this interactive panel discussion, librarians from three Canadian public universities will share their experiences hosting Wikipedians in residence.
column18:
Over the past 10 years, Wikipedian in residence (WiR) positions have become a popular way for library and archival institutions to establish collaborative working relationships with the Wikimedia open knowledge community. First introduced by the British Museum, a Wikipedian in residence is typically an experienced Wikipedia editor who works with an institution to both develop relationships in the community and facilitate the contribution of free open content to Wikipedia. With more than 175 examples self-reported on the Wikipedia Outreach page, there is no shortage of examples, but what we found was that each position is unique to the institutions and shaped by a variety of factors, including administrative and funding structures, labour restrictions, the role and priorities of the supervising manager, existing initiatives, and the candidate pool.

In this panel discussion, we will bring together three librarians from large, public, Canadian universities who each led the development of a WiR at their respective universities to discuss how the programs worked and what didn’t. The panel will start at the beginning and discuss how the WiR was proposed and funded, as well as the nitty gritty of developing a job description and recruiting the WiR candidate. We will also discuss how the positions varied, in response to our different institutional cultures and goals. Each institution will describe the wikipedia projects that came out of the residency which include: integrating collections to promote usage, library staff focused training to build broad based capacity with Wikipedia, and community digital literacy programming. The panel will end with a discussion on the assessment of the residencies and examples of how the residencies positively impacted their university and wider communities.

By bringing together three different perspectives on the WiR in a discussion style format, attendees will be able to see what factors shaped each position and learn about the breadth of Wikipedia activities undertaken. Attendees will leave this session with a variety of examples of Wikipedian projects that they can explore at their libraries. For academic libraries without the resources or institutional support to fund a WiR position, attendees will leave with ideas for sustainable initiatives that can be incorporated into existing workflows. In order to keep the presentation interactive and accessible, we will have an open Google Doc available for notes and questions from attendees, and we will monitor Twitter for questions. The Google Doc will then serve as a summary of the session for attendees’ future reference.

column9: Assessment, scholarly communication, rubrics
column10:
Assessment
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Over the last year, we have conducted focus groups, interviews, and a national forum with the goal of developing an approach to assessing academic libraries’ scholarly communication programs. In this session, we will share a draft assessment rubric developed out of our findings to elicit feedback and discussion.
column17: Over the last year, we have conducted focus groups, interviews, and a national forum with the goal of developing an approach to assessing academic libraries’ scholarly communication programs. In this session, we will share a draft assessment rubric developed out of our findings to elicit feedback and discussion.
column18:
With new technologies and paradigms for creating and sharing work, scholars across all fields have seen changes in research output, dissemination and preservation of the scholarly record, emergent publishing models, and the measurement of scholarly impact. During the past two decades, academic libraries have begun to further invest in scholarly communication through the allocation of staffing and resources and even establishing institutional repositories. However, quantifying the actual outcome or impact of these scholarly communication activities remains elusive, beyond output measures such as simple counts of consultations, workshop attendance, or by repository downloads or growth.

In August 2019 Sacramento State University and San Jose State University were awarded an IMLS National Forum grant to assess scholarly communication programs at M1 public institutions. The co-PIs conducted focus groups with scholarly communication practitioners and interviewed campus stakeholders. In May 2020, we held the National Forum on the Assessment of Scholarly Communication Programs. We’d like to propose an unconference format to present the assessment rubric we developed out of this project at the 2020 DLF Forum. We would share the draft rubric with attendees, talk through the various sections of the rubric, and get feedback on what could be improved. Participants will have the opportunity to share their own assessment methodologies and take home ideas for assessment and services of their organization’s scholarly communication program.

This project was made possible in part by the Institute of Museum and Library Services (LG-35-19-0066-19).

column16: To assess where the Digital Humanities graduate certificate at the University of Colorado Boulder might consider expanding course offerings, the presenters took a multimodal approach to gathering stakeholder feedback. We present our data-driven assessment process, the outcomes based on expressed stakeholder needs, and future plans for expanding the curriculum.
column17: To assess where the Digital Humanities graduate certificate at the University of Colorado Boulder might consider expanding course offerings, the presenters took a multimodal approach to gathering stakeholder feedback. We present our data-driven assessment process, the outcomes based on expressed stakeholder needs, and future plans for expanding the curriculum.
column18:
The Digital Humanities Graduate Certificate is an interdisciplinary program that was launched at the University of Colorado Boulder (CU Boulder) was launched in fall 2018. It is administratively situated in the Center for Research Data and Digital Scholarship, an interdisciplinary center focusing on data-intensive research. The center is a partnership between the CU Boulder University Libraries and campus Research Computing. The certificate offers CU Boulder graduate students the opportunity to learn about the field and its associated methods and movements through a core course (DHUM 5000: Introduction to Digital Humanities) and a deeper dive into program areas of focus through two electives and an optional capstone. Interdisciplinary collaboration is encouraged throughout.

The certificate program has enjoyed growing interest in both the core course and numbers of declared students. The curriculum currently is drawn largely from existing course offerings in schools and colleges across CU Boulder in order. In order to assess in which areas and formats the center might consider expanding bespoke course offerings, the presenters and 2019/2020 CLIR postdoctoral fellow at CU Boulder took a multimodal approach to gathering stakeholder feedback about what they would like to see in new offerings counting for the certificate program. We will present our data-driven assessment process, the outcomes based on expressed stakeholder needs, and future plans for expanding the certificate program’s curriculum.

column7: Approaching Data Science and Computer Programming Education
column9: education, instruction, computer programming, data science
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Digital literacy has become increasingly important to the field of librarianship. This session seeks to expand perspective and drive evolution in data instruction. Common themes in computer programming instruction methods, and how these impede or empower different types of learners, will be a focus of the session’s discussion.
column17: Digital literacy has become increasingly important to the field of librarianship. This session seeks to expand perspective and drive evolution in data instruction. Common themes in computer programming instruction methods, and how these impede or empower different types of learners, will be a focus of the session’s discussion.
column18:
Digital literacy has become increasingly important to the field of librarianship. Now, more than ever before, people are working with and relying on data and analytics to carry out critical duties. People from different educational backgrounds are entering data science and learning computer programming skills. However, a “one size fits all” model can leave some behind. How do data librarians or instructors acknowledge and meet the needs of this population? How can they remove barriers to success for those learners least likely to feel empowered to learn these skills?

Many people new to computer coding can feel overwhelmed. This session will discuss the current landscape of programming instruction, focusing on Python. In addition, the author will postulate questions to stimulate new thinking about how instructors might make computer programming skill-acquisition less daunting for newcomers. Drawing on personal experience, as a learner with a humanities background, the author theorizes that similar to language acquisition, people can be taught to read and understand computer code through the inherent patterns that exist within code.

This session seeks to expand perspective and drive evolution in data instruction. Common themes in computer programming instruction methods, and how these impede or empower different types of learners, will be a focus of the session’s discussion. The author will engage attendees in brainstorming and reflection on more effective ways to teach digital literacies by translating familiar structures to code, both in format and through semantics.

column7: Privacy and Identification Linking Issues in Archival Processes for Highly Sensitive Pediatric Translational Biomedical Research Data
column9: biomedical informatics, archives, genomic data, research data
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: How does an operational team balance privacy and access when building an enterprise research archives for patient data? At the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, a research group for rare birth defects is leveraging expertise across diverse disciplines to develop new best practices and privacy standards for archiving sensitive biomedical data.
column17: How does an operational team balance privacy and access when building an enterprise research archives for patient data? At the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, a research group for rare birth defects is leveraging expertise across diverse disciplines to develop new best practices and privacy standards for archiving sensitive biomedical data.
column18:
INTRODUCTION: The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) operates a biobank following outcomes of children with congenital birth defects. Pregnant parents who carry a fetus with a prenatal diagnosis have data tracked from birth to adulthood. Data includes highly sensitive information about parents, obstetrical outcomes, and children; therefore, robust privacy measures are put in place to protect participant identity in this research. The project complexity requires appropriately managed identifiers to link data from multiple clinical systems. This data is intended to fuel new research and includes medical history, obstetric history, prenatal diagnosis and management, delivery outcomes, specific surgical details, family history, biological samples, and genomic data.

OBJECTIVES: Incorporate innovative privacy practices with traditional archival workflows during and as an integral component of a complex study’s active processes.

METHODS: Engage institutional compliance officers to establish a documentable solution upholding identity management for the protocol. Make recommendations to the technical/operational team for archival practices that maintain the provenance of data linked to a given patient.

RESULTS: For this specific case, we detail archival storage plans in the research protocol. We also inform patients in “lay language” that their protected health information (PHI) will be protected by honest brokering as well as stored permanently in the institutional archives.

CONCLUSION: Professional archival practices are new in the biomedical domain, and this case study is at the forefront of defining archival best practices for highly sensitive biomedical research that ensure personal information and data are preserved appropriately, all in order to advance patient outcomes.
column19:
INTRODUCTION: The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) operates a biobank following outcomes of children with congenital birth defects. Pregnant parents who carry a fetus with a prenatal diagnosis have data tracked from birth to adulthood. Data includes highly sensitive information about parents, obstetrical outcomes, and children; therefore, robust privacy measures are put in place to protect participant identity in this research. The project complexity requires appropriately managed identifiers to link data from multiple clinical systems. This data is intended to fuel new research and includes medical history, obstetric history, prenatal diagnosis and management, delivery outcomes, specific surgical details, family history, biological samples, and genomic data.
OBJECTIVES: Incorporate innovative privacy practices with traditional archival workflows during and as an integral component of a complex study’s active processes.
METHODS: Engage institutional compliance officers to establish a documentable solution upholding identity management for the protocol. Make recommendations to the technical/operational team for archival practices that maintain the provenance of data linked to a given patient.
RESULTS: For this specific case, we detail archival storage plans in the research protocol. We also inform patients in “lay language” that their protected health information (PHI) will be protected by honest brokering as well as stored permanently in the institutional archives.
CONCLUSION: Professional archival practices are new in the biomedical domain, and this case study is at the forefront of defining archival best practices for highly sensitive biomedical research that ensure personal information and data are preserved appropriately, all in order to advance patient outcomes.
column29: DOBRZYNSKC@EMAIL.CHOP.EDU, GERACES@EMAIL.CHOP.EDU, MOLINAMM@EMAIL.CHOP.EDU, BURKPAPPAS@email.chop.edu, REUTERD@email.chop.edu, EvansJ@email.chop.edu, WOYCIECHOWSKI@email.chop.edu, padula@email.chop.edu, MOLDENHAUERJ@email.chop.edu, GAYNOR@email.chop.edu, felmeistera@email.chop.edu
column50: This project is a multi-disciplinary biomedical data and tissue repository focused specifically on outcomes using tissue banking that generate significant clinical and genomic data on rare diseases in pediatric populations. The concept of creating archives for this data is new to The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), and we are learning as we go thanks to a new team in our Department of Biomedical and Health Informatics specifically made up of digital archivists and metadata librarians. We are excited to bridge the gap between biomedical research and digital archives. We are starting to truly comprehend the need for this in our work, and look forward to contributing our experiences to the field and learning about through collaboration.   - Alex S. Felmeister, PhD, Research Scientist, Department of Biomedical and Health Informatics, The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia

column16: In 2016, multiple organizations launched a Data Management Training Clearinghouse. In 2018, DMTC was awarded additional support for enhancement from IMLS. column17: In 2016, multiple organizations launched a Data Management Training Clearinghouse. In 2018, DMTC was awarded additional support for enhancement from IMLS. This workshop will demonstrate the capabilities of the newly enhanced DMTC by providing hands-on introduction to the search and curation functions, and inviting participants to join the DMTC community.
column18:
in 2015, the enhanced Data Management Training Clearinghouse (DMTC) at http://dmtclearinghouse.esipfed.org has, through Spring 2020, collected over 600 skill building resources targeted to both those teaching and those wishing to learn data skills. Each resource has been submitted by a member of the project team or by the broader community, and goes through a curation and review process by community reviewers prior to publication. In 2018, the Institute of Museum and Library Services awarded the DMTC a three year National Leadership Grant for its enhancement in four critical areas:

1. Expansion of the documentation model and search capabilities to include additional attributes that have been identified by users and by a metadata working group.

2. Development of integrated assessment capabilities in the DMTC that capture improved usage statistics, UI usability feedback, and learner and instructor feedback for training materials published in the DMTC.

3. Expansion and diversification of the content of the DMTC beyond the core of Earth science and research data management skill building - the early focus of DMTC collection development.

4. Targeted outreach to the academic library community to increase familiarity with and use of the DMTC, and engage the community in the continued development and growth of the DMTC.

This workshop will demonstrate the capabilities of the newly developed DMTC by:

1. Providing an overview of the DMTC and its capabilities with an emphasis on individual and small group exploration of the interface to discover skill building materials relevant to the topic areas of workshop participants.

2. Demonstrating the submission and curation process as an opportunity for workshop participants to gain an understanding of the underlying documentation model, and the submission, review and publication workflow for DMTC content.

3. Soliciting feedback from workshop participants on their experiences using the DMTC to discover materials of interest to them, and on the presented submission, review, and publication process.

4. Inviting workshop participants to join a growing community of content creators, content submitters, and reviewers.

Learning Outcomes:

1. Outcome 1 – Workshop participants will be able to use both the browse and search capabilities of the DMTC to find skill building materials relevant to their needs.

2. Outcome 2 – Workshop participants will know how to submit materials for integration into the DMTC and understand the underlying curation process to which those materials will be subjected.

3. Outcome 3 – Workshop participants will understand the various areas in which they could potentially contribute to the community activities of the DMTC: as content creators, submitters, and reviewers.

The planned outcomes of the workshop are to bring a broader familiarity with, understanding, and use of the DMTC and its content to the academic library workshop participants; to receive actionable feedback from the community that can be integrated into ongoing planning for future enhancements to the DMTC; and to invite new participants to the continued growth and diversification of content in the DMTC by serving as content creators, submitters, and reviewers.

column16: Implementing a digital scholarship support strategy in a small liberal arts college can seem like a daunting task. At Vassar College we have implemented a sustainable and manageable solution through campus wide partnerships with talented technical professionals that actively support the needs of faculty and students.
column17: Implementing a digital scholarship support strategy in a small liberal arts college can seem like a daunting task. At Vassar College we have implemented a sustainable and manageable solution through campus wide partnerships with talented technical professionals that actively support the needs of faculty and students.
column18: Implementing a digital scholarship support strategy in a small liberal arts college can seem like a daunting task. At Vassar College we have implemented a sustainable and manageable solution through campus wide partnerships with talented technical professionals that actively support the needs of faculty and students. This collaboration is equipped with multiple studios and labs across campus. The Digital Scholarship Services Collaboration (DiSSCo) is composed of staff from the Library Digital Scholarship & Technology Services, Academic Computing Services, Library Research Services, and Media Resources departments. We have come together with the goal of better meeting the needs and supporting the interests of faculty and students pursuing digital scholarship in their teaching, learning, and research. Our work became an essential facet of the student experience during the 2019-2020 school year when the "Vassar Intensive Experiential Work" initiative was officially implemented. Intensives provide innovative learning opportunities that complement more traditional courses. These faculty-mentored experiences have provided an incubator for digital scholarship that allows the value of the DiSSCo group to shine. Through collaboration we strive to fill any potential service and knowledge gaps. We provide training, expertise, and campus resources to help transform ideas into sustainable projects that can be shared, extended, and reviewed within the scholarly community. This presentation will review the organizational structure and governance of DiSSCo as well as share the many exciting projects we have participated in. The shift from support in our physical spaces to the digital during the Covid-19 pandemic will also be addressed.

column9: preservation, platform, planning, research, discovery

column16: Adoption of digital preservation practices and technologies is on the rise, but planning for preservation is not what it used to be, especially for academic libraries. This session will explore the experiences of two archives and libraries in their move to a unified digital preservation system.
column17: Adoption of digital preservation practices and technologies is on the rise, but planning for preservation is not what it used to be, especially for academic libraries. This session will explore the experiences of two archives and libraries in their move to a unified digital preservation system.
column18:
Adoption of digital preservation practices and technologies is on the rise, but planning for preservation is not what it used to be, especially for academic libraries. The sheer volume of inbound data and objects under management that a digital archive is responsible for is growing exponentially as research systems proliferate.

Often, each project, discipline, and department has a specialized system for managing digital information amplifying the challenges of ensuring long-term and permanent resources remain accessible and usable to stakeholders, especially during uncertain times. This situation is further complicated by the proliferation of operational solutions that claim to include preservation—but what does this mean? Is the system simply running virus checks and checksums? Has ‘cloud’ become a de facto equivalent for ‘safe’? How best to address licensing concerns and exit strategies? Are these same systems good for access and discovery?

This session will highlight the experiences of two academic archives and libraries in their move to a dedicated and unified digital preservation system. The panel will discuss processes they have created to amplify the opportunities provided by a unified solution while minimizing and managing implementation challenges.

Services and programs

column16: As digital practitioners, we’re commonly asked for advice on launching digital projects from outside organizations. Digital Projects Librarian Amy Bocko will discuss her past efforts to support smaller organizations in digitization efforts through educational efforts/sharing best practices, and how this has led to developing new programs and successful grant-funding.
column17: As digital practitioners, we’re commonly asked for advice on launching digital projects from outside organizations. Digital Projects Librarian Amy Bocko will discuss her past efforts to support smaller organizations in digitization efforts through educational efforts/sharing best practices, and how this has led to developing new programs and successful grant-funding.
column18:
As digital practitioners, we commonly field inquiries from outside parties looking for advice on launching digital projects. In Digital Projects Librarian Amy Bocko’s experience the common threads in these requests come from institutions that are: 1) facing funding challenges/lack the resources to launch a digitization space/repository solution; 2) lack in-house expertise to start a digital program/proceed without growing pains; and 3) are unsure how to start scaled digital projects that will be sustainable/adhere to best practices.

In 2015, Bocko developed a “digital initiatives bootcamp”- an introduction, planning exercise and resource bank for fellow librarians/archivists in under-resourced institutions to launch sustainable digital projects. Most recently in her position at Western Michigan University, she discovered that her previous efforts did not suit the needs of the wider cultural heritage community that sought her help and she needed to develop a new approach to support digitization efforts. This led Bocko to secure grant-funding to support building a digitization equipment lending library and student assistantship; these resources coupled with WMU’s preexisting digital library infrastructure and the educational materials/guidelines she created, have enabled local institutions digitize their materials and reach a wider audience through WMU’s collection hosting/DPLA harvesting. While Phase 1 has been successful in helping two local institutions enter the digital library space, Bocko will share her plans for Phase 2, which include increasing the reach of the program and establishing a regional digitization hub to support the growth of digital access Southwest Michigan’s cultural heritage materials.

column7: Level Up!: Lessons Learned from Six Years of Collaborative Technical Skills Development
column9: Coding/computer programming, professional development, project management, team learning, technical skills

column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: As archives and libraries expand their digital collections and services, acquiring or expanding technical skills is no longer the exclusive domain of individuals; it is an institutional imperative. Two archivists and one librarian reflect on six years’ worth of lessons learned promoting collaborative technical upskilling at a large, academic archive.
column17: As archives and libraries expand their digital collections and services, acquiring or expanding technical skills is no longer the exclusive domain of individuals; it is an institutional imperative. Two archivists and one librarian reflect on six years’ worth of lessons learned promoting collaborative technical upskilling at a large, academic archive.
column18:
As archives and libraries expand their digital collections and services, acquiring or expanding technical skills is no longer the exclusive domain of individuals, although much of the professional literature on this topic might make it appear otherwise. Rather, it is an institutional imperative. Technical upskilling is as important as other types of professional development, and institutions should be encouraging their employees to collaboratively develop and promote their technical literacy.

In this presentation, two archivists and one librarian will reflect on over six years’ worth of promoting collaborative technical upskilling within the Curation team at the University of Michigan Bentley Historical Library. The presenters--who represent a number of diverse roles at the Bentley--will reflect on lessons learned from three consecutive initiatives: one provided opportunities for a small group to focus on a specific set of technical skills; another expanded the collaborative learning component of its predecessor by opening a variety of technical skills topics to the entire team; and still another provided an in-depth opportunity for a subteam to work on a single deliverable over a concentrated amount of time. The presentation will conclude with a “long view” of what went well, and what could be improved, with an emphasis on equity and inclusiveness. While the presenters come from a particular perspective, the audience should leave with relevant takeaways to bring to their own institutions, regardless of size or academic affiliation, and will be invited to share their experiences advocating for, promoting, or participating in technical upskilling throughout the presentation.

column5: University of Arizona Libraries
column7: The Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F): Early Indicators from a Pilot Program at the University of Arizona Libraries
column9: fellowships, data science, digital scholarship
column10:
Services and programs
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation provides an overview of the Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F) program, which was recently piloted at the University of Arizona Libraries. We support graduate students in building capacity for campus-wide training in data and computational scholarship. Presenters will discuss program design, initial outcomes, and future plans.
column17: This presentation provides an overview of the Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F) program, which was recently piloted at the University of Arizona Libraries. We support graduate students in building capacity for campus-wide training in data and computational scholarship. Presenters will discuss program design, initial outcomes, and future plans.
column18:
Across disciplines, rapidly growing interest in digital and data-intensive scholarship creates a largely unmet need for critical training in technical skills. To address this need, the University of Arizona Libraries allocated funding to test a proof of concept, one-year pilot with four graduate fellows. Our program, the Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F), is intended to build capacity for campus-wide training in data and computational scholarship. It address three known challenges in contemporary higher education: (1) insufficient training for data-intensive, computational research within subject disciplines; (2) uneven attention to digital pedagogy and strategies for teaching technical concepts within graduate training programs; and (3) a need for ongoing development of modular curricula that can be integrated into the classroom and extracurricular workshops or used independently by scholars and researchers at the point of need.

Our pilot launched in January 2020 with a series of workshops whereby library subject matter experts trained graduate students on technical and pedagogical skills. In turn, the students embarked on a process of self-directed learning with projects related to digital scholarship and data science, culminating in a series of open workshops that extend their knowledge to the campus community. Librarians’ instructional sessions (1) build connections between the cohort and mentors, (2) teach the basics of instructional design of short-term, modular workshops, (3) convey best practices in digital pedagogy, and (4) discuss open educational resources and open licensing. Early indicators from our pilot suggest that the model is successful and extensible to the greater academic library community.

column16: The UBC Library Research Commons (RC) provides introductory workshops on tools and skills employed in digital scholarship. In Winter 2019, the RC collectively started using GitHub to create open and reproducible content for these workshops. This talk is on the development and implementation of our collaborative workflow based in Github.
column17: The UBC Library Research Commons (RC) provides introductory workshops on tools and skills employed in digital scholarship. In Winter 2019, the RC collectively started using GitHub to create open and reproducible content for these workshops. This talk is on the development and implementation of our collaborative workflow based in Github.
column18:
The University of British Columbia Library Research Commons (RC) provides introductory workshops on tools and skills employed in digital scholarship. In Winter 2019, the RC collectively started using GitHub to create open and reproducible content for these workshops.

RC educational content creators include librarian faculty, Graduate Academic Assistants (GAAs), and partners from other units. A workshop may have multiple authors and be updated by many people. Because of this distributed content development, one workshop may have many versions stored in many places and formats.

To coordinate our activities we adopted a workflow that leverages GitHub. Open, modular instructional content is collaboratively authored and published using GitHub Pages. We tested the workflow on a series of librarian-created technical workshops on core skills for digital scholarship. The next stage is to extend the workflow to others in the RC including a TLEF-funded team of graduate students who will develop GIScience content, and our core GAA instructors.

This talk will introduce our approach to building consensus on what tool to use, why we settled on Github, how we piloted this approach on a local case study, and lessons we learned. We will also present on the outcomes of the second phase of this work which will occur over Summer 2020.

column5: Northeastern University, United States of America
column7: Technical Debt: Causes, Identification, And Remediation
column9: technical debt, sustainability
column10:
Project management, including workflows and processes
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column12: Project management, including workflows and processes
column16: There is no such thing as a codebase that doesn't contain technical debt, but it can be managed to remove the worst negative consequences. In this talk, I will present the approach to managing it that we have developed at the Digital Scholarship Group at Northeastern University.
column17: There is no such thing as a codebase that doesn't contain technical debt, but it can be managed to remove the worst negative consequences. In this talk, I will present the approach to managing it that we have developed at the Digital Scholarship Group at Northeastern University.
column18:
Over the course of the last year and a half, the Digital Scholarship Group at Northeastern University identified several codebases that were increasingly difficult to work with and update. Common symptoms included repeated code, inflexible code structures, design anti-patterns, and a resulting long backlog of issues. We needed to establish new practices among the developers, and get buy-in from the stakeholders, to plan an approach to remediating the state of code in various projects.

In this talk, I will begin with the steps that uncovered the problem areas involved. This will involve a brief and gentle direct look at code that exhibits technical debt (eschewing casting any blame on previous or current developers -- that isn’t helpful to moving forward). With that basis, I will look into some code archeology, hypothesizing about the work circumstances that fostered the build-up of technical debt, also heavily inspired by last year’s DLF presentation “Planning for Perpetuity: Towards a Model of Technical Debt for Cultural Heritage Institutions”.

I will also summarize the conversations that led to the buy-in from stakeholders, an essential step in project management for sustainability of code, and the firm decisions that came out of those conversations, especially establishing a “Maintenance Friday” time that the developers and managers mutually understand as a necessary, long-term part of our processes.
column19:
Over the course of the last year and a half, the Digital Scholarship Group at Northeastern University identified several codebases that were increasingly difficult to work with and update. Common symptoms included repeated code, inflexible code structures, design anti-patterns, and a resulting long backlog of issues. We needed to establish new practices among the developers, and get buy-in from the stakeholders, to plan an approach to remediating the state of code in various projects.
In this talk, I will begin with the steps that uncovered the problem areas involved. This will involve a brief and gentle direct look at code that exhibits technical debt (eschewing casting any blame on previous or current developers -- that isn’t helpful to moving forward). With that basis, I will look into some code archeology, hypothesizing about the work circumstances that fostered the build-up of technical debt, also heavily inspired by last year’s DLF presentation “Planning for Perpetuity: Towards a Model of Technical Debt for Cultural Heritage Institutions”.
I will also summarize the conversations that led to the buy-in from stakeholders, an essential step in project management for sustainability of code, and the firm decisions that came out of those conversations, especially establishing a “Maintenance Friday” time that the developers and managers mutually understand as a necessary, long-term part of our processes.
column50:
I'm hoping that others might submit proposals on the topic of technical debt. I was trying to pull them together for a fuller panel proposal, but then coronavirus happened. So, I'll leave individual proposals to you all to organize as you see fit.

I also know that I'll be putting in a completely different submission, and understand that you -- quite rightly -- won't put in two presentations from the same person. As above, that's part of your fun job to discern which is more useful to the community!

column7: Whys And Choices Around FLOSS Licenses
column9: open source, licenses
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
Leadership and management
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Many of us writing code or managing projects, not being lawyers, often have to rely on broad guides available online to choose a license. I’ll talk through the details of our organization’s decisions about what licenses to apply, and why.
column17: Many of us writing code or managing projects, not being lawyers, often have to rely on broad guides available online to choose a license. I’ll talk through the details of our organization’s decisions about what licenses to apply, and why.
column18:
Whenever developers fire up a new repository in GitHub, we are helpfully prompted to choose a license for the code. While GitHub itself, as well as other sources, provide very useful guides, they can become more mechanical than is truly instructive for the hows and whys for defining a FLOSS project.

In this talk, I will walk through the history of Northeastern University Digital Scholarship Group’s work to become more deliberate about the licenses applied to the code that we publish. It will start with our -- I think, generally shared with many other libraries -- position of wanting to share our work with others to build on (especially when public-grant funded). Then, we’ll talk about the different license options we considered and rejected, and why we made our choices about our admittedly loose and flexible policy.

(Please note, I am not a lawyer, nor does the thinking here have the imprimatur of any lawyer.)

Since 2016, the DLF Metadata Support Group has offered an informal and supportive networking space for people who work with digital libraries and metadata. The Slack community has over 600 members who participate in discussion channels dedicated to general metadata topics, migrations, linked data, workflows, and more.

During our Breakfast/Lunch Session, we will…..

Gather together to discuss the impact of the pandemic on metadata work

Share some of the major metadata topics of discussion that occurred over the last year on Slack

Anyone doing metadata and digital library work is welcome to participate in this session!

column9: ACCESSIBILITY, INCLUSIVE DESIGN, DIGITAL EXHIBITION
column10:
Policy, legal, and accessibility issues
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Recent lawsuits against Hunters Point Library for violation of Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) evidence that accessibility is not optional, but rather mandatory for professional at all levels. This presentation builds on different fields to present approaches to address accessibility for practitioners in digital library, archives, and museums.
column17: Recent lawsuits against Hunters Point Library for violation of Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) evidence that accessibility is not optional, but rather mandatory for professional at all levels. This presentation builds on different fields to present approaches to address accessibility for practitioners in digital library, archives, and museums.
column18: In November 2019, Hunters Point library in New York City was sued for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by not making the new building accessible to people with wheelchairs. In January 2019, Beyoncé Knowles was sued for not providing accommodation for people with significant vision impairments to access the primary portal for news about all Beyoncé’s fans club. These recent lawsuits for violating ADA show the importance of integrating and addressing issues of accessibility in the design of any product, or material that is meant for public consumption. Though mandated by law, issues of accessibility are still for many institutions and practitioners an afterthought. As public organization, libraries are mandated by law to be open and welcoming to everyone irrespective of their abilities, gender, race, or sexual orientation. In a context where diversity is not just limited to race, gender, cultural background, and social status, but also includes various abilities, it is critical for librarians, curators, and archivists to address accessibility in their workflow. This presentation will engage participants in an interactive discussion on the issue of accessibility. The presenter will draw on various fields approach to addressing accessibility. Building on a design process she termed “designing inclusive digital exhibition” to guide the discussion on practical ways practitioners in digital library, archives, and museums can address and integrate accessibility in their workflow.

column16: With the increasing demand for geographic components in research, there is an opportunity for research data repositories to provide alternatives to text-based discovery. This brief talk introduces Geodisy: an open-source spatial discovery platform for Canadian open research data, developed by a UBC team over the last eighteen months.
column17: With the increasing demand for geographic components in research, there is an opportunity for research data repositories to provide alternatives to text-based discovery. This brief talk introduces Geodisy: an open-source spatial discovery platform for Canadian open research data, developed by a UBC team over the last eighteen months.
column18:
With the increasing demand for geographic components in research, there is an opportunity for research data repositories to provide alternatives to text-based discovery. Enter Geodisy: an open-source spatial discovery platform for Canadian open research data. Initially funded by CANARIE, Geodisy’s online interface provides a map-based search that is available alongside Canada’s Federated Research Data Repository (FRDR). Users search for data based on its location and have the ability to preview datasets as overlays on a digital map and access comprehensive metadata. Data is currently sourced from Scholars Portal Dataverse, which houses open research data from forty Canadian institutions.

The platform and the software behind it use both pre-existing and custom-made components, all of which are free and open-source. The code and pipeline setup instructions are freely available via our public Github repository, and other institutions are both welcome and encouraged to adopt their own instances of the software.

This work benefits all research disciplines that use geospatial location, from anthropology to zoology to climate science. The project’s next goal is to expand the interoperability of the software to include additional data sources, such as governmental open research data. In this presentation, we will share software architecture designs, metadata mapping processes, and a demonstration of the platform.

column7: Sustaining Reflective Practice Through Emergency Remote Teaching
column9: Critical Digital Pedagogy, Online Learning, Metacognition, Reflective Practice
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Join us in reflecting on our relationship to technical systems during emergency remote teaching, while also exploring issues such as trust, authority, and grief. A 5-minute presentation will be posted prior to the Forum. During the session, join us for 15-minute breakout groups that put these ideas into practice.
column17: Join us in reflecting on our relationship to technical systems during emergency remote teaching, while also exploring issues such as trust, authority, and grief. A 5-minute presentation will be posted prior to the Forum. During the session, join us for 15-minute breakout groups that put these ideas into practice.
column18: For five years, we have run a series of face-to-face “Toolshops” at the University of Pittsburgh that bring members of our academic community together in semi-structured settings to work on the aspects of our professional work driven more by the social practice of shared meta-cognitive reflection than on content-driven scholarship. The abrupt transition to emergency remote teaching prompted us to transition the core of our Toolshop work online via the development of a series of co-learning encounters that facilitated problem-solving alongside open-ended inquiry. We wondered together, how can we support one another as we redefine our expectations, approaches, and identities as both teachers and learners? Using the topics of critical digital pedagogy, archives, and “thinking like a computer,” we were interested in expressing thoughts in, through, and about technical systems while also exploring issues such as trust, authority, and grief. We considered the ways we could release our control of the conversation without abandoning the community, as well as the capacious affordances of domestic spaces, the workings of liberatory pedagogy, and the workings of generous practice. We propose to offer a 5-minute, pre-recorded presentation of our process of reconfiguring the Toolshop model into synchronous/asynchronous co-learning experiences (made accessible prior to the Forum), and use our 15 synchronous minutes to run breakout groups (whether in-person or online) working with participants on externalizing and share their experience(s) with a piece of their own educational technology, whether the Forum takes place in Baltimore or via teleconference.

column7: Improving Discovery of Academic Literature Through Geographic Inference
column9: geographic information systems, discovery tools, environmental information, metadata automation, natural language processing
column10:
Technologies, infrastructure, and/or vendor relations
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: We will demonstrate a tool developed at Kansas State University and the University of Idaho to improve on the problems of georeferencing academic literature through NLP and automation. We will discuss new ways of using spatial data layers to infer additional metadata to enhance the searching/browsing process for users.
column17: We will demonstrate a tool developed at Kansas State University and the University of Idaho to improve on the problems of georeferencing academic literature through NLP and automation. We will discuss new ways of using spatial data layers to infer additional metadata to enhance the searching/browsing process for users.
column18:
Searching scientific literature typically involves using keywords or controlled vocabularies, ignoring the geographic location of where the research was done. When geographic location is present, it is usually in the form of a laboriously assigned controlled vocabulary. Many “georeferenced bibliographies” have tried to improve on this by geolocating the study area described in the article, but are often unsustainable, requiring extensive labor. Our presentation will highlight a project at K-State and the University of Idaho to improve on these problems. We will demonstrate a prototype for automating georeferencing of documents and providing a search/browse interface that uses the location to infer additional metadata through the use of varying spatial data layers. We will use audience contributions to explore the logic of how geographic locations can be used to create better recall and precision in searching.

Good platforms for literature discovery cost time, labor, and expertise that often is only available through expensive discovery tools or academic literature databases. This project is entirely open-source and aims to make its bibliographic catalog of georeferenced literature openly available without restriction, through an API as well as custom-built widgets for some existing systems used in libraries. Our belief is that innovations in allowing a user to find papers based on their inferred context - e.g., a search for papers on domestic violence where one can limit to locations based on a map of population density or income levels - should be available to all users and libraries. Our project aims to do so.

column9: augmented reality, student empowerment, politics and technology, labor
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.

column16: This presentation discusses the Penn and Slavery Project, an augmented reality tour and a research website, in the context of political and technological realities at the University of Pennsylvania. It considers how librarians structured opportunities to empower students to harness the possibility and technology of augmented reality for public scholarship.
column17: This presentation discusses the Penn and Slavery Project, an augmented reality tour and a research website, in the context of political and technological realities at the University of Pennsylvania. It considers how librarians structured opportunities to empower students to harness the possibility and technology of augmented reality for public scholarship.
column18:
This presentation will discuss the Penn and Slavery Project in the context of political and technological realities at the University of Pennsylvania. The Penn and Slavery Project describes and engages with the history of slavery at the University of Pennsylvania through an augmented reality tour and a research website. It traces how the University fundraised from slaveholders, the foundational Penn trustees who enslaved people, the medical school’s role in developing and promoting racist theories, the unequal access to education across the history of the university, and the resilience and contributions of Penn’s black community.

The Penn and Slavery Project is a student-led project, invested in by faculty and librarians, funded by the Provost and several departments and centers at the university. Over the past two years, it has been a hybrid project and course-series led by student researchers and technologists with the help of an outside AR firm and librarians. This presentation will consider how this project empowered students within the frameworks of university labor, including the ways that Penn librarians structured opportunities for students to learn and succeed. It will also examine how the students have harnessed AR within the political context of self-representation and university-representation, looking at the decisions they made around framing, storytelling, design, and the development of experiences for the public.

column16: Institutions with digital materials often lack dedicated positions or substantial budgets. How can new trends be introduced when there is a lack of technical expertise or administrative buy-in? Panelists will discuss proven tactics like relationship building, surveying peer institutions, and skill development and how these tools can spur positive change.
column17: Institutions with digital materials often lack dedicated positions or substantial budgets. How can new trends be introduced when there is a lack of technical expertise or administrative buy-in? Panelists will discuss proven tactics like relationship building, surveying peer institutions, and skill development and how these tools can spur positive change.
column18: Introducing change in any organization can be difficult for a variety of reasons. Institutions with digital materials in their collections often lack sufficient budgets or dedicated positions, and frequently struggle in the face of embedded cultural norms, limited staff resources, and internal politics and policies. These common realities can seem like impossible barriers to introducing new methods in digital stewardship or moving initiatives forward. This panel brings together four distinct perspectives that demonstrate how new trends, technologies, and approaches can be introduced into environments where lack of technical expertise, administrative buy-in, or other factors might otherwise impede positive change. Panelists from the New-York Historical Society, the Bancroft Library at UC Berkeley, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, and AVP will discuss how they have applied proven tactics like relationship building, technical needs assessments, and peer institution surveys to help introduce new approaches that enhance processing, discovery, and preservation of digital collections and content. Each panelist will highlight techniques and approaches from their local environment and will discuss what has worked and what hasn’t as they attempt to tackle the challenges inherent in moving change forward.

column7: Moving From Wondering To Researching In The Era Of COVID-19

column16: Finding topics and researching is becoming more complex, and requires a lot of ingenuity, creativity, and flexibility especially in the era of a global pandemic. Join this powerful workshop where participants will engage in an interactive session on finding research topics and conducting research through a series of activities.
column17: Finding topics and researching is becoming more complex, and requires a lot of ingenuity, creativity, and flexibility especially in the era of a global pandemic. Join this powerful workshop where participants will engage in an interactive session on finding research topics and conducting research through a series of activities.
column18:
Finding topics, accessing research sites, and conducting research has been and is getting more challenging especially in these times of crisis. The global pandemic has exceptionally increased the complexity related to research and data collection. Yet, global pandemic should not prevent practitioners from engaging in research and collecting data. In this workshop, we will focus on how to advance research in the COVID-19 era. The presenters will discuss ways to find research topics, and conduct research in the midst of a global pandemic. Participants in this workshop will learn how to transform their ideas, interests, hesitations, and/or questions develop research questions and projects. Presenters will engage participants in guided small group discussions, with the purpose of having participants reflect on and consider their work environments as research sites (e.g. working from home). Presenters will also engage participants in a series of group discussions to enable participants to consider the daily activities related to their work as data. As this is a group activity, participants will be able to learn from each other, which will lead to deeply meaningful discussions and insights. Research approaches, techniques, technologies, and tools will then be shared with participants as avenues to may explore to advance research in this era. This workshop is appropriate for students and practitioners in digital library, archives, museums, and other technology-related fields. As a result of this workshop, participants will:

· Recognize research opportunities

· Develop strategies for conducting research

· Identify technologies/tools and research approaches appropriate for research

• Learn how to engage in research building off of an established archive

column16: During COVID-19, University of Oregon Digital Research, Education, and Media (DREAM) Lab undergraduate students needed to work remotely. The management infrastructure built by Digital Scholarship Services (DSS) was able to provide student workers experience developing a digital project translation sample library for use in library consultations.
column17: During COVID-19, University of Oregon Digital Research, Education, and Media (DREAM) Lab undergraduate students needed to work remotely. The management infrastructure built by Digital Scholarship Services (DSS) was able to provide student workers experience developing a digital project translation sample library for use in library consultations.
column18:
At the beginning of the COVID-19 crisis, the University of Oregon Libraries were closed to the public and non-essential staff. This made the work of responding in real-time to Digital Research, Education, and Media (DREAM) Lab service point needs difficult. To ensure continuity for the DREAM Lab’s mission and employment for student staff, a protocol was designed to continue efforts to expand digital scholarship and research data management support for the University. Digital Scholarship Services worked to create a telework infrastructure that would foster well-being, provide remote support and management, and offer student workers hands-on experience in developing digital scholarship projects.

Student work helped create a sample library for faculty consultations, demonstrating the same project represented in two or more platforms. This sample library helps explain the differences between platforms beyond feature charts, providing interactivity and clarity for faculty who come to consultations with an idea of what platform they want to use for projects or have an idea but are unsure of what platform would represent their idea best.

Students acquired hands-on experience building digital projects using tools applied to digital research within the humanities; gained practical data management skills for organizing, storing, and reusing digital information; applied content developed for original digital project that supports humanistic inquiry; described how original digital projects transform through translation to a different digital platform; and reproduced specific digital projects designed to contribute to open education, research and the public good.
column19:
At the beginning of the COVID-19 crisis, the University of Oregon Libraries were closed to the public and non-essential staff. This made the work of responding in real-time to Digital Research, Education, and Media (DREAM) Lab service point needs difficult. To ensure continuity for the DREAM Lab’s mission and employment for student staff, a protocol was designed to continue efforts to expand digital scholarship and research data management support for the University. Digital Scholarship Services worked to create a telework infrastructure that would foster well-being, provide remote support and management, and offer student workers hands-on experience in developing digital scholarship projects.
Student work helped create a sample library for faculty consultations, demonstrating the same project represented in two or more platforms. This sample library helps explain the differences between platforms beyond feature charts, providing interactivity and clarity for faculty who come to consultations with an idea of what platform they want to use for projects or have an idea but are unsure of what platform would represent their idea best.
Students acquired hands-on experience building digital projects using tools applied to digital research within the humanities; gained practical data management skills for organizing, storing, and reusing digital information; applied content developed for original digital project that supports humanistic inquiry; described how original digital projects transform through translation to a different digital platform; and reproduced specific digital projects designed to contribute to open education, research and the public good.

column5: Montana State University, United States of America
column7: How Qualitative Data Stewardship Practices Can Inform Responsible Stewardship of Big Social Data
column9: big social data, data ethics, data curation, data stewardship, qualitative data reuse
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: The ethical and epistemological challenges of research with big social data are well-established. How can we responsibly use and archive big social data? This presentation suggests that robust data stewardship strategies developed to support qualitative data reuse can inform similar practices for big social data.
column17: The ethical and epistemological challenges of research with big social data are well-established. How can we responsibly use and archive big social data? This presentation suggests that robust data stewardship strategies developed to support qualitative data reuse can inform similar practices for big social data.
column18:
Big social data (such as social media and blogs) and archived qualitative data (such as interview transcripts and diaries) are similar, but their respective communities of practice are under-connected. Both types of research repurpose existing social data to advance discoveries in social science. Both also present challenges of context, informed consent, privacy and confidentiality, and intellectual property. However, despite these similarities, big social research has not yet been widely framed as a form of qualitative data reuse, and qualitative data reuse has only begun to be discussed through a big social data lens.

Qualitative data reuse is a more established practice, and therefore has more developed data stewardship strategies to support epistemologically-sound, ethical, and legal data sharing. Data stewardship strategies that support responsible reuse of qualitative data include data management planning, metadata schemes, and restricted access. However, issues still exist, including issues around scaling up qualitative research by combining archived data to support longitudinal studies and broader insights.

Data stewardship for big social data is less well-developed, and there is little consensus about how to maintain balance between transparency and protecting research subjects. Addressing this challenge is especially important when researching vulnerable or marginalized communities who connect via social media. While data stewardship practices could alleviate some of these challenges, such practices are still in development.

This presentation suggests that librarians and data curators can use the robust data stewardship practices that support qualitative data reuse to inform similar practices to support responsible research and archiving for big social data.

column7: Tracing Paths to Digital Humanities Competencies
column9: digital humanities, assessment, services, program design, sustainability

Education and/or professional development

column16: The Indiana University Libraries and Institute of Digital Arts & Humanities have built a pipeline of digital humanities programming for students and faculty. By harnessing data analysis approaches through design-thinking, this presentation will trace scholars’ paths towards digital humanities competencies and provide a template for assessing similar programs.
column17: The Indiana University Libraries and Institute of Digital Arts & Humanities have built a pipeline of digital humanities programming for students and faculty. By harnessing data analysis approaches through design-thinking, this presentation will trace scholars’ paths towards digital humanities competencies and provide a template for assessing similar programs.
column18:
Digital humanities (DH) centers use many approaches to foster outreach, exposure, and engagement with digital methods in disciplinary contexts. Data collected from these programs, such as consultation logs or workshop attendance, provide insight at a program-level or on a semester-by-semester basis. Through design-thinking assessment techniques (i.e., journey mapping), this presentation will review several years of data gathered in order to determine how a DH center’s programming impacts its institution.

At Indiana University (IU) Bloomington, the IU Libraries and the Institute of Digital Arts & Humanities (IDAH) have built multifaceted DH programs: workshops, consultations, certificates/minors, internships, faculty and graduate student fellowships, HASTAC scholarships, an intensive incubator, symposia, and speaker series. These programs promote digital skills acquisition by creating a pipeline towards sustainable, permeable competencies in DH research and pedagogy. This pipeline also supports cross-institutional partnerships, which strengthen a shared knowledge base and extends our community of practice across campus and beyond. Since late 2014, we have collected data about our scholars—from attendance and affiliation information to more detailed information about rank, role and funding—to help us effectively respond to DH needs and trends. We will illustrate ways that specific IU students and faculty have excelled (or stalled) by tracking their paths through these programs with an eye toward assessing how programs interact as a whole. Moreover, we will identify scalable approaches that can be adapted by other institutions as we continue to build and improve digital humanities programs to effectively support the intersection of digitally-inflected research methods and humanities scholarship.

column7: Developing A Framework for Managing Blended Moravian Archival Collections in Northern Labrador
column9: partnerships, Indigenous archives, rural archives, capacity, ethics
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
2019
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: The international dispersal, contrasting epistemologies of ownership and sheer volume make the management of Moravian archival records relating to Northern Labrador complex. Our CLIR-funded project is laying the groundwork for a partnership of organizations in Northern Labrador that will address these issues.
column17: The international dispersal, contrasting epistemologies of ownership and sheer volume make the management of Moravian archival records relating to Northern Labrador complex. Our CLIR-funded project is laying the groundwork for a partnership of organizations in Northern Labrador that will address these issues.
column18: Managing archival records generated by Moravian missionaries in Northern Labrador is a complex task. In addition to those issues common to archives in Northern and rural communities such as the lack of infrastructure and uneven capacity, here, the Moravian records pose a range of other challenges: international dispersal, contrasting epistemologies of ownership and the sheer volume of material. In giving us the means to digitize a large chunk of this international collection, CLIR has also laid the groundwork for a partnership of organizations in Northern Labrador to begin addressing these issues. My presentation will focus upon how we are going about this work, beginning with a novel partnership between the Nunatsiavut Government and Moravian Church in Newfoundland & Labrador.
