column7: Capturing Oral Histories During a Pandemic
column9: oral history, COVID-19
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: A health sciences library and large academic library worked together with the medical ethics and humanities program in the school of medicine to develop a protocol and collection to capture Oral Histories during the COVID-19 pandemic.
column17: A health sciences library and large academic library worked together with the medical ethics and humanities program in the school of medicine to develop a protocol and collection to capture Oral Histories during the COVID-19 pandemic.
column18: This session will highlight a way of collaborating during a time of crisis and showcase how an idea from a physician became a reality. In early April 2020, a physician from the emergency department at the institution’s hospital approached the library asking if there was a way to document the collaboration efforts he was seeing around the hospital and beyond to confront the COVID-19 pandemic. After being connected to an oral history expert in the medical humanities program at the School of Medicine, a protocol was developed that helped speak to the process of capturing these important stories. Librarians at the main campus academic library created a collection that began capturing photos and stories from around the state about the crisis. This collection was expanded and adapted to involve a section dedicated to oral histories. An electronic release form was developed and entrees could be collected digitally. All oral histories could be taken through a videoconferencing application, making the full process easy for busy healthcare workers that also comply with current health regulations.

Services and programs

column16: Digital scholarship programs are central organizations for integrating digital technologies into research, teaching, and engagement work at universities. But how these programs are organized, what they support, and how they measure their effectiveness is understudied. Our survey of R1 digital scholarship program leaders illuminates what these programs do in practice.
column17: Digital scholarship programs are central organizations for integrating digital technologies into research, teaching, and engagement work at universities. But how these programs are organized, what they support, and how they measure their effectiveness is understudied. Our survey of R1 digital scholarship program leaders illuminates what these programs do in practice.
column18:
Although universities have supported the use of digital technologies in research, teaching, and outreach activities for decades, how this support is formalized varies across institutions. “Digital scholarship programs” have emerged as the central form of organizing support services for integrating digital tools into scholarship, but just how these programs are organized, what they support, and how they perceive and measure their own effectiveness is understudied--with the most recent survey of major programs now nearly five years old. Through our 17-question survey that was sent to 99 leaders of digital scholarship programs at Carnegie Classification as R1 (Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity), we have gained insight into the current organization and practices of these programs at large institutions in the United States. Respondents reported detailed descriptions of resources, staff, activities, practices, and perceptions of their own program.

In this poster we will present the most significant results from our survey including digital scholarship programs’ sources of funding, constituent demographics, most frequent requests, outreach strategies, and qualitative highlights of successes, challenges, and priorities for the future. By illuminating how such programs are constituted across a large cross-section of research-focused universities, we hope to offer conference attendees a portrait of these programs' usually invisible structures and to inspire attendees to consider ways they may build or reshape their own institution’s digital scholarship program.
column19:

column16: This presentation will focus on definitions and ethical applications for use/reuse of digital materials. The speakers will: provide finalized definitions for use/reuse; introduce the impact assessment matrix and ethical guidelines; and address the lack of common practices for what constitutes and how to assess reuse of digital materials.
column17: This presentation will focus on definitions and ethical applications for use/reuse of digital materials. The speakers will: provide finalized definitions for use/reuse; introduce the impact assessment matrix and ethical guidelines; and address the lack of common practices for what constitutes and how to assess reuse of digital materials.
column18: The DLF Assessment Interest Group Content Reuse Working Group is developing tools and documentation to better assess the reuse of digital objects. This is particularly of relevance to Galleries, Libraries, Archives, Museums, Repositories (GLAMR) practitioners since there are no established definitions, standards, or common practices for the assessment of digital object reuse. This presentation will focus on two resources currently under development: the impact assessment matrix and ethical guidelines for assessing reuse. The matrix helps practitioners to define and position activities along a use-reuse spectrum. Presenters will provide an overview of the matrix, both unpacking the distinctions between use and reuse and their various instances as well as highlighting the areas of continued debate. The ethical guidelines propose a set of core values, principles, and guidelines for the application of this assessment in a manner that accounts for the cares of GLAMR and stakeholder communities and the collections that they steward. Presenters will introduce the most current iteration of the ethical guidelines and discuss how practitioners can use it to develop more ethical, considerate assessment practices. Arguing that both the matrix and the ethical guidelines are needed to effectively and equitably assess use and reuse, the presenters will conclude the talk by articulating how the the two resources begin to address the lack of standards and common practices as well as by situating these outputs in the larger work of their IMLS-funded project “Digital Content Reuse Assessment Framework Toolkit.”

column16: Participants will learn about open-source software products of the Review, Appraisal and Triage of Mail (RATOM) project to (1) extract data and metadata from email, identify named entities and write results to simple database structures for processing, and (2) query, browse and tag email for record status and potential sensitivities.
column17: Participants will learn about open-source software products of the Review, Appraisal and Triage of Mail (RATOM) project to (1) extract data and metadata from email, identify named entities and write results to simple database structures for processing, and (2) query, browse and tag email for record status and potential sensitivities.
column18:
Participants will learn about open-source software to appraise and process email, focusing on two sets of software products of the Review, Appraisal and Triage of Mail (RATOM) project, a partnership funded by the Andrew We. Mellon Foundation between the School of Information and Library Science at the University of North Carolina and the State Archives of North Carolina. The first set of tools efficiently extracts data and metadata from email (mbox or OST/PST), identifies named entities and writes results to simple database structures for future processing, including application of machine learning. The second set of tools supports querying, browsing and tagging email based on a variety of criteria, including record status and potential sensitivities. Participants will run all tools using a web browser, so no software installation will be required. In addition to gaining hands-on experience using the tools, participants will also learn about the rationale for their development, how they relate to other available software, and how processing of email can fit

into larger digital curation workflows. We'll conclude with a discussion of implications for participants in their institutions.

column5: University of Utah, United States of America
column7: Developing and Supporting Technology Hubs in Libraries
column9: technology hub, VR, multimedia, 3D printing, virtual displays
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This interactive workshop will provide key elements in developing and supporting technologies with minimal budgets and physical space while building partnerships with faculty, staff and students that use them.
column17: This interactive workshop will provide key elements in developing and supporting technologies with minimal budgets and physical space while building partnerships with faculty, staff and students that use them.
column18:
Over the past several years, an academic health sciences library in the mountain west has developed four technology hubs. Hubs are shared and central technology resources used by campus partners. A technology hub can include tools like virtual reality, multimedia studios, 3D printing and virtual interactive displays.

This workshop will identify four elements for attendees to explore in developing technology integration into a hub model for their campus units and partners. Steps for this process, include:
- Knowing and identifying patron needs
- Exploring new technology
- Finding or repurposing space, and
- Allocating funds

Specific examples will be given throughout the workshop that demonstrate principles to sustain the technology interventions. Through mutual benefit and understanding, several stakeholders will assist the library in evaluating, implementing, assessing, and prioritizing changes in the hubs. We’ve largely used this feedback to align with recent campus strategies to use technologies to enhance education and research.

Learning objectives from the workshop include 1) identifying relevant technology tools and strategies to enrich library technology infrastructure and 2) reflections on ways that technology hubs can enhance library outreach and teaching.

column7: Saving Legal Information: A Cross-Institutional Model For Digital Archiving
column9: law, born-digital, government documents

Consortia, collaboration, and partnerships;
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This panel will focus on the critical importance of preserving legal information for the future and explores how institutions can pool resources and expertise to create affordable and sustainable digital archives. Particular attention will be devoted to striking a balance between autonomy and collaboration, while maintaining a supportive community framework.
column17: This panel will focus on the critical importance of preserving legal information for the future and explores how institutions can pool resources and expertise to create affordable and sustainable digital archives. Particular attention will be devoted to striking a balance between autonomy and collaboration, while maintaining a supportive community framework.
column18:
This panel will focus on the critical importance of preserving legal information for the future and explores how institutions can pool resources and expertise to create affordable and sustainable digital archives. Particular attention will be devoted to striking a balance between autonomy and collaboration, while maintaining a supportive community framework.

The Legal Information Preservation Alliance is a non-profit consortium of academic, federal, state and public law libraries working on projects to preserve print and electronic legal information. This presentation highlights the shared governance model of one of its major projects, the Legal Information Archive (LIA).

Born-digital materials are incredibly fragile and at great risk of loss or alteration. LIA was conceived to help combat the loss of this information in the legal field. LIA is a collaborative digital archive established to preserve and ensure permanent access to vital legal information published online. It is one example of how the law library community is taking on new responsibilities as stewards of its digital legal heritage. The genesis of the collection consists of materials gathered by the Chesapeake Digital Preservation Project, a collaboration between Georgetown University Law Library, the Maryland State Law Library, the Virginia State Law Library, and Harvard University Law Library. These archived materials consist of government, policy, and other legal information pulled from the Web.
column19:

column7: Responsible Machine Learning (ML) in Memory Institutions
column9: Machine learning, bias, automation
column10:
Social contexts and ethics/responsibility
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: In libraries and archives, computational methods can introduce distortions and bias, often building on biases of collecting and description practices accumulated over time and transmitting them into learned models. This session will facilitate conversation about how we might identify and examine bias across machine learning pipelines, both social and technical.
column17: In libraries and archives, computational methods can introduce distortions and bias, often building on biases of collecting and description practices accumulated over time and transmitting them into learned models. This session will facilitate conversation about how we might identify and examine bias across machine learning pipelines, both social and technical.
column18:
Machine Learning (ML) is poised to address significant demand issues in memory organizations because of benefits it promises to bring to bear (efficiency, speed, scale), and it will inevitably permeate aspects of operations that involve digital content management (digital libraries, digital archives, digitized special collections), sooner rather than later. In fact, there is a growing list of machine learning applications already in use in memory institutions.

But, without considering the organizational values, socio- technical issues and impact on society, memory organizations may repeat the same mistakes that other domains have already committed. Memory organizations need to prioritize discussions of value alignment and social concerns over optimizing operational mechanisms, especially in the context of ML because of its amplification powers.

University of Utah, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and University of Notre Dame are working on a project to understand and identify sources of bias in ML pipelines in memory institutions. Our intent is to facilitate a conversation with practitioners in the digital library community that are working with ML projects. As part of this working lunch session, based on literature review and our analysis of ML projects in memory institutions, we will summarize ML pipelines prevalent in memory organizations. Then we will frame open ended questions (examples below) to engage the audience in participation. Example questions:

What elements of the socio-technical infrastructure will need to be examined to understand sources of bias in ML projects in memory institutions.

Which forms of algorithmic bias can possibly apply to archives and digital libraries.
column19:
Machine Learning (ML) is poised to address significant demand issues in memory organizations because of benefits it promises to bring to bear (efficiency, speed, scale), and it will inevitably permeate aspects of operations that involve digital content management (digital libraries, digital archives, digitized special collections), sooner rather than later. In fact, there is a growing list of machine learning applications already in use in memory institutions.
But, without considering the organizational values, socio- technical issues and impact on society, memory organizations may repeat the same mistakes that other domains have already committed. Memory organizations need to prioritize discussions of value alignment and social concerns over optimizing operational mechanisms, especially in the context of ML because of its amplification powers.
University of Utah, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and University of Notre Dame are working on a project to understand and identify sources of bias in ML pipelines in memory institutions. Our intent is to facilitate a conversation with practitioners in the digital library community that are working with ML projects. As part of this working lunch session, based on literature review and our analysis of ML projects in memory institutions, we will summarize ML pipelines prevalent in memory organizations. Then we will frame open ended questions (examples below) to engage the audience in participation. Example questions:
What elements of the socio-technical infrastructure will need to be examined to understand sources of bias in ML projects in memory institutions.

column16: Along with creating improved data management workflows to organize and augment digital assets, Oklahoma State University Archives has been experimenting with machine learning. It was determined that bringing together a core group can help sustain the use of deep learning applications and justify further commitment of resources for the organization.
column17: Along with creating improved data management workflows to organize and augment digital assets, Oklahoma State University Archives has been experimenting with machine learning. It was determined that bringing together a core group can help sustain the use of deep learning applications and justify further commitment of resources for the organization.
column18:
The Oklahoma State University Archives identified the need for an updated inventory and documentation of valuable materials to guide the development of digital preservation priorities. Along with creating improved data management workflows to organize, clean and augment sparse and inconsistent digital assets, the archives first started to experiment with machine learning in fall 2018.

Since then, the outcome of applying machine learning and facial recognition techniques has shown promising results. Undertaking machine learning is not a simple process; it requires commitment of significant resources to be successful.

The experience has shown that one organization can find synergies through efforts with other library units when colleagues join the conversation. As colleagues are eager to explore ways to augment knowledge for thousands of archival digital assets or apply neural networks to improve customer service by automating sorting of help tickets, the use of data management strategies to optimize processes is fundamental.

This presentation will describe major steps, challenges and opportunities detailed in a recent publication and show that bringing together a core group can help sustain the use of deep learning applications and justify further commitment of resources for the whole organization.

column16: Digital collections are an important storehouse of community memory; how can cultural organizations balance providing access for users with maintaining trust from donors and rights owners? The results are surprising: in this technical discussion we look behind the curtain at digital access and permission management practices across dozens of institutions in Australasia.
column17: Digital collections are an important storehouse of community memory; how can cultural organizations balance providing access for users with maintaining trust from donors and rights owners? The results are surprising: in this technical discussion we look behind the curtain at digital access and permission management practices across dozens of institutions in Australasia.
column18:
Digital collections are an important storehouse of community memory; how can cultural organizations balance providing access for users with maintaining trust from donors and rights owners? The results are surprising: in this technical discussion we look behind the curtain at digital access and permission management practices across dozens of institutions in Australasia.

Members of the Recollect community curate digital repositories with contents ranging from hundreds to millions of items. Each institution enacts unique strategies for engaging their community around content while building long-lasting relationships with creators and contributors. This best-practice survey reveals the unique ways in which educational institutions collect and preserve at-risk heritage items; how indigenous groups extend their role as guardians of the past into the virtual space; and where new partnerships can pair cutting edge creatives with government agencies.

In combination with strong access policies, dynamic interfaces with context-aware data become a central tool for building a collaborative online community. At the same time, creating detailed user personas is essential for achieving maximum impact among a diverse user base. Through illustrated examples of effective policy, curation, and user management, this presentation will allow DLF attendees to consider a robust mix of tools and practices to safely grow online engagement.

column16: The Open Data Literacy project refined data curation curriculum in the University of Washington’s Information School to align with workforce needs, and collaborated with public sector partners to craft open data internships into rich experiences that increased student expertise and produced practical and sustainable deliverables for library and government partners.
column17: The Open Data Literacy project refined data curation curriculum in the University of Washington’s Information School to align with workforce needs, and collaborated with public sector partners to craft open data internships into rich experiences that increased student expertise and produced practical and sustainable deliverables for library and government partners.
column18: For over a decade LIS education has made significant progress on curriculum development in the areas of data curation and research data management. However, coursework that prepares students for open data roles in public libraries and government agencies remains underdeveloped. To address this gap, the Open Data Literacy (ODL) project in the Information School at the University of Washington has been working to update and create new courses, while collaborating with public sector partners to offer internships and other student field experiences in open data. Building on an established base of data curation curriculum, ODL integrated new modules covering open data in the public sector and tutorials on using APIs, Github, and OpenRefine, and other relevant technologies. Collaborating with both partners and students, the team evolved an internship model to assure experiences that increased expertise for students and produced practical and sustainable deliverables for library and government partners. This poster reports on the program evaluation conducted through focus groups with students and interviews with internship sponsors in public libraries, the state library, and state and city government agencies. We demonstrate alignment of student outcomes gained through the ODL program with key data science competencies (National Research Council, 2015), and how other LIS programs can adopt similar strategies to meet workforce needs in open data.

column7: A 3D Data Preservation Model in Cross-Disciplinary Use
column9: 3D, virtual reality, digital preservation, OAIS, workflows
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This poster presents the results of a survey on 3D and virtual reality preservation methods combined with the results of a multi-case study on 3D datasets at Virginia Tech University Libraries. These results culminated in a proposed 3D/VR preservation workflow employed by VTUL on a current 3D digitization project.
column17: This poster presents the results of a survey on 3D and virtual reality preservation methods combined with the results of a multi-case study on 3D datasets at Virginia Tech University Libraries. These results culminated in a proposed 3D/VR preservation workflow employed by VTUL on a current 3D digitization project.
column18:
Numerous disciplines are producing 3D and virtual reality (VR) data but without the guidance of published standards. After Virginia Tech University Libraries received a CLIR grant to digitize specimens from the Virginia Tech Insect Collection in 3D, we wanted to contribute to 3D/VR reproducibility by developing a workflow for 3D/VR preservation applicable across disciplines in the OAIS reference model.

We conducted a multi-case study in preserving 3D data in the OAIS model through interdisciplinary collaboration with several departments on campus using different types of 3D/VR datasets. The primary result is that what information is preserved has greater importance over how it is packaged for preservation. These preliminary findings indicated that the primary risks facing 3D/VR are software obsolescence, reliance on proprietary software and hardware, minimal support for popular file formats, and the lack of community-adopted standards and documentation for creation and preservation. These results are limited to samples of convenience, and collaborators providing these datasets are VT faculty. To expand on this work, I developed a survey composed of guided questions asking what data types our colleagues work with, creation and preservation methods, specific metadata schemas, and their level of documentation.

In alignment with the conference topic “Impact of Feasibility on Decision-Making,” this poster will present the survey results on the handling of 3D/VR content and the influence of their content types on preservation actions and workflows. This poster will also present the proposed 3D preservation workflow that VTUL will employ on the insect collection.

column7: The Sum of Our Parts: the Value of Multi-partner Collaboration
column9: collaboration, access, women, activism, discovery
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
2018
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: How do we value collaboration? In Her Own Right project panelists examine the impact of large-scale collaboration for end-users, contributors, and participants. From metadata messes to DAMS successes, we’ll share the benefits and value we’ve gathered throughout our process.
column17: How do we value collaboration? In Her Own Right project panelists examine the impact of large-scale collaboration for end-users, contributors, and participants. From metadata messes to DAMS successes, we’ll share the benefits and value we’ve gathered throughout our process.
column18:
The Philadelphia area community of libraries and archives has a long history of inter-institutional collaboration and strong local professional networks due in large part to the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL). In 2018, PACSCL was awarded a CLIR Digitizing Hidden Collections grant for its project “In Her Own Right: The Many Faces of Women’s Activism, 1820-1920.” The grant built on an existing foundational project and digitized collections from ten repositories. Over its three phases of production, the In Her Own Right project collaborated with a total of twenty institutions, targeting audiences including high school students and teachers, traditional scholars, and digital humanities users of raw data. The CLIR-funded phase of the project supported digitization, description, and aggregation of 9700 records and roughly 140,000 pages of content.

For the In Her Own Right project, collaboration is a means to aggregate and deliver subject-focused content to a broad audience via a unified access point for increased discovery. PACSCL’s mission is about developing a community of practice and the In Her Own Right collaboration demonstrates the benefits of working with a range of sizes and types of repositories, supporting technology growth and capacity, and sharing resources toward a common goal. This panel discussion will assemble end-user, project management, and project participant perspectives on how collaboration impacts the use and management of digital materials and lays the groundwork for expanded use of those collections.

A series of five short presentations totaling 25-30 minutes will provide the basis for discussion on collaboration value and impact. The project archivist will speak about what she has learned over two years of working with 20 repositories of varying shapes, sizes, and capacities toward the common goal of increased access. This perspective will include a look at the promise and challenge of funding that supports digitization and description, opening the question of how fully digitization projects support end-use: is traditional metadata enough? Two project participants, one representing a small repository, will discuss how the collaborative structure supported increased access, technology growth, and capacity building. Two additional panelists will talk about the use of project materials: an independent scholar will reflect on how research using a digitized collection in the context of a larger aggregate is different from using its physical counterpart; a repository participant will discuss specific cases of their institution’s materials in the In Her Own Right portal, particularly after COVID-19 caused the repository to close to the public and to most staff.

For the final 20 minutes of the session, the panelists will facilitate a group discussion on how we as content managers can leverage the power of collaboration to benefit our end users. The session is targeted to anyone interested in collaborative models, with a goal of examining existing projects to understand future needs.

In addition to CLIR, the project team sought and received funding from the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation, and the New Century Trust.

column16: Recovering data from legacy data tapes can be a daunting task. This lightening talk will explore the process of working with taped-based media through the traversal of a decision tree that takes us from a box of mystery tapes to rescued data.
column17: Recovering data from legacy data tapes can be a daunting task. This lightening talk will explore the process of working with taped-based media through the traversal of a decision tree that takes us from a box of mystery tapes to rescued data.
column18: Migrating data from legacy media can be easy when working with common and widely used formats. When digital tape-based media are the target, a longer process involving research, testing, and maintenance must begin. Drive hardware, interfaces, legacy workstations, and software access all come into focus as hurdles to overcome. This lightening talk will explore the process of recovering data from legacy taped-based media through the traversal of a decision tree that takes us from a box of mystery tapes to rescued data.

column16: This poster discusses the experience of planning a library-based hackathon. The Open Data Day Hackathon is an interdisciplinary event in which students create apps for the public good using open data. The poster shares insights and advice around planning library-based hackathons, including topics such as budgeting, promotion, planning, and more.
column17: This poster discusses the experience of planning a library-based hackathon. The Open Data Day Hackathon is an interdisciplinary event in which students create apps for the public good using open data. The poster shares insights and advice around planning library-based hackathons, including topics such as budgeting, promotion, planning, and more.
column18:
The poster will discuss the experience of planning a library hackathon centered around open data. The UTA Open Data Day Hackathon is an event where students compete to create an app for the public good using open data. 2020’s theme was “movement,” and included submissions related to transportation, migration, climate, ecology, and more. Collaboration was a core value of the hackathon, and students from a variety of majors and skill levels and types were encouraged to attend.

This poster will reflect on lessons learned and pitfalls encountered when planning and deploying the hackathon. Because most college hackathons are not created in collaboration with the college library, this poster will share insights for hackathons designed by and around the academic library, as opposed to those developed in coordination with the corporate technology sector. It will also provide insights about innovative student-based library programming around data and technology. In short, the poster will reflect on successes and failures related to the hackathon so that other library workers can successfully plan similar events.

column16: This poster summarizes the activities of CAWG’s Inclusive Metadata Task Force with the aim of both providing information about the group’s activities and deliverables as well as inviting conference attendees to join the meetings, contribute new ideas, and give feedback about where the group should go next.
column17: This poster summarizes the activities of CAWG’s Inclusive Metadata Task Force with the aim of both providing information about the group’s activities and deliverables as well as inviting conference attendees to join the meetings, contribute new ideas, and give feedback about where the group should go next.
column18:
First convened in 2018, the Inclusive Metadata Task Force (IMTF) is a part of the DLF Cultural Assessment Working Group in the Assessment Interest Group. Exploratory in nature, the activities of the IMTF over the past three years have ranged from reading articles together, creating and enhancing bibliographies, crafting values statements, and beginning the work of drafting guiding questions for assessment. The group has sought to be a welcoming venue through which participants can collaboratively build understanding and generate ideas for how to go about inclusive metadata work in our institutions. The IMTF also actively seeks out collaborations with other task forces and working groups.

This poster will summarize what the group has done so far, highlighting deliverables such as the values statement, the annotated bibliography and the inital guiding questions which are meant to provide grounding and a place to begin tackling the issues around inclusive metadata as a practice. The aim of the poster is both to provide information about the group’s activities as well as invite conference attendees to join the meetings, contribute new ideas, and give feedback about where the group should go next.

column16: The University of Miami Libraries recently migrated CONTENTdm. The actual data migration turned out to be the easy part. By focusing on the organizational and institutional changes related to a system migration this presentation will provide insights that are applicable to a range of institutions and contexts.
column17: The University of Miami Libraries recently migrated CONTENTdm. The actual data migration turned out to be the easy part. By focusing on the organizational and institutional changes related to a system migration this presentation will provide insights that are applicable to a range of institutions and contexts.
column18: Recently, the University of Miami Libraries migrated from a locally-hosted instance of CONTENTdm to an OCLC-hosted instance of CONTENTdm. The actual data migration turned out to be the easy part. The hardest parts of the migration were all of the processes surrounding the migration: identifying content, ensuring content was standardized and uniform, adapting to new features, coordinating across the library, etc. The migration also presented opportunities to re-envision workflows, re-evaluate current practices, and revise best practices. This presentation will provide participants with a roadmap of the migration planning process and a perspective on the work that occurs before and after the migration itself takes place. It will discuss how we built a cross-departmental team to accomplish the migration and what changes we made to our digital collections workflows and practices as a result of going through the migration process. By focusing on the organizational and institutional changes related to a system migration, rather than the purely technical ones, this presentation will provide insights that are applicable to a range of institutions and contexts.

column16: In the 1990s, The University of Virginia Library developed thousands of TEI-encoded online texts, but the original interface for these texts obsolesced and they fell into disuse. Today, these texts are being repurposed as the foundation for Literature in Context, an open anthology of frequently taught literary texts.
column17: In the 1990s, The University of Virginia Library developed thousands of TEI-encoded online texts, but the original interface for these texts obsolesced and they fell into disuse. Today, these texts are being repurposed as the foundation for Literature in Context, an open anthology of frequently taught literary texts.
column18: In the 1990s, The University of Virginia Library invested substantial resources into developing online full-text collections, encoded in TEI. As the original search and delivery interface for these texts grew obsolete over time, the texts themselves became hidden away in the library’s digital repository, obscured from public view and little used by researchers or students. Today, some of these texts are being revived and repurposed as the foundation for open educational resources. This presentation will describe how these legacy texts are being incorporated into the Literature in Context project, a collaboration between researchers at the University of Virginia and Marymount University, supported by an NEH Digital Humanities Advancement Grant. Literature in Context is an open anthology of frequently taught literary texts from the long 18th century, freely available for use by teachers, students, and the general public. The texts, which are carefully edited and feature media-rich annotations, are intended to provide an authoritative alternative to the unreliable texts of unknown provenance that students, seeking to avoid the high cost of textbooks, typically discover on the internet. Students themselves are key contributors to the Literature in Context project, working with their instructors to edit and enhance the TEI encoding of the base texts, and to add annotations written with an audience of their fellow students in mind. Literature in Context has also developed robust documentation and workflows to encourage students and teachers at other institutions to contribute their own texts to the larger archive.
column19: In the 1990s, The University of Virginia Library invested substantial resources into developing online full-text collections, encoded in TEI. As the original search and delivery interface for these texts grew obsolete over time, the texts themselves became hidden away in the library’s digital repository, obscured from public view and little used by researchers or students. Today, some of these texts are being revived and repurposed as the foundation for open educational resources. This presentation will describe how these legacy texts are being incorporated into the Literature in Context project, a collaboration between researchers at the University of Virginia and Marymount University, supported by an NEH Digital Humanities Advancement Grant. Literature in Context is an open anthology of frequently taught literary texts from the long 18th century, freely available for use by teachers, students, and the general public. The texts, which are carefully edited and feature media-rich annotations, are intended to provide an authoritative alternative to the unreliable texts of unknown provenance that students, seeking to avoid the high cost of textbooks, typically discover on the internet. Students themselves are key contributors to the Literature in Context project, working with their instructors to edit and enhance the TEI encoding of the base texts, and to add annotations written with an audience of their fellow students in mind. Literature in Context has also developed robust documentation and workflows to encourage students and teachers at other institutions to contribute their own texts to the larger archive.

column16: The University of Kentucky Libraries’ new pilot program, CreateUK, is a licensed web-hosting service that positions the Libraries as not only a service provider but also a campus collaborator. Learn more about CreateUK and discuss ideas for how the library can lead and partner in digital scholarship activity on campus.
column17: The University of Kentucky Libraries’ new pilot program, CreateUK, is a licensed web-hosting service that positions the Libraries as not only a service provider but also a campus collaborator. Learn more about CreateUK and discuss ideas for how the library can lead and partner in digital scholarship activity on campus.
column18:
In 2017, University of Kentucky (UK) Libraries formed the Digital Scholarship Center Task Force (DSCTF) to identify current services on campus that address digital scholarship teaching and learning needs, explore opportunities to strengthen existing services, and recommend new initiatives.

While there have been individual scholars, departments, and programs across campus, including the Libraries, engaged in digital scholarship activity, the DSCTF findings confirmed a significant gap in equitable access to web-hosting options. Thus, UK Libraries recognized a strategic opportunity in piloting CreateUK, a licensed web-hosting service.

In our first year of this pilot, CreateUK has become more than a web-hosting service for campus. It has become an entree to building new and meaningful relationships with colleges, departments, and campus services for whom common purpose with the libraries is not always easily visible or determined. Offering a web-hosting platform with built-in open source applications ready to use that is sufficiently flexible enough to accommodate diverse usage, positions UK Libraries as not only a service provider but also a collaborator in digital pedagogical practices and projects with faculty, staff, and students.

In this session attendees will learn more about CreateUK and how it is used to engage and partner with faculty and campus services. This session will conclude with an invitation for attendees to consider what opportunities they might create to engage their campus constituents in digital scholarship activities. Ideally, such discussion will yield additional ideas for positioning the library as a leader and partner in digital scholarship initiatives on campus.

column2: Digital Preservation 2020: Get Active with DP
column5: Virginia Tech, United States of America
column7: Choosing Archival Format By Machine Consumption Efficiency
column9: web archiving, file format, research data, big data, big data analytics
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: We analyze the reuse inefficiency of digital preservation systems and trace the root causes to data file formats and their design rationales. The archival formats need to be less human-centric and more efficient for machine consumption.
column17: We analyze the reuse inefficiency of digital preservation systems and trace the root causes to data file formats and their design rationales. The archival formats need to be less human-centric and more efficient for machine consumption.
column18:
Traditionally, digital preservation takes a repository-centric view on system design. The target of digital preservation is deposited into a repository, which also holds related metadata about them and provides discovery mechanisms. Once the desired digital objects have been identified, the end-user is expected to retrieve them from the repository and start the reuse on her own.

With the rapid growth of the scope and the scale of digital preservation, researchers and practitioners increasingly lean towards a data-centric view on its system design. The target of preservation is considered similar to research data sets, which need to be constantly interrogated, sliced and diced, scanned and transformed, and disseminated in forms unrecognizable from the deposited formats. The reuse needs to be embedded in the system, and the majority of the data manipulations have to be done by computers equipped with custom-built programs and procedures. The preservation system is therefore not obliged to preserve data in the same formats as they were deposited. Instead, the archival formats should be determined by how well they fit the purpose of the reuse. Misalignments will significantly slow down the reuse and render the preservation systems unusable for research. Open file formats are not free from such misalignment. We have recently discovered an up to 100 times speedup in analytics simply by converting the web archival files from WARC to Parquet. In this talk, we will analyze the root causes of such inefficiencies, and shift our attention to data file formats and their design rationales.

column16: The University of Florida Digital Collections improved facet values of the Samuel Proctor Oral History Collection, a high-profile national and international resource, using Oxygen XML Editor. This presentation will elaborate on the methods to spark a discussion about facet value improvement in digital libraries.
column17: The University of Florida Digital Collections improved facet values of the Samuel Proctor Oral History Collection, a high-profile national and international resource, using Oxygen XML Editor. This presentation will elaborate on the methods to spark a discussion about facet value improvement in digital libraries.
column18: Faceted search, also known as dynamic taxonomies, is a popular feature in digital libraries. Appearing as labels, facets are usually listed in digital libraries for users to select to guide the browsing or to refine (further) the search results further. To achieve its utmost efficiency, faceted search requires the facet values to be unique and simple concepts. However, usually cleaning up and clustering of facet values don’t happen prior to or during the process that digital libraries aggregate content from various sources. This leaves a huge amount of improvement work needed after the content is available in the digital libraries. The University of Florida Digital Collections pioneers the improvement work with Samuel Proctor Oral History Collection, a high-profile national and international resource, using Oxygen XML Editor. This presentation will elaborate on the methods to spark a discussion about facet value improvement in digital libraries.

column16: Universities are increasingly implementing Research Information Management Systems (RIMS) to provide a single source of data on university faculty activity. This presentation will describe the library's leadership in harvesting, normalizing, and creating data models for scholarly activities, and initiate a conversation on the library’s role in managing institutional data.
column17: Universities are increasingly implementing Research Information Management Systems (RIMS) to provide a single source of data on university faculty activity. This presentation will describe the library's leadership in harvesting, normalizing, and creating data models for scholarly activities, and initiate a conversation on the library’s role in managing institutional data.
column18:
Universities are increasingly implementing Research Information Management Systems (RIMS) to provide a single source of data on university faculty activity, including research publications, teaching, grants, and other scholarly output. There are no comprehensive or authoritative data sources for these inputs, and departments across the university vary considerably in terms of their publications and service activities. Librarians are well positioned to provide leadership and guidance in collecting and modeling data structures for capturing institutional data in RIMS.

This presentation will discuss our process for gathering scholarly identifiers and matching them with individual faculty to enable the system to more accurately harvest their publications. It will also discuss our approach to consultations with members of the campus community, including the research office, university administration, faculty, HR, and others in order to create data models to capture metadata about scholarly activities for reporting and discovery. This will equip the system to capture data related to outreach, engagement, open access, international collaboration, and other measurements that have traditionally been elusive or gathered piecemeal.

The presenters will initiate a conversation with attendees about their experiences and ideas related to their library’s role in managing institutional data of this nature.

column2: Digital Preservation 2020: Get Active with DP
column7: Software Preservation Lab Challenges
column9: software preservation, staffing, infrastructure, workspaces
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Software is ubiquitous worldwide, and ensuring its preservation is important. Adequately preserving and describing complex objects like source code, binaries, and hardware introduces major technical, social, and legal barriers. This panel will explore how staff preserving software create physical and digital workspaces to accomplish their goals.
column17: Software is ubiquitous worldwide, and ensuring its preservation is important. Adequately preserving and describing complex objects like source code, binaries, and hardware introduces major technical, social, and legal barriers. This panel will explore how staff preserving software create physical and digital workspaces to accomplish their goals.
column18:
During the Fall of 2018, the Technical Infrastructure working group of the Software Preservation Network (SPN) conducted 12 interviews of software preservation workers in SPN member institutions, as well as virtual walkthroughs of their spaces. This panel reports back on these interviews and walkthroughs in the hope of inspiring new software preservation efforts, collaboratively addressing challenges as a community, and inviting others to share their experiences with establishing software preservation programs. We will discuss a range of topics, from common challenges, to how physical spaces (“labs”) for software preservation are built, to decision making around technical maintenance, to how patrons can (or should) access software collections.

Of particular importance will be the theme of how software preservation work is often an extension of other forms of preservation work. Whether it is equipment used to perform digital forensics, staff that process born-digital archives, or infrastructure to maintain digital collections, the SPN Technical Infrastructure working group found that the foundations for software preservation work already existed at many institutions before a formal program began, and likely exist at many other institutions with or without current software preservation programs.

The second theme of the panel will focus on where software preservation work requires committing additional resources. The most expensive of these are staff time and collaboration across multiple divisions. Panelists will discuss how they have responded to these challenges and adapted their programs over time.

Framed by a brief initial summary of the interviews, the panel will consist of moderators from the working group and panelists who were interviewed.

Panelists:

Jonathan Farbowitz, Metropolitan Museum of Art

Monique Lassere, Harvard University

Traci Popp, University of Illinois

column12: Project management, including workflows and processes
column16: It is important for all the library units to work towards the organization’s strategic initiatives in academic libraries. This presentation will discuss the necessary project planning the USF Linked Data Group undertook to begin creating linked data for the digital collections at USF.
column17: It is important for all the library units to work towards the organization’s strategic initiatives in academic libraries. This presentation will discuss the necessary project planning the USF Linked Data Group undertook to begin creating linked data for the digital collections at USF.
column18: It is important for all the library units to work towards the organization’s strategic initiatives in academic libraries. Libraries are often working with lower than necessary staff and must prioritize projects. The University of South Florida (USF) Tampa Library Linked Data Group shares the same experiences where there is very little specific expertise nor allocated time dedicated to linked data projects. Yet, the Linked Data Group takes on the mission of transforming library digital collections’ metadata into linked open data thus providing greater access and discoverability of the libraries’ digital collections. In an effort to help support the library’s strategic directions for collections, the group has selected a small sampling of digital collection items. The focus of this project is to document the process of scaling linked data creation thereby making it possible to convert large numbers of digital collections into linked open data. The group has already experimented with creating a small collection — only 20 items — into linked data with the goal of learning the creation process. This presentation will discuss the necessary project planning the group undertook, as well as the discoveries and lessons learned along the way, to begin this next stage in creating linked data for the digital collections at USF.

column5: University of Florida & Digital Library of the Caribbean, United States of America
column7: Self-Determination: Intermutuality and Supporting Each According to Their Needs - Utilizing Agile/Scrum and Management Practices
column9: procedural justice, agency, inclusivity, meaningful work
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Libraries have been instruments of oppression. Alternative models emerged in response: decolonizing, postcolonial, postcustodial, slow archives. We discuss the Digital Library of the Caribbean's shared governance, mutual aid, mutual dependency, and the strategic application of agile/scrum technical development, and managerial theories based on fairness, for building community while apart.
column17: Libraries have been instruments of oppression. Alternative models emerged in response: decolonizing, postcolonial, postcustodial, slow archives. We discuss the Digital Library of the Caribbean's shared governance, mutual aid, mutual dependency, and the strategic application of agile/scrum technical development, and managerial theories based on fairness, for building community while apart.
column18:
Power inequities mean even well-intended libraries routinely disrupt people’s knowledge of and access to their cultural heritage. These institutions were allies in or at least instruments of the political and legal dominance of one culture over others. Alternative or mitigative models to this colonization have emerged in response: decolonizing, postcolonial, postcustodial, and slow archives. This presentation discusses an alternative model based on the Digital Library of the Caribbean (dLOC), which incorporates tenants of shared governance, mutual aid, generous thinking, community building, polycentrism, collaborative pluralism, and mutual dependency. Importantly, we discuss dLOC’s ways of working: utilizing concepts and methods from agile/scrum technical development and managerial theories based on fairness, fostering self-determination and supporting our communities.

dLOC’s alternative model is baked-in and extends through all aspects, including organizational design and technical development. For example, dLOC’s technical team follows agile and scrum for equitably engaging stakeholders to support each according to their needs. While agile and scrum are often utilized for deeply capitalistic ends, these are also methods that avoid top-down controls and instead enable voice of those most in need and most impacted by digital library technologies. These range from developers to stakeholders at partner institutions. Additionally, dLOC’s alternative model reflects concepts from progressive management theory that have developed over time in the literature but are not commonly applied to scholarship on digital libraries. These broad concepts include agency, procedural justice, and organizational support, and translate to meaningful work and community supports for other stakeholders and institutions.

column7: Teaching Towards Justice: Data Justice In Library Instruction
column9: data justice, instruction, data literacy, ethics
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: As academic librarians increasingly teach data science skills, attention must be paid to scholarship arguing that big data increases inequality. By integrating data justice principles into instruction, librarians can encourage students to become responsible data practitioners. This presentation outlines ways librarians can include ethics and justice in data instruction.
column17: As academic librarians increasingly teach data science skills, attention must be paid to scholarship arguing that big data increases inequality. By integrating data justice principles into instruction, librarians can encourage students to become responsible data practitioners. This presentation outlines ways librarians can include ethics and justice in data instruction.
column18: As academic libraries increasingly teach data science skills in the form of workshops and consultations, librarians must take steps to ensure that their instruction responds to the growing inequity caused by irresponsible use of data. As students learn about data science, a significant body of activists, scholars, and librarians critique the ways that big data increases inequality. This criticism usually revolves around how, why, and for whom data are collected and analyzed, particularly as it applies to marginalized communities. By integrating data justice principles into library instruction, librarians can encourage students to become responsible data science practitioners who design and understand the value of ethical technologies. Building upon LIS and critical data studies scholarship by Safiya Umoja Noble, Maggie Walter, Catherine D’Ignazio, and Lauren F. Klein, this presentation outlines practical ways that librarians can include ethics and justice in computationally-focused instruction, and argues that data justice should be considered a fundamental pillar of technology instruction.
column19: As academic libraries increasingly teach data science skills in the form of workshops and consultations, librarians must take steps to ensure that their instruction responds to the growing inequity caused by irresponsible use of data. As students learn about data science, a significant body of activists, scholars, and librarians critique the ways that big data increases inequality. This criticism usually revolves around how, why, and for whom data are collected and analyzed, particularly as it applies to marginalized communities. By integrating data justice principles into library instruction, librarians can encourage students to become responsible data science practitioners who design and understand the value of ethical technologies. Building upon LIS and critical data studies scholarship by Safiya Umoja Noble, Maggie Walter, Catherine D’Ignazio, and Lauren F. Klein, this presentation outlines practical ways that librarians can include ethics and justice in computationally-focused instruction, and argues that data justice should be considered a fundamental pillar of technology instruction.

column16: Providing access to sensitive data is unpopular within digital libraries and repositories due to the inherent disclosure risk. Hashicorp's Vault platform has made it possible for us to implement a lightweight solution for secure, zero-knowledge encryption of deposited datasets, while still facilitating access requests.
column17: Providing access to sensitive data is unpopular within digital libraries and repositories due to the inherent disclosure risk. Hashicorp's Vault platform has made it possible for us to implement a lightweight solution for secure, zero-knowledge encryption of deposited datasets, while still facilitating access requests.
column18: Digital repositories have historically avoided accepting deposit of sensitive data, including all human subjects data which has not been adequately de-identified, on the basis that they cannot provide adequate encryption and access controls to avoid a breach in cases where disclosure risk may be very high. This leads to researchers being underserved by our existing platforms, especially in the social sciences, where there may not be adequate funding to support bespoke platforms for sensitive data retention, and it limits the guidance that we or our ethics boards can offer them. We have developed a solution using Hashicorp's Vault platform that enables zero-knowledge (i.e., inaccessible to the repository managers) deposit of sensitive data to Canada's Federated Research Data Repository, while still facilitating discovery and managed access to these data sets. Our implementation does not require depositors or other users to have any special knowledge of encryption tools, and does not require researchers to retain their own encryption keys, increasing accessibility and minimizing the risk of data loss. We have also begun to adapt our curation guidelines to ensure that encrypted data remains discoverable from its metadata, while ensuring that our users understand the different considerations in working with encrypted packages. This work currently compromises a desktop client (using Python and Electron), as well as templates, workflows, and in-progress policies, all of which are open source and which could be adapted to any other repository platform.

column7: “Can We Digitize This? Should We?” Navigating Ethics, Law, and Policy in Bringing Collections to Digital Life
column9: digitization, ethics, copyright
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: UC Berkeley Library’s responsible access workflows and a corresponding community engagement policy support cultural heritage institutions seeking to digitize special collections by helping institutions navigate complex areas of law and policy. They also address social justice, adopting an ethics of care approach that balances potential value and harm.
column17: UC Berkeley Library’s responsible access workflows and a corresponding community engagement policy support cultural heritage institutions seeking to digitize special collections by helping institutions navigate complex areas of law and policy. They also address social justice, adopting an ethics of care approach that balances potential value and harm.
column18:
We will overview UC Berkeley Library’s responsible access workflows (http://ucblib.link/34C) that support cultural heritage institutions seeking to digitize the research-rich collections they steward. These openly-licensed workflows and a corresponding community engagement policy (https://digital.lib.berkeley.edu/about) reduce institutions’ burden of developing expertise in complex areas of law and policy, and address opportunities to make localized determinations when uncertainty arises—such as when metadata or rights information is lacking.

The workflows will help libraries, archives, and museums navigate the following essential digitization issues:
- Ethics: Are there social or religious customs, or other circumstances—such as threats of personal or legal harm, or risks of exploitation of people, natural or cultural resources, or indigenous knowledge—that may or should impact digitization of the collections materials?
- Copyright: Are the collections materials protected by copyright and, if so, is the institution the copyright holder? If not, does a relevant copyright exception apply that permits creation and distribution of digital copies anyway?
- Contracts: Do provisions in gift or donor agreements limit the conditions under which digitization services or access can be provided?
- Privacy: Do the collections reveal information that could impinge upon the privacy rights of the subjects under federal and state laws?

Particular attention will be given to the ethics workflow’s localized practices (http://ucblib.link/34D) which promote social justice by adopting an ethics of care approach that balances whether the value to cultural communities, researchers, or the public outweighs the potential for harm or exploitation of people, resources, or knowledge.

column35: We are hopeful that our presentation can contribute to a community of practice around ethics in digitization and promote the importance of addressing social justice in our digitization efforts.

column7: Towards a New Normal: What a Global Pandemic can Teach us About the Digital Acquisitions
column9: digital archiving, acquisitions, covid-19, donors

column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation will examine how the covid-19 pandemic has altered archival processes around acquisitions of digital materials, and the long-term implications of these alterations on donor transparency and ease-of-use. The work is informed by news media and institutional websites, and builds upon a survey and past research of the author.
column17: This presentation will examine how the covid-19 pandemic has altered archival processes around acquisitions of digital materials, and the long-term implications of these alterations on donor transparency and ease-of-use. The work is informed by news media and institutional websites, and builds upon a survey and past research of the author.
column18: With the start of the novel coronavirus pandemic, many archival institutions were forced to shut down and drastically adjust their daily practices, moving away from their physical holdings and into an exclusively online environment in many cases. These unprecedented times pushed archivists towards unprecedented actions in all areas of their work. But while the covid-19 outbreak may one day be a thing of the past documented only in the archival records left behind, the actions archivists have taken during this period to adjust to remote work while capturing the documentary heritage of a global event provide enduring lessons on how we acquire records, and interact and work with donors of digital content moving forward. This presentation will examine how the covid-19 pandemic has altered our archival processes as they relate to the acquisition of digital records, and discuss how these alterations could benefit archival institutions in a post-pandemic world and positively change the services we deliver. Through the examination of news media and institutional websites, this presentation builds on a survey conducted prior to the pandemic and explores what our actions during a global pandemic teach us about donor transparency, ease of use, and digital acquisition processes going forward.

column16: This presentation explores a subject librarian’s experiences of collaborating with digital humanities colleagues to develop and offer programming that attracts multidisciplinary participation from faculty and students representing a variety of campus programs. Session attendees will leave the presentation with techniques for developing collaborative digital humanities programming and building cross-campus partnerships.
column17: This presentation explores a subject librarian’s experiences of collaborating with digital humanities colleagues to develop and offer programming that attracts multidisciplinary participation from faculty and students representing a variety of campus programs. Session attendees will leave the presentation with techniques for developing collaborative digital humanities programming and building cross-campus partnerships.
column18:
How can subject librarians collaborate effectively with digital humanities colleagues? What are strategies for developing digital humanities programming initiatives that stimulate interdisciplinary cross-campus participation? What are approaches for offering programs that facilitate sharing research efforts in digital humanities at any stage, as well as ideas and best practices for teaching?

This presentation will explore a subject librarian’s experiences of reaching out and collaborating with digital humanities colleagues to develop and offer programming that attracts multidisciplinary participation from faculty and students representing a variety of campus programs. The presentation will also explore outreach and partnership efforts with campus units such as the Michigan State University (MSU) Center for Gender in Global Context, and the MSU College of Communication Arts and Sciences, to develop and shape digital humanities programming initiatives. Best practices and lessons learned for collaboration and developing and nurturing productive partnerships will also be discussed.

Building on the knowledge and experiences of attendees, this presentation will include reflective questions for session participants to consider and discuss with others for developing their own interdisciplinary programming for faculty, students, and practitioners in digital humanities. Specific tips for effective collaboration will also be shared. Session attendees will leave the presentation with tools and techniques for developing collaborative digital humanities programming and building cross-campus partnerships.

column7: Minding the Text Mining Gap: Ethical and Legal Literacies for Libraries
column9: text mining, ethics, copyright, licensing, text data mining
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Drawing upon lessons learned from Building Legal Literacies for Text Data Mining (Building LLTDM; buildinglltdm.org), a recent NEH-funded Institute, we will overview actionable strategies for libraries to develop and implement core skills needed to navigate law, policy, ethics, and risk to better support text data mining (TDM) research.
column17: Drawing upon lessons learned from Building Legal Literacies for Text Data Mining (Building LLTDM; buildinglltdm.org), a recent NEH-funded Institute, we will overview actionable strategies for libraries to develop and implement core skills needed to navigate law, policy, ethics, and risk to better support text data mining (TDM) research.
column18:
Drawing upon lessons learned from Building Legal Literacies for Text Data Mining (Building LLTDM; buildinglltdm.org), a recent NEH-funded Institute, we will overview actionable strategies for libraries to develop and implement core skills needed to navigate law, policy, ethics, and risk to better support text data mining (TDM) research.

TDM, a form of computational text analysis, is an increasingly relevant and prevalent approach to social science and humanities research. Researchers often rely on library-stewarded or licensed collections to support TDM, yet shy away from building and openly sharing diverse and representative corpora due to uncertainty around copyright and licensing restrictions. The perception of legal obstacles does not just deter research: it biases research by limiting researchers to particular topics and sources of data, leaving important questions unasked, and rendering TDM findings less broadly applicable. A growing body of research also demonstrates how race, gender, and other biases found in openly-available corpora have contributed to and exacerbated bias in the development of artificial intelligence tools.

Building LLTDM, first previewed in a 2018 DLF presentation, addresses these challenges through a framework and instructional materials for librarians and research professionals to develop copyright, licensing, privacy, and ethics literacies. Having now administered the Institute, we will leverage insights to cultivate community input and action on key calls to action surfaced by Institute: (1) moving toward TDM-friendly library licenses; (2) integrating the literacies into digital libraries to better serve computational researchers; and (3) addressing ethics at the intersection of digital library collections and computational research.
column19:

column7: Mitigating Bias Through Controlled Vocabularies
column9: metadata, controlled vocabularies
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This talk shares experiences in identifying ways to disrupt metadata bias. The goal of these efforts is to arrive at a process that identifies and incorporates controlled vocabularies from marginalized communities, that respects their interests, and is not hindered by metadata formats or system technology.
column17: This talk shares experiences in identifying ways to disrupt metadata bias. The goal of these efforts is to arrive at a process that identifies and incorporates controlled vocabularies from marginalized communities, that respects their interests, and is not hindered by metadata formats or system technology.
column18:
Mitigating bias in metadata is not a finite task but this talk shares experiences in identifying ways to disrupt metadata bias. The goal of these efforts is to arrive at a process that identifies and incorporates controlled vocabularies from marginalized communities, that respects their interests, and is not hindered by metadata formats or system technology.

One way to mitigate bias in metadata is to know about controlled vocabulary options that exist from historically marginalized communities. Within the Samvera Community, there is a working group developing guidelines and steps to determine when a controlled vocabulary is useful and how to find and evaluate a relevant controlled vocabulary for descriptive metadata creation. Another way to mitigate bias is to have options to easily incorporate controlled vocabularies for use from multiple sources. Cataloging/digital collection management applications have varying capabilities to enable term selection using different or multiple controlled vocabularies. Additionally, Linked Data vocabularies can connect terms between larger, less representative vocabularies (like Library of Congress Subject Headings) and terms from a community’s vocabulary to aid and instruct end users conducting research online. Yet another way to disrupt metadata bias is to support communities who are providing controlled vocabularies. Working through steps to discover and use controlled vocabulary options from marginalized communities helps to center those communities’ concerns by advocating to use terminology from those communities in descriptive practice and encouraging software improvements to better support varied controlled vocabulary use.

column7: Images as Data with Computer Vision
column9: computer vision, access, discovery, images
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: The tutorial will highlight approaches and resources for transforming digital images into data for search and discovery. The tutorial will begin by introducing the concept of computer vision. We will then share available resources, which include tutorials, white papers, and critiques of computer vision for identifying features in image collections.
column17: The tutorial will highlight approaches and resources for transforming digital images into data for search and discovery. The tutorial will begin by introducing the concept of computer vision. We will then share available resources, which include tutorials, white papers, and critiques of computer vision for identifying features in image collections.
column18:
Libraries, archives, and other cultural institutions are making exciting and unprecedented commitments to digitizing their holdings. Recent events have amplified the importance of access and discovery to collections. Social justice movements continue to highlight how institutions of power such as libraries through their collection and access practices can be active participants in addressing inequities. As people including students, researchers, and life long learners explore, learn, and create from their homes, access to digitized materials has become even more a part of people’s daily lives. With funding from a Mellon-funded initiative called “Collections As Data” (https://collectionsasdata.github.io/part2whole/cohortone/), a team including the workshop leaders are developing methods for image analysis using computer vision among archival collections. At the same time, important critiques have arisen about the use of these technologies and methods, particularly how they may support or hinder social justice.

In the “Images as Data with Computer Vision” tutorial, we will introduce methods for transforming digital images into data for search and discovery. We will highlight approaches (ex. the concept of distant viewing) and resources (ex. tutorials for feature identification in Python and R) for transforming digital images into data for search and discovery. The tutorial will begin with introducing the concept of computer vision including research questions and outcomes that animate the area of study. We will then share available resources, which include tutorials, white papers, and critiques of computer vision for identifying features to increase access to image collections.
