column7: Global Press Archive®: Lessons Learned from a Massive Newspaper Digitization Program
column9: open access; OCR for non-Latin alphabets; world newspapers; digital newspaper collections
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation chronicles a collaborative program for the digitization and distribution of large foreign newspaper collections and lessons learned. Topics include logistical challenges; continent spanning cloud-based workflows; publishers and copyright; challenges of languages with non-Roman scripts (Russian, Arabic, Chinese, Japanese, others); and accessibility through consortia and Open Access collections.
column17: This presentation chronicles a collaborative program for the digitization and distribution of large foreign newspaper collections and lessons learned. Topics include logistical challenges; continent spanning cloud-based workflows; publishers and copyright; challenges of languages with non-Roman scripts (Russian, Arabic, Chinese, Japanese, others); and accessibility through consortia and Open Access collections.
column18:
In 2016, East View Information Services initiated a partnership with Stanford Libraries and the Hoover Institution Library & Archives to digitize 25 million pages of newspapers from around the world, most in Chinese, Japanese and Arabic, as well as Cyrillic languages. This partnership served as the catalyst for East View to greatly expand its own newspaper digitization program, now known as the East View Global Press Archive®. In 2019, East View extended the partnership to include the Center for Research Libraries to make widely available 4.5 million pages of newspapers with a combination of Open Access and consortia-wide collections. The Global Press Archive program will ensure the broadest accessibility to rare vernacular language newspaper content from around the world and further support research in the Digital Humanities.

This presentation shows both partnerships as successful models for digitization and distribution of massive newspaper collections, and highlights key lessons learned from the program. Topics will include: logistical challenges; development of global cloud-based workflows; publishers and copyright; challenges of working with languages in non-Roman scripts, such as Russian, Arabic, Chinese, Japanese, and others; and broad accessibility through consortia and Open Access collections.

The newspaper collections cover East Asia, the Middle East including Turkish newspapers, Africa, the Americas, Western and Eastern Europe, New Zealand, and Australia. Mostly the issues were published in the 20th century but some are from the end of the 19th century. Some issues have been microfilmed; others are originals. The quality of the originals and the microfilm varies widely.
column19:

column35: The partners in this collaboration span the globe from New Zealand, Cambodia, Laos, Russia, Europe, North and South America, China, and Japan.

column16: Learn about appropriately using color in charts, some online tools for selecting and evaluating colorblind-safe color palettes, and four design principles for creating maximally accessible data visualizations for all readers (simplicity, context, legibility, and contrast).
column17: Learn about appropriately using color in charts, some online tools for selecting and evaluating colorblind-safe color palettes, and four design principles for creating maximally accessible data visualizations for all readers (simplicity, context, legibility, and contrast).
column18: This 15-minute tutorial will introduce participants to a few key concepts, best practices, and tools (such as VizPalette: https://projects.susielu.com/viz-palette) for selecting appropriate color scales and color palettes for data visualizations, including recommendations for making charts accessible in print and digital formats and to folks with various visual impairments or color vision deficiencies. It will also share four design principles for maximizing accessibility for all chart readers: simplicity, context, legibility, and contrast.

column7: DanceDance Annotation
column9: video annotation, communities of origin, Laban Movement Analysis, Performing Arts
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Too often when documenting movement, the community within which dances are created is ignored or overlooked. By combining insights from knowledgeable members of the communities themselves with new technological tools we can improve the interdisciplinary study of dance and other forms of movement through structured data and well-curated digital resources.
column17: Too often when documenting movement, the community within which dances are created is ignored or overlooked. By combining insights from knowledgeable members of the communities themselves with new technological tools we can improve the interdisciplinary study of dance and other forms of movement through structured data and well-curated digital resources.
column18: The DanceDance Annotation project’s high level goal is to build a trusted video annotation platform for community practitioners, students, and scholars to produce and share new knowledge about the study of human movement. The platform will host videos of dances in an online space where members of origin communities can lead engagements with these materials, annotate videos, and assist in the development of a searchable database. Annotation will be supported by three vocabularies including Choreometrics codes, Laban Movement Analysis elements, and vocabularies supplied by the communities of origin. In addition to the annotated movement videos, the database will include contextual material such as still photos, oral history files, and additional documents supplied by the origin communities and other archives. Disseminating these contextualized analyses will make information about cultural traditions, as reflected in dance, accessible to a community of origin as well as researchers and scholars. Our platform will allow researchers to investigate questions that were previously difficult to study, such as: How can scholars and practitioners share and communicate findings on the evolution of movement practices in a given location? How can we compare specific dance practices in one or more cultures to better understand dance's relationship to identity building, social production, community bonding and social structure including factors of gender, race, ethnicity, and age? How can we return ownership of the dances to communities of origin? And finally, how could digital media technology allow us to see the movement more clearly?

Our platform will allow researchers to investigate questions that were previously difficult to study, such as: How can scholars and practitioners share and communicate findings on the evolution of movement practices in a given location? How can we compare specific dance practices in one or more cultures to better understand dance's relationship to identity building, social production, community bonding and social structure including factors of gender, race, ethnicity, and age? How can we return ownership of the dances to communities of origin? And finally, how could digital media technology allow us to see the movement more clearly?
column35: As those who design, develop, and support ethnic dance collections, archivists and librarians would gain a better understanding of the need to include communities themselves, giving voice to community members and return ownership of materials.

column7: Improving Discovery of Academic Literature Through Geographic Inference
column9: geographic information systems, discovery tools, environmental information, metadata automation, natural language processing
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: We will demonstrate a tool developed at Kansas State University and the University of Idaho to improve on the problems of georeferencing academic literature through NLP and automation. We will discuss new ways of using spatial data layers to infer additional metadata to enhance the searching/browsing process for users.
column17: We will demonstrate a tool developed at Kansas State University and the University of Idaho to improve on the problems of georeferencing academic literature through NLP and automation. We will discuss new ways of using spatial data layers to infer additional metadata to enhance the searching/browsing process for users.
column18:
Searching scientific literature typically involves using keywords or controlled vocabularies, ignoring the geographic location of where the research was done. When geographic location is present, it is usually in the form of a laboriously assigned controlled vocabulary. Many “georeferenced bibliographies” have tried to improve on this by geolocating the study area described in the article, but are often unsustainable, requiring extensive labor. Our presentation will highlight a project at K-State and the University of Idaho to improve on these problems. We will demonstrate a prototype for automating georeferencing of documents and providing a search/browse interface that uses the location to infer additional metadata through the use of varying spatial data layers. We will use audience contributions to explore the logic of how geographic locations can be used to create better recall and precision in searching.

Good platforms for literature discovery cost time, labor, and expertise that often is only available through expensive discovery tools or academic literature databases. This project is entirely open-source and aims to make its bibliographic catalog of georeferenced literature openly available without restriction, through an API as well as custom-built widgets for some existing systems used in libraries. Our belief is that innovations in allowing a user to find papers based on their inferred context - e.g., a search for papers on domestic violence where one can limit to locations based on a map of population density or income levels - should be available to all users and libraries. Our project aims to do so.

column5: ArchivesSpace, United States of America
column7: Taking Care When You’re the Constant for a Community in Crisis
column9: community, virtual communities, crisis, radical empathy
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: As an established virtual community ArchivesSpace was able to quickly leap into action during the coronavirus crisis and has been a constant for many. Constants may also need care, however. This presentation will consider ways that people and organizations can build radical empathy within and across a virtual community.
column17: As an established virtual community ArchivesSpace was able to quickly leap into action during the coronavirus crisis and has been a constant for many. Constants may also need care, however. This presentation will consider ways that people and organizations can build radical empathy within and across a virtual community.
column18:
In ArchivesSpace we take great pride in having built a strong virtual community over the years. Like much of the U.S., in March 2020 nearly everyone in our community confronted a new reality that kept them from their physical spaces, disrupted their regular routines and cut them off from their usual in-person professional and personal interactions. In math or physics a constant remains the same in all circumstances and all conditions. For many in our community, ArchivesSpace has become their constant in this time, and we have leapt into action and responded to the call -- developing new programs, shoring up well-established ones, being a steady presence as people sought things that would get them through the workday. Thousands of our users have attended events, requested help or just been in touch since the coronavirus crisis began.

But what happens when "the constant" is confronting a version of that same new reality? In a field of helpers, how can we signal for empathy from others and allow ourselves to need help? This presentation will discuss some ways that people and organizations can provide the support needed by those they serve without sacrificing themselves. It will also consider how to build radical empathy within and across a virtual community.

column7: Engaging with the Public Domain: Scaling up the Deep Backfile Project
column9: public domain, linked open data, serials, online collaboration, copyright research
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14: BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column16: We discuss how we've trained and supported dozens of library workers researching copyright information on thousands of 20th century serials held by Penn, and publishing it as linked open data via Wikidata. We show how the data benefits digitization projects and researchers, and how more can get involved.
column17: We discuss how we've trained and supported dozens of library workers researching copyright information on thousands of 20th century serials held by Penn, and publishing it as linked open data via Wikidata. We show how the data benefits digitization projects and researchers, and how more can get involved.
column18:
The COVID crisis brought both an increased need for equitable access to online resources, and an opportunity to organize a library-wide project in response to a remote work mandate. At Penn, we have scaled up a project researching copyrights of 20th century serials to involve more than two dozen workers in all parts of the library system. Staff who had previously worked mostly offline and those whose work was impacted by closures were invited to participate. We are investigating thousands of serials held by Penn that may lack copyright renewals or notices. We are searching databases and the Web for renewal information, other evidence related to copyright, and existing free digital scans, and putting this information in machine-readable linked data records tied into Wikidata. Making this information available will help make a rich deep backfile of serial issues throughout the 20th century readable and reusable by researchers not just at our library, but well beyond.

In this presentation, we will discuss how the project came about, how we developed training and tools to support and manage people with a variety of skills and backgrounds working remotely, and what challenges we've had to deal with. We'll also show some examples of what we've accomplished to date, and discuss how other libraries and interested researchers can benefit from our work and get involved themselves.

column9: GIS, HBCUs, instruction, disaster preparedness, maps
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
Affiliated with an HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities)
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14:
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
Affiliated with an HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities)
column16: GIS represents an innovative step forward for academic libraries. This panel will examine the use of GIS in a variety of ways: library instruction, disaster preparedness, and archives. As context and interactivity become more necessary, it’s important to consider and use tools outside the scope of a traditional academic library.
column17: GIS represents an innovative step forward for academic libraries. This panel will examine the use of GIS in a variety of ways: library instruction, disaster preparedness, and archives. As context and interactivity become more necessary, it’s important to consider and use tools outside the scope of a traditional academic library.
column18:
Academic libraries are always looking for new and innovative ways to engage users. As expectations of interactivity and context-aware design increase, it’s vital that libraries evolve to fit these needs and expectations. This presentation will feature a panel from the Atlanta University Center Robert W. Woodruff Library, which is the library for a consortium of four Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). Each panelist will discuss how Geographic Information Systems are being used in an academic library setting, such as geo-referencing of historical maps in archives, creating a geo-referenced directory of Georgia's natural, cultural and historical organizations (NCHs) for disaster preparedness, and using StoryMaps and custom Google Maps in creative ways for assignments in digital humanities.

Session attendees will learn how GIS is being used in archives through using ArcGIS, the benefits and challenges of this kind of engagement, and the importance of making underrepresented resources available to users. Attendees will see how a directory of Georgia’s NCHs was created, and how to replicate the project to preserve their own region's rich natural, cultural, and historical resources using free online tools. Last, session attendees will learn about teaching GIS topics through the use of StoryMaps and custom Google Maps. The panelists will also discuss how teaching GIS can be informed by ACRL’s Framework for Information Literacy for Higher Education.

This panel will focus on providing examples, demonstrations, and tools that others can use when implementing GIS at their institution. Attendees will be provided with applications, example assignments, and approaches to teaching with GIS.

column16: Historically, these workshops were conducted in a collaborative lab setting. But the COVID-19 concerns forced us to move the workshops online. This presentation will talk about the challenges faced during this transition and the steps taken to address them.
column17: Historically, these workshops were conducted in a collaborative lab setting. But the COVID-19 concerns forced us to move the workshops online. This presentation will talk about the challenges faced during this transition and the steps taken to address them.
column18: The Data Services unit at the University of Miami Libraries conducts workshops on data analysis and visualization using R. Historically, these workshops were conducted in a collaborative lab setting with students following the R script instructions along with the instructor. But the COVID-19 concerns forced us to move the workshops online. Learning a new programming language is challenging when the students don't have a good foundation and can easily get lost trying to follow a code. How did we alter our workshop material and teaching methodologies to deliver the content to the students effectively? How did we minimize the distractions for the students while keeping them engaged? This short presentation will talk about tips for successfully conducting R workshops via zoom.

column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Oral History as Data (OHD) is a static web tool that transforms interview transcript data into interactive websites. Users can publish, search, visualize, and share the text and audio/video from oral histories, qualitative interviews and similar outputs via the web in a few simple steps.
column17: Oral History as Data (OHD) is a static web tool that transforms interview transcript data into interactive websites. Users can publish, search, visualize, and share the text and audio/video from oral histories, qualitative interviews and similar outputs via the web in a few simple steps.
column18: This is an update for a project first presented at DLF in 2018. The Oral History as Data tool -- available @ https://uidaholib.github.io/oral-history-as-data/ -- allows users to publish, analyze, and visualize transcripts from oral histories, qualitative interviews, and other content via a static web repository. Using GitHub and GitHub pages, a full oral history site can be published for free, completely through the web interface of GitHub. The tool can connect the coded interviews with audio formats (MP3,SoundCloud) as well as streaming video services like YouTube and Vimeo. The presenter will detail the tool and its uses, demonstrating some of the sites the University of Idaho Library's Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning (CDIL) -- https://www.voicesofgayrodeo.com/ & https://ctrl-shift.org/ -- has developed using it. This past year the tool has received significant improvements and documentation. These updates will be featured, and the tool's future development as a CollectionBuilder type (https://collectionbuilder.github.io/) will also be discussed.

column7: How DevOps is Changing Digital Library Development: New Roles, New Goals
column9: DevOps, software development, collaboration
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Software engineering is moving into a post-Agile world. To build partnerships with developers, we need to understand how recent trends, particularly the DevOps movement, are changing how work gets done. The different mindsets of Agile and DevOps could result in new roles and new goals in digital library projects.
column17: Software engineering is moving into a post-Agile world. To build partnerships with developers, we need to understand how recent trends, particularly the DevOps movement, are changing how work gets done. The different mindsets of Agile and DevOps could result in new roles and new goals in digital library projects.
column18:
To be sure, our success in building digital library systems depends on effective collaboration with our IT colleagues. It may be challenging though when IT disciplines are constantly in flux, not only in technologies and practices, but in team structures and processes as well. Software engineers, for example, are now moving into a post-Agile world, just when we thought that we had mastered Agile software development frameworks. To build productive partnerships, it is critical to understand how recent trends in IT, particularly the DevOps movement, are changing how our IT colleagues are working. This presentation will describe the different mindsets of Agile and DevOps which could result in new roles and new goals as we implement our digital library projects.

Key takeaways: differences between Agile and DevOps, new roles in IT, impact on digital library development, how DevOps encourages respect and appreciation of differences

column7: “Voices of SMU” Oral History Project
column9: oral history; BIPOC; alumni; race relations; students
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14: BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column16: Since 2018, SMU’s History Department, Archives, and Libraries have partnered to create the “Voices of SMU” Oral History Project comprising 200+ interviews. Under this project, undergraduate and graduate students (typically POC) conduct oral history interviews with SMU alumni of color and are creating a related body of research.
column17: Since 2018, SMU’s History Department, Archives, and Libraries have partnered to create the “Voices of SMU” Oral History Project comprising 200+ interviews. Under this project, undergraduate and graduate students (typically POC) conduct oral history interviews with SMU alumni of color and are creating a related body of research.
column18:
Since 2018, SMU’s History Department, SMU Archives, and SMU Libraries have partnered to create the “Voices of SMU” Oral History Project. Under this project, undergraduate and graduate research assistants (majority POC) are hired to conduct oral history interviews with SMU’s alumni of color. The oral histories are stored in the SMU Archives and made available online in the Southern Methodist University Oral History and Digital Humanities Student Projects digital collection. 

Currently, the 200+ oral histories record the experiences of Black, Latinx and Asian students at Southern Methodist University, ranging from 1965 and the period of integration at the school to the present. Through this research, we hope to take steps towards creating a more diverse atmosphere at SMU, in addition to documenting and validating the unique experiences of alumni of color. For current students of color, knowing what their predecessors had to undergo can also be a source of validation and solidarity. 

Equally importantly, the interviews comprise a growing body of research the students are mining and presenting in a variety of venues. And, beyond numbers and diversifying SMU’s archives to promote inclusivity, the project has created research and networking opportunities for the research assistants and proven to be a positive way of engaging with alumni of color.

This panel will provide an overview of Voices of SMU and cover several areas of research the students are pursuing:
- Project Background: The Voices of SMU project has changed greatly over two years, both through streamlining and in response to the pandemic. This presentation will provide an overview of the partnership, including highlights, milestones, technologies, and workflows. (Cindy Boeke, Digital Collections Librarian, SMU Libraries)
- Visual Representation: Throughout Western History, people of color have often been visually depicted through white interpretations of brown, black, and yellow skin, but the representations that people of color have of themselves are often excluded. At Voices of SMU, we take innumerable steps to ensure that both the stories and the physical representations of participants are presented with dignity and authenticity, and we champion people of color by granting oratorical and visual agency. (Camille Davis, Camille Davis, PhD Candidate, SMU History Department)
- Counter Spaces: The Voices of SMU interviews demonstrate the importance of college "counter-spaces," which are spaces specifically for college students of color. This presentation will discuss how "counter-spaces" help students of color thrive at PWIs and challenge race-based micro aggressions, as well as the roles counter-spaces play in promoting inclusivity and standing up for students of color. Finally, the challenges counter-spaces face, some of which are caused by university administration, will be reviewed. (Nia Kamau, SMU Human Rights/International Studies Major, Class of ‘22)
- Multicultural Organizations: Based on her interviews, the presenter will focus on two SMU multicultural organizations, the College Hispanic American Students (CHAS) and the Association of Black Students (ABS), and illustrate the importance of continued financial support for their activities. (Valeria Reynosa, History and Political Science Major, Class of ’22)

column5: Haverford College, United States of America
column7: A Toolkit for Teaching in the Time of Covid
column9: digital pedagogy, online learning, curricular support, digital scholarship, special collections
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Presenters will share Haverford College Libraries’ Digital Pedagogy Toolkits project, designed in preparation for hybrid and online classrooms during the fall 2020 semester. This project strengthens the library’s role in teaching and learning at Haverford, helps faculty reimagine their courses, and serves as a resource for the academic libraries community.
column17: Presenters will share Haverford College Libraries’ Digital Pedagogy Toolkits project, designed in preparation for hybrid and online classrooms during the fall 2020 semester. This project strengthens the library’s role in teaching and learning at Haverford, helps faculty reimagine their courses, and serves as a resource for the academic libraries community.
column18:
While preparing for hybrid and online classrooms during the fall 2020 semester due to Covid-19, Haverford College Libraries launched a digital pedagogy toolkits project to strengthen the library’s role in teaching and learning and help faculty reimagine their courses while direct physical access to many library resources is limited.

The web-based project consists of three categories of modular toolkits that--in combination with each other--form innovative assignments where students engage with library collections and expertise. By combining relevant critical literacies to contextualize a research project, a digital primary source packet, and a digital scholarship toolkit, faculty can assemble meaningful assignments that meet pedagogical goals for hybrid or online classrooms. Instead of focusing primarily on technical tools, we take a problem-based approach, framing the hypothetical use of a kind of digital scholarship tool in terms of their fit with subject matter and desired teaching outcomes, while also proposing potential assignments.

Our goals in this project are to demystify digital scholarship and pedagogical methods for our faculty, grow the library’s strong connection to the curriculum during a time of crisis, create new opportunities in the curriculum for Special Collections and Digital Scholarship, and share knowledge and resources with the broader professional community. The toolkits also provide a way for faculty to engage in exciting pedagogical projects while maintaining equitable access to materials for students who are unable to physically access library materials. In this 15-minute presentation, the presenters will share the design and development process for the toolkits, as well as outreach strategies and potential future directions for the project.

column5: Oklahoma State University, United States of America
column7: Collecting & Modelling Data for a Research Information Management System
column9: Research Information Management (RIM) systems, bibliometrics, data ethics, university outreach, scholarly profiles
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Universities are increasingly implementing Research Information Management (RIM) Systems to provide a single data source on university faculty activity. This presentation describes harvesting, normalizing, and creating data models for traditional and community-engaged scholarly activities, and initiates a conversation on the library’s role in managing and sharing institutional data responsibly.
column17: Universities are increasingly implementing Research Information Management (RIM) Systems to provide a single data source on university faculty activity. This presentation describes harvesting, normalizing, and creating data models for traditional and community-engaged scholarly activities, and initiates a conversation on the library’s role in managing and sharing institutional data responsibly.
column18:
Universities increasingly implement Research Information Management (RIM) systems to provide a single source of data on university faculty activity, including research publications, teaching, grants, and other scholarly output. There are no comprehensive or authoritative data sources for these inputs, and departments across the university vary considerably in terms of their publications and service activities. Librarians are well positioned to provide thoughtful leadership and guidance in collecting and modeling data structures for capturing institutional data in RIM systems.

This presentation will describe our process for gathering scholarly identifiers and matching them with individual faculty to enable more accurate publication harvesting. It will also discuss our approach to consultations with members of the campus community, including the research office, university administration, faculty, HR, and others in order to create data models for a wide spectrum of scholarly activities. This will equip the Research Information Management (RIM) system to capture data related to outreach, community engagement, open access, international collaboration, and other measurements that have traditionally been elusive or gathered piecemeal. Together these steps provide a fuller picture of faculty activities beyond those represented in harvested citations.

Finally, the presenters will initiate a conversation with attendees about the library’s role in managing institutional data of this nature. Important components of this discussion will explore how to communicate the limitations of citation data to the campus community and how to develop a more nuanced picture of scholarly activity representative of all faculty.

column16: Pre-pandemic TikTok was a space for Gen Z, but it has quickly grown to encompass people of all ages. The Texas Archive of the Moving Image shares how they are gaining engagement for their content on the platform and other new space smade popular by necessity of staying in.
column17: Pre-pandemic TikTok was a space for Gen Z, but it has quickly grown to encompass people of all ages. The Texas Archive of the Moving Image shares how they are gaining engagement for their content on the platform and other new space smade popular by necessity of staying in.
column18: The pandemic has changed the way we watch and engage with media. People are spending more time on devices and in spaces like zoom, twitch and TIktok while on-site public programming has become a future dream. As a digital library dealing with archival content, the Texas Archive of the Moving Image has been experimenting and strategizing new ways to engage with its audience in a time when their regular screenings and traveling programs no longer make sense. In this session, interim director Elizabeth Hansen will discuss their experimentation with TikTok, Twitch and Zoom to engage new and old audiences with content in COVID19 America as well as the other institutional changes surrounding their Texas Film Round-Up program. She'll address new workflows and technology implications for the project that put an emphasis on digital engagement flipping the organizations focus from website first to social first.

column7: 50 Years On, Many Years Past: Queer & Ethical Linked Data
column9: queer, linked data, sexuality, open source, open access
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: HistSex’s 50 Years On, Many Years Past. 50 Years On is an open-source, freely-available resource focused on the history of sexuality. It is a platform for educators, students, and researchers that provides multiple resources. Additionally, it is a demonstration of the possibilities of ethical description and cataloging for digital libraries
column17: HistSex’s 50 Years On, Many Years Past. 50 Years On is an open-source, freely-available resource focused on the history of sexuality. It is a platform for educators, students, and researchers that provides multiple resources. Additionally, it is a demonstration of the possibilities of ethical description and cataloging for digital libraries
column18:
HistSex’s 50 Years On, Many Years Past. 50 Years On is an open-source, freely-available digital resource and collection focused on the history of sexuality. It aims to both support the ongoing work of historians and to fill a representational need rooted in the realities and histories of LGBTQIA+ sexual identity.

This resource provides a more concrete understanding of the queer past by serving as a platform for educators, students, and researchers. It offers:

1. A searchable, annotated directory of archives and libraries relevant to LGBTQIA+ research across the country.

2. A descriptive catalog of digital projects connected to queer sexuality and sexual representation.

3. A timeline of major events in the history of sexuality to help ground and pique public interest.

4. A bibliography of histories of sexuality reviewed and annotated by historians of sexuality, and librarians active in sexuality fields. Ranked ranked for audience reading level, sortable by topic, time, and place, and presented online in an open and easily-searchable format.

Built on the Omeka S platform, 50YO uses the Homosaurus LGBTQ linked data vocabulary, which is developed and maintained by an international queer community. Thus it serves as a demonstration of the possibilities of ethical description and cataloging for digital libraries.

This project validates and contextualizes existing fictional collections. Second, it is a peer-reviewed reference resource for educators and students, among others. Finally, this project provides a valuable resource for libraries developing displays for Pride events, window displays and exhibits in the stacks.

column5: University of Arizona Libraries, United States of America
column7: The Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F): Early Indicators from a Pilot Program at the University of Arizona Libraries
column9: fellowships, data science, digital scholarship
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation provides an overview of the Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F) program, which was recently piloted at the University of Arizona Libraries. We support graduate students in building capacity for campus-wide training in data and computational scholarship. Presenters will discuss program design, initial outcomes, and future plans.
column17: This presentation provides an overview of the Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F) program, which was recently piloted at the University of Arizona Libraries. We support graduate students in building capacity for campus-wide training in data and computational scholarship. Presenters will discuss program design, initial outcomes, and future plans.
column18:
Across disciplines, rapidly growing interest in digital and data-intensive scholarship creates a largely unmet need for critical training in technical skills. To address this need, the University of Arizona Libraries allocated funding to test a one-year pilot with four graduate fellows. Our program, the Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship (DS2F), is intended to build capacity for campus-wide training in data and computational scholarship. It address three known challenges in contemporary higher education: (1) insufficient training for data-intensive, computational research within subject disciplines; (2) uneven attention to digital pedagogy and strategies for teaching technical concepts within graduate training programs; and (3) a need for ongoing development of modular curricula that can be integrated into the classroom and extracurricular workshops or used independently by scholars and researchers at the point of need.

Our pilot launched in January 2020 with a series of workshops whereby library subject matter experts trained graduate students on technical and pedagogical skills. In turn, the students embarked on a process of self-directed learning with projects related to digital scholarship and data science, culminating in a series of open workshops that extend their knowledge to the campus community. Librarians’ instructional sessions (1) build connections between the cohort and mentors, (2) teach the basics of instructional design of short-term, modular workshops, (3) convey best practices in digital pedagogy, and (4) discuss open educational resources and open licensing. Early indicators from our pilot suggest that the model is successful and extensible even under the current constraints of the pandemic.

1: National Network for Equitable Library Service;
2: Wilfrid Laurier University
column7: Creating Digital Libraries that People With Disabilities Can Use: Why Talking About Compatibility with Assistive Technologies is Necessary
column9: people with disabilities, accessibility, digital libraries, wcag, assistive technologies
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Digital libraries are expected to follow accessibility guidelines to ensure people with disabilities can use them. Our presentation addresses the fourth requirement of the internationally adopted Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, which requires web content to work with people’s assistive technologies. This requirement is often neglected, perhaps because of its complexity.
column17: Digital libraries are expected to follow accessibility guidelines to ensure people with disabilities can use them. Our presentation addresses the fourth requirement of the internationally adopted Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, which requires web content to work with people’s assistive technologies. This requirement is often neglected, perhaps because of its complexity.
column18:
Digital libraries are expected to be built with features that recognize people with disabilities (PWD) as valued, contributing members of society. The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.0 are internationally adopted standards to support developers create content that many people with diverse disabilities can use. As with many public organizations, libraries are required to follow these guidelines.

Our presentation addresses the fourth WCAG conformance requirement. This states organizations need to build or acquire web content that is compatible with the assistive technologies (e.g., screen readers) that users with disabilities rely on to interact with the web. We draw it to the attention of the DLF Forum, because it is arguably the most complicated requirement. As the WCAG authors note, it is tied to sociological factors, including social and economic status of users.

Our presentation describes the situation this requirement puts libraries in using easy to understand and humanizing terms. We draw on our experiences as a sighted web and user experience librarian at a Canadian university and a blind accessibility specialist for the National Network for Equitable Library Service (NNELS), which provides books for users with print disabilities through Canadian public libraries.

Despite the complexity of this requirement, we offer two questions everyone can ask to make it simpler. First, we can ask about the assistive technologies people with disabilities in our communities are using. Second, when talking about web content we either develop or purchase, we can ask does it work with the assistive technologies our users rely on?

2: Northeastern University School of Law, Civil Rights and Restorative Justice Project (Boston, MA, USA)
column7: Recording Restorative Justice and Accountability: The Burnham-Nobles Digital Archive
column9: civil rights, metadata, digital archives, collaboration, legal history
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
Affiliated with another BIPOC-centered library, archive, and/or museum
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14:
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
Affiliated with another BIPOC-centered library, archive, and/or museum
column16: This panel will discuss the Burnham-Nobles Digital Archive, which represents the Civil Rights and Restorative Justice Project at Northeastern University School of Law. Highlights include the collaborative efforts of project stakeholders to honor victims of racially motivated violence and the archival value of social justice informed collection arrangement and description.
column17: This panel will discuss the Burnham-Nobles Digital Archive, which represents the Civil Rights and Restorative Justice Project at Northeastern University School of Law. Highlights include the collaborative efforts of project stakeholders to honor victims of racially motivated violence and the archival value of social justice informed collection arrangement and description.
column18:
The Civil Rights and Restorative Justice Project (CRRJ) at Northeastern University School of Law conducts research and supports policy initiatives on anti-civil rights violence in the United States and other miscarriages of justice during the period 1930-1970. CRRJ serves as a resource for scholars, policymakers, and organizers involved in various initiatives seeking justice for these crimes.

This panel will share the experiences of the collaborative team involved in building the Burnham-Nobles Digital Archive, which builds on CRRJ investigative records to create a public archive and database. This archive will be presented on a website which provides access through functions that center the victims, allowing family members and researchers to continue seeking justice and understanding of racially motivated violence.

The Burnham-Nobles Digital Archive, by furthering the CRRJ’s mission of restorative justice, shows how digital projects and archival records can honor families and communities who have endured racial violence. The archive is being built by a collaborative team of experts with diverse specialties in law, historical and legal research, and archival and information science -- meeting the CRRJ's vision for this archive requires institutional commitment and support for building a broad team. The work of the Burnham-Nobles Digital Archive team is centered on record-keeping as accountability for past racial violence and its ongoing effects today.

The project is nearing the end of the design process, using the expertise of CRRJ investigators, archivists, metadata experts, digitization specialists, data engineers and website designers at Northeastern University Library. The collection organization, metadata structures, and technical infrastructures next move into a testing phase which will evaluate both functionality and methods used to center the victims represented in the collection.

Raymond Wilkes will first discuss the CRRJ project’s investigate method, approaches to data and organization, current restorative justice projects, and the relationship between the investigator and archivist. Gina Nortonsmith will next discuss mission-driven archiving as represented in the CRRJ project: designing systems which represent and honor real people. Her presentation will touch on stakeholder dialogue and coordination of needs between CRRJ and the library, project management which straddles multiple library departments, and developing strategic technical directions in partnership with CRRJ project leaders. Amanda Rust will follow with a discussion of methods for facilitating the connection between project stakeholders and the data engineer and software developers that will build and refine underlying databases and new interfaces in support the CRRJ. Then, Drew Facklam will represent her work on this project from the perspective of metadata creation and its effects on the interoperability between the University's MODS-based Digital Repository Service (DRS) and the specialized collection-specific archival site. Finally, panelists will end with a Q&A reflecting on lessons learned throughout the project.

column7: Broadening Access to Big Bibliometric Data with a Community-Built Infrastructure
column9: Open access, digital infrastructure, big data, collaboration, reproducibility
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Despite demand, academic libraries struggle to provide big bibliometric datasets for their patrons due to the cost and specialized expertise the datasets require. CADRE is a cloud-based platform for sharing, provisioning, and analyzing big bibliometric data. Libraries share CADRE development expenses to reduce per-library costs, while increasing access for patrons.
column17: Despite demand, academic libraries struggle to provide big bibliometric datasets for their patrons due to the cost and specialized expertise the datasets require. CADRE is a cloud-based platform for sharing, provisioning, and analyzing big bibliometric data. Libraries share CADRE development expenses to reduce per-library costs, while increasing access for patrons.
column18:
The hefty price of big bibliometric datasets and the infrastructure required to support them prevents many academic libraries from providing the resources to their patrons and the broader community.

The Collaborative Archive & Data Research Environment (CADRE) will create an affordable, cloud-based platform that provides institutions of any size—and even members of the general public—sustainable access to big bibliometric data. CADRE stores, secures, and maintains big bibliometric datasets on the platform while providing a user-friendly, data-mining interface and data analysis tools.

Indiana University Libraries, in partnership with the Indiana University Network Science Institute and the Big Ten Academic Alliance (BTAA), formed a cross-industry coalition, including nine other BTAA library institutions, to create CADRE. Libraries can join CADRE through a tiered-pricing model, which includes a free tier of access.

The platform is currently seeded with Microsoft Academic Graph and the Web of Science and provides tools that empower individual researchers to work with big data, such as a GUI query-builder and a coding environment for creating data-analysis and visualization tools. Users come together in the “Marketplace” to share workflows, tools, research, and more—and to utilize what others share. CADRE promotes standardized, high-quality data with Digital Object Identifiers, advancing reproducibility and improving data provenance.

We invite DLF attendees to test CADRE’s free tier of service and share feedback on what they believe will make CADRE—a platform built on collaborative principles—the solution to all academic libraries’ and researchers’ big data research needs.
